This applies equally to men and women of all ages without discrimination.Our crews have the dficult task of implementing that policy and don’t always get it right.”Emily also told The Sun Online she wore the same outfit on theThomas Cook flight without any issues - while her pals also wore revealing tops - in a bid to prove her point.She added: Even now speaking about it I am shaking, I felt like I was going to burst into tears.She was flying from Birmingham to Tenere

title: woman tries sell leftover chinese food facebook
story: The fast-food bundle had four mystery dishes, two sauces and what looks like a bag of prawn crackers.The half-eaten food was posted about midnight on Saturday to the Plymouth Crazy Sell and Buy page at the bargain price of £.She wrote in the post she “paid well over  pounds” and it “only been sat here for a few hours”.The woman, from Devonport, claimed she needed it “gone ASAP”.It is unclearthis was posted as a prank orthis woman was genuinely trying to sell her leftover takeaway.She claimed the contents of her takeaway as four chicken balls with sauce that had been “undipped”, rice, prawn crackers, “untouched” chicken curry, “half a bag of cold chips”, chicken satay, chow mein and crispy chilly beef.The post had more than  comments in the closed Facebook group, but it was shared to a public page that amassed more than  shares and  comments.Some commented askingthe takeaway deal was still for sale yesterday and others wondered how much of the food was eaten.One said: “I thinkI’m honest I’m interested, is there any gloopy sweet and sour sauce ”Another added: “Bet all the chicken has been picked out. Itll all be sauce and veggies.”The woman appeared to offer to deliver the food.She wrote: “Serious buyers only. Can deliver for small free need to walk my dog anyway. Let me know.

title: danny dyer prince charles related
story: The future king couldnt hide his surprise as the Cockney actor revealed they were both descended from King Edward II of England as they shook hands at the Princes Trust this afternoon.As the pair met, Danny informed the -year-old royal he was in East Enders before adding: Just wanted to let you know were related.Prince Charles seemed surprised as an aide laughed at the actors bold declaration.The Prince of Wales was today attending the National Princes Trust and TK Maxx  Homesense Awards  held at the London Palladium.Danny had discovered the family connection on a  appearance on Who Do you Think You Are As well as a set of relatives from working-class areas of London, researchers also discovered a blood link with Thomas Cromwell, an English lawyer who was chief minister to King Henry VIII.And earlier this year, the -year-old travelled to Sweden and France as part of his documentary Danny Dyers Right Royal Family that explored the lives of his aristocratic ancestors.Of course, Dannys not alone in his claims, with other Who Do You Think You Are  participants including Alexander Armstrong, Boris Johnson and Matthew Pinsent all turning out to be of royal descent.But should we be surprised that someone with a cockney accent can also boast such lineage  It’s actually more common than you might realise.Statisticians have argued thatyou go back far enough, everyone within a certain group of people will have a shared ancestor.And geneticists have found evidence they claim shows everyone of European descent alive today shares enough DNA to suggest they all have the same very large set of ancestors from as recently as , years ago.And Dannys not the first celeb to dig up noble links, with Madonna, Paris Hilton and Johnny Depp all staking a claim to the throne.Even Donald Trump — whose mother was born in Scotland — has royal connections.He is related to Richard III through the medieval monarch’s great-great uncle, the st Duke of Lancaster, John of Gaunt, who died in .

title: mum sacked boss pregnant unfair dismissal
story: Aimee Sanderson, , of Garstang, Lancashire, was thrilled to discover she was expecting her first child after suffering a previous miscarriage.But she claims that when she told her boss Steve Brennan, founder of digital agency Bespoke, he responded sarcastically: Well, thats good news isnt it.Aimee, who worked as a digital content strategist, said that from then, she was hauled into meetings about her performance.She was eventually dismissed for gross misconduct five months later in December .The mum-of-one took the case to an employment tribunal, which accepted that her claims of unfair dismissal and unfavourable treatment were well founded.The  said that her pregnancy or intended maternity leave was a material factor in the decision to dismiss her.A report said: Mr Brennan took a decision, even before disciplinary proceedings were initiated, that the claimant was to be dismissed and concerns were exaggerated in such a way as to attempt to justy a finding of gross misconduct, the tribunal found.Aimee, who lives with her husband Dean, , and baby Charlie, now one, said she was shocked by her employers reaction to her pregnancy.She said: His reaction was incredible. It knocked me off my feet.It was common knowledge in the office that I had had a miscarriage.The mum-of-one said that senior staff at the firm had been critical when she called in ill with morning sickness, and that they were digging for information from her colleagues to askshe was under performing.Ahead of a disciplinary hearing, Mr Brennan set out his allegations in a letter to Aimee and claimed she had not delivered on work promised to clients.According to the findings from the tribunal, the letter stated the company found the allegations constituted gross misconduct.In the concluding comments of the document, the report said that her pregnancy or intended maternity leave was a material factor in the decision to dismiss her.Aimee, who is looking for a new job, said: If I hadnt taken the company all the way that I took them, what happens when the next person gets pregnant The whole experience put a lot of stress on my marriage, my parents.Butyou do something that you know in your heart is right then I think you are stronger from it.A remedy hearing will take place on April , where judges will decide how much Bespoke Digital Agency must award Aimee.Lauren Grice, head of partnerships at Bespoke said in a statement that the company would be appealing the tribunal judgement.She said: In  years as an employer we have consistently supported staff through family matters and have never before had to attend a tribunal.The employee was dismissed for reasons of performance and conduct in .

title: second eu referendum brexit vote
story: But how likely is a second vote before the UK leaves the EU on March   We take a look, below.Theresa May has spoken repeatedly against a second referendum, at one point saying it could threaten the UKs social cohesion.She said it would set a dficult precedent and that the implications for the country were serious.In fact at every turn, the Tories have ruled out any possibility of a Peoples Vote.An analysis by Reuters indicated there was no majority in British parliament for a second Brexit referendum among lawmakers.The study came ahead of a crunch meaningful vote on March , which May lost by an overwhelming majority, for a second time.If Parliament fail to reach an agreement this week it could result in a No Deal, or the PM would have to request an extension from the EU - which theyve shown themselves unwilling to do.When setting out the next steps, May said politicians will vote tonight on whether the UK should leave the bloc without a deal or not.If they vote against a no-deal Brexit, they will vote on Thursday on whether Article , which is the legal mechanism taking the UK out of the EU, should be extended.She also said that politicians would need to decide whether they want to delay Brexit, hold a second referendum, orthey want to leave with a deal, but not this deal.Tonight, March , MPs will vote on whether the UK should leave the EU without a deal and,that falls through, on whether Brexit should be delayed.Tory MPs get a free vote on a no-deal Brexit.At pm tonight, politicians will vote on a government motion saying that parliament rejects leaving the EU without a deal on March  - but notes that leaving without a deal remains the legal default unless a deal is agreed, allowing for it to happen at a later date.But,that is also rejected, therell be yet another vote on March  on whether to delay Brexit by extending Article , probably by months.If Britain does seek a delay, it would require the agreement of all the blocs other  members.Wednesdays motion has no legal force, however, and ultimately doesnt prevent a no-deal exit.Another option is to hold a general election, which Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn previously raised the possibility of.And a second referendum may also be on the cards, after nearly a million people marched in support of a Peoples Vote, campaigning for a second referendum to be held on Brexit.Some MPs, though are keen for a binding referendum, where the result would automatically take effect.However, the BBC points out, there would need to be a new piece of legislation to make this happen, and to work out the rules, for example, who could vote.A further option is another no-confidence vote, which May has previously survived, which could be triggered by Corbyn.After months of resisting pressure within his party, Jeremy Corbyn finally said Labour would back another EU referendum after his alternative Brexit plan was defeated on February .His U-turn came after eight MPs quit the party to form the Independent Group.But Labour has now apparently pulled back from pushing for a second referendum ahead of a week of crunch votes on a Brexit deal.The party is concerned that such a move could be isive for the country.Shadow chancellor John McDonnell said Labour would focus on trying to rule out a no-deal Brexit and the government’s “bad deal”.Today, ahead of the vote on whether the UK should leave the EU without a deal, Corbyn argued that May has failed, no longer has the ability to lead and must change her approach.Labours leader added: This is a rudderless Government in the face of a huge national crisis.He urged the Commons to listen to the country, including workers and EU nationals who are fearful for their futures, saying of May: She needs now to show leadership.But May said Labours proposals have also been rejected by MPs and she noted Corbyn appeared hesitant to back his own partys policy to move towards a second referendum.She added at Prime Ministers Questions: He has nothing to offer this country.Coral spokesman John Hill said that the firm has cut the odds on a general election taking place this year into - , while it is - that there is another EU referendum in .He added: “The odds on Theresa May leaving her position as Prime Minister are shortening all the time and it now looks like her exit from number  will come sooner rather than later.”A poll carried out by YouGov on March  revealed that  per cent believe Remain would winthere was a second referendum,  per cent say the same for Leave and  per cent would be undecided.From February  to March , the proportion of people who think there will be a second referendum jumped from  per cent to  per cent..The SNP have said they would back a so-called Peoples Vote and a number of Conservative MPs have also backed one.So there could be a majority in Parliament for it but a second referendum will not happen quickly and the first stage is for there to be an Act of Parliament.That will require the backing of a majority of MPs and it took seven months before Parliament signed off the previous referendum legislation in .Last time around there was a four-month period between the then Prime Minister David Cameron announcing the referendum in February , and the vote taking place on  June.But the Electoral Commission has said in future there should be at least a six-month gap to allow enough time to register campaigns and put counting officers in place.There is also the question of what to do about Article .This could be avoidedthe EU agreed to extend the Article  deadline - but that would need to be unanimously agreed by all EU member states.Then there is the question of what to put on the ballot paper.If there are three questions - for example accept a negotiated Brexit deal stay in the EU or leave with no deal - then just  per cent could decide the winning option.The first referendum on EU membership took place in .Two-thirds of votersbacked the continued membership of the European Economic Community, which the UK had joined only two years before.Under Harold Wilsons leadership, the Labour Party was trying to present to the public a dferent version of EEC membership to get a better deal.The EEC was integrated into the European Union after it was created in .In June , Britain voted to leave the EU after .million people backed Leave compared to .million Remain voters.

title: brexit blue passports delay home office
story: The Home Office confirmed that the new blue passport design would be phased in “from late ”.But for months, Brits may be issued with either a blue or burgundy one – and will have no say on which design they get.“You will not be able to choose whether you get a burgundy or a blue passport during this time,” the Passport Office said.It insisted that all British passports should be blue from “early ”.But the decision is likely to cause uproar among Brexit and Remain-backing Brits. The iconic blue passport is inextricably linked with leaving the EU after Brexit-backers launched a campaign for its .Announcing the decision to bring them back two years ago, ex-Immigration Minister Brandon Lewis insisted every Brit would be able to request one from October .At the time he said: “I recognise that for many people who voted in that referendum, they want to see that things are dferent.”The Passport Office on Tuesday confirmed that British passports issued from March  would no longer include the words ‘European Union’ on the front cover. Both blue and burgundy designs would be equally valued for travel, it said.The Sun’s ‘True Blue’ campaign for theof the iconic blue book was launched after Brexit referendum result. It was ditched in  after a long-running battle with Brussels.The blue design was originally introduced in , and was described as “perfection itself” by the League of Nations, forerunner of the United Nations.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no deal brexit vote house of commons theresa may
story: The PM will tonight enrage many Tory MPs by backing a delay to our EU exit - rather than quitting without a deal on March .Even Mrs Mays allies admitted the move will massively split the party - complaining: Were totally f***ed.As the Commons prepared for another crucial Brexit vote:As many as  members of the Government told the PM she must offer a free vote on an amendment which would see Britain strike a transition agreement with the EU even in a No Deal scenario.Pro-Brexit ministers are furious that Remainers have had their own way in Cabinet over recent months.The clash is a sign of how powerless Mrs May is to hold her warring Government together even as the clock ticks on the Brexit process.After last nights crushing defeat for the PMs Brexit deal, Parliament will today vote on whether or not to approve a No Deal exit in  days time.Mrs May announced she would leave it up to inidual MPs to decide how they should vote.And she today confirmed she will oppose No Deal along with other Cabinet ministers such as Philip Hammond and David Gauke.During the  election campaign, Mrs May repeatedly insisted: No Deal is better than a bad deal.But she has also pointed out that evenMPs vote against No Deal tonight, it remains the legal default and could still happen in May or June.And she insists her deal is a good one which is better than a World Trade Organisation exit.Defending her strategy today, Mrs May said: I want to leave the EU with a good deal - I believe we have a good deal.If No Deal is defeated, the Commons will get a further vote tomorrow on whether to delay Brexit by around two months.One of the PMs closest allies told The Sun tonights vote will be hugely damaging for the Tory party by pitting Remainers and Brexiteers against each other.The insider said: The party is going to be fundamentally ided over this. Were totally f***ed.A group of Tory MPs from across the Brexit ide, including Jacob Rees-Mogg, Damian Green, Nicky Morgan and Steve Baker, have tabled an amendment to tonights vote on the so-called Malthouse compromise.Their motion calls for a post-Brexit transition period of up to three years even in a No Deal scenario, to give both sides the time to hammer out a future trade deal.Mrs May initially planned to order MPs to vote against the amendment, but changed her mind after a fiery Cabinet meeting where pro-Brexit ministers said she must leave it up to iniduals.Eventhe Malthouse plan were approved by the Commons, Brussels would be unlikely to agree a transition period without a comprehensive withdrawal agreement in place.Boris Johnson hit out at Mrs Mays decision to offer a free vote on No Deal - telling LBC: I do think that is absurd, this is a fundamental matter of Government policy.But David Cameron backed the PM, saying: Obviously, what needs to happen next is to rule out No Deal - that would be a disaster for our country - and to seek an extension, and Im sure that is what is going to happen next." data-credit"" data-sizes"auto" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   dk-comp-graphic-pagemay-v.jpg stripallw" src"data:image svg+xml,%Csvg xmlnshttp:www.w.org  svg viewBox  . %E%C svg%E" Even the Cabinet is likely to be split on the No Deal vote - with Brexiteers such as Andrea Leadsom voting in favour, while the likes of David Gauke oppose it.Chancellor Philip Hammond openly urged the PM to go for a softer Brexit deal which can win the support of other parties in an extraordinary blow to her authority.Delivering his Spring Statement this afternoon, he called for MP to remove the threat of an imminent No Deal exit hanging over our economy.Mr Hammond, an arch-Remainer, added: Tomorrow, we will have the opportunity to start to map out a way forward towards building a consensus across this house for a deal we can collectively support to exit the EU in an orderly way.In a further sign of Cabinet splits, his no at the Treasury Liz Truss said she would vote against ruling out No Deal, telling the BBC: No Deal would be better than not Brexiting.Speaking at Prime Ministers Questions, Mrs May hit out at Jeremy Corbyn for opposing her deal without saying what he wants to happen instead.She pointed out that the Labour boss has this week held back from supporting a second Brexit referendum - even though that is his partys official policy.The PM, who is battling a bad sore throat, blasted: I may not have my own voice, but I do understand the voice of the country.He doesnt agree with Government policy, he doesnt even agree with Labour party policy - he has nothing to offer this country.Mrs May is under increasing pressure from her own MPs to resign or even trigger a snap General Election.Nicky Morgan warned the Cabinet may have to confront Mrs May later this week and demand that she resign.Tory MP Daniel Kawczynski blasted today: Not only did she not campaign for Brexit, she didnt even campaign. Shes sitting on the fence and when you sit on the fence, you get splinters.I thinktheres an extension to Article  andthis intransigence goes on then of course there may be calls for a change in leadership.Aides admit the PM is closer than ever to throwing in the towel - but remains adamant she will press on with her current deal.Its still not clear whether the EU will actually grant Britain an extension to the Brexit process eventhe Commons votes to request one tomorrow.

title: how old theresa may prime minister paid brexit
story: With her position considerably weakened, bookmakers say the odds on May leaving her position as PM are shortening all the time. Heres what we know about the embattled Conservative Prime Minister.May, , was born in Eastbourne, Sussex on October , .She graduated from Oxford University with a geography degree in .May started her career at the Bank of England, and has worked as a financial consultant and senior adviser in International Affairs before she turned to politics.Her previous positions in Government include Home Secretary and Minister for Women and Equalities.Theresa May has been the MP for Maidenhead since , and became the first female chairman of the Conservative Party from -.Her husband Philip, who works in private equity, has been described as her secret weapon because he acts as her eyes and ear in the City.In , then Home Secretary May, revealed to the Daily Mail that she has Type  diabetes, a disease which carries risks of heart attacks and strokes.Speaking at the time, May said she carries a needle with her at all times and must inject herself with insulin at least twice a day.She said: It was a real shock and, yes, it took me a while  to come to terms with it.The diabetes doesn’t affect how I do the job or what I do. It’s just part of le... so it’s a case of head down and getting on with it.May was appointed PM on July , .Back then, the BBC said her toughness has become her political hallmark.She regularly attends St Andrews Church with her husband in Sonning, Berkshire.May supported the UK remaining in the EU during the referendum campaign but was not a prominent campaigner.Her entire premiership has been devoted to ensuring Britain has a smooth departure from the EU - but its been a rocky road.She has survived two direct threats to her leadership, one from within her Conservative Party, and one brought by opposition Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn, who tried but failed to force a general election.In November , the EUs  other countries gave their backing to her Brexit plan at a special summit in Brussels.It came after a number of cabinet resignations and calls for her to quit.The PM vowed to push with every fibre of my being hours after she pulled the trigger on a Brexiteer rebellion led by  Jacob Rees-Mogg which could spark a leadership challengeAfter the deal was approved by the EU, she made a direct appeal to the public in a letter to the nation.In her letter Mrs May said: “I will be fighting campaigning with my heart and soul to win that vote and deliver this Brexit deal for the good of the UK and all of our people.”But on December , , Mrs May cancelled the vote at the eleventh hour after realising she was sure of certain defeat.The chaotic Brexit negotiations led to her own D-Day two days later, when a critical number of MPs submitted votes of no confidence.On the night of December , an anonymous vote saw  Conservative MPs vote for her to stay, against  who voted for her to be ousted.Since then, MPs have rejected her Brexit deal for a second time - resulting in further instability at Westminster, and putting her political future in doubt.During a speech on Brexit in Grimbsy, on March , she said that months have been spent arguing about Brexit, when we could be focusing on improving our NHS, our schools and our communities.As Prime Minister, my job has been to negotiate the very best deal I could. Everyone now wants to get it done.She described the process as dragging on, but stressed that Brexit will not be a race to the bottom.May added that people voting to leave the European Union had voted for real change in our country.And it was a message to those in positions of power that for too many people working hard up and down the country, le was too hard. The Prime Minister is currently paid £,  a year, which includes the basic salary for an MP – currently set at £,.And being PM does have its perks - May gets a £, a year plush pad at No  Downing Street and free use of lavish Chequers throughout the year.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: 5 surprises spring statement 2019
story: News surprises in the Spring Statement  small print that got buried by BrexitThings have been busy with Brexit today, so you probably missed all this. And Philip Hammond would be terribly upsetyou missed outShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video highlights-philip-hammonds--spring-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChancellor Philip Hammond dangled the end of austerity before MPs today in his Spring Statement -they back a Brexit deal.The top Tory made his big financial announcement all about leaving the EU, and peppered it with some other changes that could help your le.But the actual details were pretty scant. Lots of the meat is in a separate report by the Office For Budget Responsibility- the governments official independent watchdog. It will shock you to learn that the watchdogs verdict is not quite so rosy as the Chancellors big impressive speech. More importantly it may have passed you by, since MPs are holding an era-defining series of votes on Brexit. So as a public service, weve rounded up  bits of small print from the OBR that are worth reading - and got thoroughly buried by Brexit. Delaying Universal Credit will mean less transition cash is paid out to struggling families, an official government document shows.The revelation comes after managed migration of million existing benefit claimants onto the new six-in-one system was pushed back, only starting in mid-. Tory ministers launched the -month delay to ensure people wouldnt see their incomes suddenly drop when they move over. But this delay has had a consequence for other families. It means thousands more people will move to UC while the new system is still being put together - and get no transition payments at all. Thats because any existing claimant with a change in circumstances moves to UC immediately, without being able to wait for the extra cash that will be in place under managed migration. Today, the Office for Budget Responsibility revealed the delay has saved the government poundmillion in UC costs over five years. The reason for that saving was not made clear in the OBRs report. Some of it may be due to more people remaining in the old system for longer, instead of racking up costs under UC. But the OBR also explicitly said transition cash has been reduced.  Last week, Tory welfare chief Amber Rudd announced more than , pensioners will no longer face regular reviews for their disability benefits. It was hailed by the Work and Pensions Secretary as a compassionate change for thousands of people, allowing them to keep their PIP benefits without fearing theyll be taken away. But todays OBR report shows there is another reason too. According to the report, the DWP faced long-term capacity constraints from carrying out the reviews at the same time as assessing new claims, and moving people to PIP from old benefits. So the department has prioritised moving old-style claimants onto PIP, rather than processing scheduled award reviews, the OBR said. . Business investment is at its worst level since the financial crash  The OBR report says business investment is expected to fall for the second year in a row in .This is its weakest performance since the financial crisis and is due to uncertainty related to the Brexit process, the OBR said. Labour MP Clive Lewis of the anti-Brexit Best For Britain campaign said: Thats not a Britain fit for the future. Its a limping, broken Britain.Once our short-term future is saved from a clf-edge, we must then put this issue back to the public and give them the final say on what happens. . House prices are set to go into reverse  House prices are set to fall briefly into reverse, the OBR said. The dip below zero inflation is expected to happen around the end of this year - before prices pick up again. The brief dip will be good news for buyers but bad news for anyone struggling to sell a house. Despite this, though, the OBR expects house prices to soar % between  and the start of  - close to growth in household income. . Were still sitting on a poundbillion loss from the RBS bailout  The taxpayer has currently lost out by poundbillion from the RBS bailout, OBR papers show. There were pound.billion in cash outlays to the formerly stricken bank, but there have only been pound.billion in principle repayments. Overall the Treasury is down pound.billion from its ious interventions during the financial crash.

story: NewsBBC hosts sassy side-eye during Brexit  perfectly captures mood of nationNewsnight host Emily Maitlis has been praised on social media for her exasperated reaction during an interview about BrexitShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video bbc-hosts-sassy-side-eye-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Last night The Prime Minister was humiliated and the country was thrown into a political crisis after MPs rejected her new Brexit deal. The House of Commons voted - against Theresa Mays plan - just  days after it suffered the biggest defeat in history.Understandably, people are feeling a range of emotions right now, with manly likely switching from confusion to frustration, and back again.And these feelings were perfectly encapsulated by a BBC host on television last night as she interviewed a  of MPs about what on earth is going to happen next for Britain. While grilling politician Barry Gardiner about Labours Brexit stance, Newsnight host Emily Maitlis dropped some seriously sassy side-eye.The -year-old asked the MP: If there is a general election called, which there is every likelihood could happen, what will be on your manesto  What Brexit vision will be on your manesto then  He replied: To negotiate the deal that we have set out. Maitlis couldnt stop herself from interrupting him, enquiring: Thats going to be on the leaflet   Gardiner continued: We will decide what our manesto position is as we normally do...At which point, Maitlis began shuffling her papers before glancing off to her right with a look of sheer exasperation on her face. She then began scrawling notes, which many viewers at home were desperate to have a glance at.   The MP added: It is a democratic party, as you know, it is not made up by one person on Newsnight as you know. Still seemingly unimpressed, Maitlis shot back: Well its not made up at all, people are literally pulling their hair out tonight. Following the heated exchange, the host was praised on social media for capturing the mood of the nation. One person tweeted: Emily Maitlis speaks for the nation.   Another commented: Emily Maitlis reaction here is PERFECT. A third added: Maitlis side-eye has knocked the planet off orbit. What a mood, wrote a fourth. However not everyone was impressed with the hosts behaviour, with some branding it unprofessional.  Speaking to Buzzfeed News, Maitlis joked that she hadnt been writing during the show but instead was crossing out all future dates and holiday plans.She later admitted that she had been making notes of what the guests were saying. She explained: When Im trying to process thoughts I write down what theyve just said so I can actually take it in and seeit makes sense to me.

story: NewsBrexit: Donald Tusk shares -year-olds stinging Brexit slapdown letterThe European Council President posted a picture of the letter - complete with unicorn drawingShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  MAR News "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Donald Tusk has shared a letter from a -year-old fan featuring a stinging Brexit slapdown and a drawing of a unicorn. The European Council President posted a picture of the letter on his Instagram account this morning.The letter, from Sophie, reads: Dear Mr Tusk. “I live in Britain. I know we are leaving the EU, but I think we should be friends.” She then asks: “Please may I have a signed photo of you for my Europe book ” Sophie adds: “I have drawn you a unicorn.”   Open Europes Henry Newman said: This is embarrassing. What is the president of European Council doing  It is a very serious negotiation and he is playing on Instagram” Following last nights Brexit vote, Mr Tusk said: We regret the outcome of tonights vote and are disappointed that the UK Government has been unable to ensure a majority for the Withdrawal Agreement agreed by both parties in November. On the EU side we have done all that is possible to reach an agreement. Given the additional assurances provided by the EU in December, January and yesterday, it is dficult to see what more we can do. If there is a solution to the current impasse, it can only be found in London.   He added: The EU, for its part, continues to stand by the Withdrawal Agreement, including the backstop, which serves to prevent a hard border in Ireland and preserve the integrity of the single market unless and until alternative arrangements can be found. With only  days left to March , todays vote has signicantly increased the likelihood of a no-deal Brexit. We will continue our no-deal preparations and ensure that we will be readysuch a scenario arises. Should there be a UK reasoned request for an extension, the EU will consider it and decide by unanimity. The EU will expect a credible justication for a possible extension and its duration. The smooth ing of the EU institutions will need to be ensured.

title: brexit mess whose stupid fault
story: NewsopinionWhose fault is this Brexit chaos  people you can blame for this mess, for which theres only one solutionShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsopinion"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen Theresa May awakes from whatever restless minutes of sleep she can grab, she must feel that Brexit is making every day hellishly and inexplicably the same.But before she decides to hunt down and throttle Punxsatawney Phil in a bid to bring her suffering to an end, it might be an idea to check just who is responsible for the neverending torture of GroundMogg Day. Because, oh my, there are a LOT of contenders for this particular crown of sh*t-dripping thorns.. David Cameron Its easy to blame Dishface, because hiding his well-covered form in his shepherds hut and having to keep a safe distance from piglets makes him an easy target.But for those who have forgotten, it is this well-polished human turd who promised, during the referendum campaign, that he would trigger Article  of the Lisbon Treaty immediatelythe vote was to Leave.The Leave campaign, on the other hand, promised it would not. But having curled it out on the national stage, Dishface made Article  a political necessity.So certain was he that Remain would win he refused to allow the civil service to prepare for Article , an act later described as an act of gross negligence for which we have been paying ever since. . Theresa May  This poor cow gets the blame for everything, despite arguably having managed the best anyone could with the be-spaffed sows ear she was gted by her predecessor. But having taken over from him a month after the referendum, she did a bunch of stupid things.She said Leave means Leave, when leaving cleanly was never possible without amputating Northern Ireland and watching it explode. Even before she lost her slim majority, she bent her knee to the extremist headbangers demanding a definitive act to cement the referendum result which was, even then, looking shakier than an alcoholic Elvis impersonator. She wrote to the EU triggering Article , setting a two-year deadline for a task that was impossible, unwinnable, and unsellable. And the courts promptly told her that was illegal because she was not a medieval monarch who ruled by ine right, and it must be approved by Parliament.. The House of Commons  Having been instructed to exert its sovereignty, the House of Commons took back control by agreeing with the PM. The entire Tory party, the DUP and % of Labour voted to trigger Article . The supporters included red and blue front benches, and the big names who have complained since about the clock which they wound up - Corbyn, Watson, Thornberry, Hammond, Johnson, Mogg.Last night, pretty much the same people voted against the best deal that could be come up with in the two-year limit they had set - like turkeys voting against veganism on Christmas Eve. Tonight, you can bet your bottom dollar the same MPs will ide into those prepared to go against the will of the people and exit WITHOUT a deal, and those who want to hit snooze on the alarm they once thought so important.. Idiots  Lets also blame - after all, why should anyone be immune  - people who voted for something they didnt understand and didnt research. Lets blame people who said worl, Norvern Ireland is fine now, innit  Lets blame the north east, the Welsh, Cornwall, car factory workers, racists, Islamophobes and everyone  who put a X in a box without realising the decision would bite them on the arse like a great white whos been on a diet since Amity Island. Except, well, every vote is like that. We dont all read all the leaflets, we dont all vote asking ourselves how this would affect Belfast or Bognor or Billericay.But this was not a normal vote. It was not legally-binding, it sold no policies, and none of us would ever vote for the importation of blood products, distemper vaccines or fissile material to be given to the sort of firm blamed for the Great KFC Chicken Shortage.. Russian trolls  Previous votes did not involve fake news, Facebook malgorithms, St Petersburg troll factories and data theft enabling direct social media advertising of absolute bollocks.Facebook was only born in  the Electoral Commission had yet to get around to outlawing some of this stuff, or requiring candidates to declare it. This enabled a free-for-all that tossed facts out of the window and capitalised on what was already an instinctive, emotional, impulse vote. They told you to vote for what you FEEL, and made you feel under attack.Oh, and on top of that, it also saw the grossest breach of campaign finance rules in British history. The only reason no-one was jailed for it and a re-vote ordered was because the referendum wasnt legally-binding. It is noticeable that, having done their utmost to make Brexit as unlikely, chaotic and damaging as possible, the Brexit campaigners are doing the most blaming. We will be waiting a while for Moneybags Mogg and What Japes Johnson to admit any responsibility for the shambles they did a lot to orchestrate.This was a vote undertaken in circumstances of insanity. The Tory party lost its purpose in a row about the French, Labour lost is way in a row about Communism, and Parliament had its teeth knocked out by Tony Blair, were handed a set of dentures by the Supreme Court, and has since devoted itself to gnawing its own feet off. Voters lost their minds arguing with each other, the internet warped like the Starship Enterprise on an LSD bender, and the pro-Brexit pot-wallopers were obnoxious, obstreperous, and obstructive.Theresa May, bless her socks, has done all she can to destroy her own premiership and thereby est herself of the filled nappy that Brexit has hung around her neck. It seems to be throttling her at present, after which we can only hope it move on to more deserving victims. Were on course for another vote, which should really thrill all those who crow about the will of the people although strangely they seem quite angry about it. Whether its a referendum or a general election, we can only hope that this time our politicians locate both butt checks, remove their craniums from within them, and find the brainpower necessary to write the legislation needed to require a minimum turnout and minimum majority. Had they done that  years ago, we wouldnt be in this purgatorial cesspit, in which chaos and indecision empty their bowels on us while two pensioners bitch about whod be best at making things worse.The politicians think the people got us into this mess, and the people blame the politicians. GroundMogg Day will only come to an end when we stop shouting and start talking about how to kill it.

Philip Hammond proved yet again today that he can barely hold a tune let alone recognise a popular hit. This Spring Statement was an exercise in trying to play catch up. There was additional money for the police to tackle kne crime - a rebuke to Theresa May who has claimed there is no direct link between police funding and levels of crime. The Chancellor also promised some additional funding for housebuilding, though much of this was a re-packaging of previous announcements. And there was a string of consultations on the environment presented as an example of how the Government understood the concerns of younger voters. There was no great over-arching strategy.  Instead we got the equivalent of a SWOTtest by a middle manager fearful that he may see his company car downgradedhe fails to meet his sales targets. He identied the areas voters are worried about and then did the bare minimum to buy off their concerns. The poundmilion for the police across England is a tenth of the amount cut from the politan Police alone. As John McDonnell pointed out in his response, the pledge to build more environmentally-friendly homes comes nine years after the Tories scrapped Labour’s Green Homes guarantee. The Chancellor used much of his statement to trumpet his government’s economic achievements. He talked of the record number in work, rising wages and a five years of economic growth.

But today was the second-most important financial event of the year - the Spring Statement. Youre forgivenyou didnt know. The major update, second only to the Budget, was sandwiched between debates on Brexit that will change Britains future. And Chancellor Philip Hammond weaponised Brexit, dangling billions of funding before MPs - but threatening to swipe it all awayMPs dont agree a deal. Aside from our leaving the EU it was a bit of a damp squib. Yet despite all this, there were some announcements to take note of - and you should. Because theyll affect your le just as they wouldwe werent leaving the EU. Heres our guide to the Spring Statement at a glance.  The Chancellor announced he intends to launch a full three year spending review before the summer recess - to be concluded alongside an Autumn Budget, probably in November. It will cover areas including social care, local government, schools, police, defence, and the environment - and could finally boost spending in those areas. That is what I mean to an end to austerity - delivered by an Conservative government, he said. But it could all be scuppered by Brexit  Mr Hammond used the review as a threat - saying it depends on leaving the EU with a deal. “Last night’s vote leaves a cloud of uncertainty hanging over our economy and our most urgent task in this house is to overcome that uncertainty, he said. The progress we have made will be at riskwe cannot secure a smooth and orderly exit from the EU.  Mr Hammond warned of signicant disruption in the short term and a smaller less prosperous economy in the long termwe dont get a Brexit deal. The Chancellor warned no deal will mean higher unemployment, lower wages and higher prices in the shops. Mr Hammond told MPs: I need to be straight with the house A no-deal Brexit would deliver a signicant short- to medium-term reduction in the productive capacity of the British economy. And because our economy is operating at near full capacity, any fiscal and monetary response would have to be carefully calibrated not to simply cause inflation. An insulting poundmillion for kne crime  The Tory government has unveiled a poundmillion emergency fund for police across the country to tackle kne crime. Chancellor Philip Hammond said the funding will be made available immediately and ring-fenced for overtime and schemes such as violent crime reduction units. poundmillion is new Treasury cash and the remaining poundmillion must be found by the Home Office from existing budgets. He caved in after weeks of calls for the Tories to plunge more cash into fighting the surge in kne crime. But the fund was slammed as not good enough after years of Tory cuts that have shed , officers. Labours shadow policing minister Louise Haigh said: Our overstretched officers are already at breaking point, owed thousands of rest days and leave. It wont paper over the deep cracks in the system. Lib Dem Ed Davey tweeted: Its an insult to hard-working police  kne crime victims  their families.  Free sanitary products will be available in schools in England from this September, the government confirmed today. Chancellor Philip Hammond made the announcement in his Spring Statement in a victory for period poverty activists. Campaigners say some girls spend days offschoolbecause they are menstruating, too worried to go to lessons without a tampon or sanitary towel. He said he would fund the provision of free sanitary products in secondary schools and colleges in England from the next school year.  Chancellor Philip Hammond has today pledged to deliver , more affordable homes to tackle the UKs housing crisis. Delivering his speech the day after Theresa Mays second Brexit deal defeat, he announced plans to for a poundbillion homes guarantee scheme to support and deliver around , affordable homes. It was later claried the money is a loan guuarantee - not hard up-front cash. In the Autumn Budget , the Government set out a series of policies to raise housing supply by the end of this Parliament - bringing it to its highest level since , on track to reach , a year on average. Today he said he will unlock pound million from the Housing Infrastructure Fund - the  grant introduced to invest in new build homes - to unlock up to , more affordable homes at sites including Old Oak Common in London, the Oxford-Cambridge Arc and Cheshire. But Polly Neate, chief executive of Shelter said: “While this is good news, it has to be noted that we can’t deliver social housing on the scale we need on borrowing alone.  Starting from June, paper landing cards will also begin to be abolished at airports for people visiting from overseas. This will reduce bureaucracy for travellers and speed up the processing of passengers on arrival in the UK, the Treasury said. But while thats good news for all concerned, another change will only slow things down for Brits ing from abroad. From June , citizens of the US, Canada, New Zealand, Australia, Japan, Singapore and South Korea will be permitted to use e-gates at UK airports and at Eurostar terminals, the Treasury said. This will signicantly reduce queues and improve the flow of passengers and the overall experience at the UK border.  Other announcementspound million for Borderlands Growth deal in England Scotland and negotiations progressing on future deals for mid-Wales and Derry Londonderry A consultation on supporting private infrastructure investment after we leave European investment bank. Halving apprenticeship levy on firms from % to %, described as a poundm package of reforms already announced at the budget, is being brought forward to this April , square kilometres of ocean around Ascension Island will be declared a Marine Protected Area. Airlines could be forced to offer genuinely additional carbon offset schemes, with a call for evidence launched. A new review of the minimum wage will be launched to seeit is enough to live on. Fossil fuel heating is set to be banned in new-build homes from  under a FutureHomes Standard. A study of the digital advertising market by the Competition and Markets Authority after a report by Professor Jason Furman, Barack Obamas former Chief Economist, sets out recommendations to overhaul competition regulation today. PhD-level roles will be exempt from the visa cap for immigrants. pound million for the ARCHER supercomputer at Edinburgh University. Mr Hammond joked: With the right algorithms it might even be able to come up with a solution to the backstop. pound million for genomics research at the European Bioinformatics Institute pound million for a new Extreme Photonics Centre in Oxfordshire, along with a guarantee of UK funding for the JET nuclear fusion reactor, whatever happens with Brexit poundmillion to be spent in  cities from a fund already announced at the  Budget. poundmillion for nine areas that have bid since budget for full fibre networksThis list is being updated. Finally, the numbers  Borrowing: pound.bn   - DOWN since Autumn  prediction pound.bn   - DOWN pound.bn   - DOWN pound.bn   - DOWN pound.bn   - DOWN Debt: .%   %   .%   %   %   - DOWN since Autumn  prediction The Government remains on track to meet both its fiscal targets early, with the cyclically adjusted deficit at .% next year and falling to .% by  , the Chancellor said. Headroom against the fiscal mandate increases from pound. billion at the time of the autumnBudgetto pound. billion today, he said. And how Labour reacted with fury  A Labour government would chill the very marrow of our economy, Hammond said, quoting ex-Labour MP Angela Smith as he slammed the empty promises and dangerous rhetoric of Labour. He mocked parallel universe Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell. But Mr McDonnell branded his Tory the tainted Chancellor and slammed him for failing to end the cruel benefits freeze, which is continuing to the end of March  at least. He added: We have just witnessed a display by the Chancellor of this Governments toxic mix of callous complacency over austerity and ... mishandling of Brexit.

Weve looked at  ways it would affect your everyday leShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video here-how-no-deal-brexit-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe UK is due to leave the European Union on  March  - andtheres no agreement, itll be a No Deal Brexit. A Brexit deal was agreed between the UK and the EU in November , but it was voted down twice in the House of Commons - first in January by  votes, then on March th by  votes. MPs are voting on Wednesday  March on whether to avoid a No Deal Brexit - and theyre widely expected to block it. But even so, no deal remains the default option and plans have long since been put into action, costing more than poundbillion, in case it happens. The government published  technical notices outlining the practical effects of No Deal - from driving licences to cats. And it unveiled new tarfs that would slap pound, on the cost of a family car from the EU - but leave % of goods imports, including steel, tarf free. This could threaten struggling UK industries with a flood of cheap imports.  Meanwhile ministers have , troops held at readiness, could call up Army reserves and declare martial law. Supermarkets and pharma giants are stockpiling food and medicine. If theres no arrangement in time, well lose  international trade deals in a blink, shed access to EU criminal databases and troops couldto the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic. A lot of the effects are on business. UK farmers face a nine-month wait for approval to export organic goods to the EU. Fishermen could be blocked from EU waters. And manufacturers fear their supply chains drying up. But businesses are not what whove written this guide for. Instead we have tried to establish  ways No Deal Brexit will affect you, the reader and your everyday le. What is a No Deal Brexit  No Deal is the default optionMPs, the EU and the UK government cant agree a Brexit Withdrawal Agreement by  March . The -page deal on the table would have ensured businesses arent cut off by continuing rules in a transition period until December . But it came at a cost - a backstop that could trap the UK in an EU customs union from . That means MPs have opposed it. Leaving with no deal will mean falling back on World Trade Organisation trade tarfs - increasing the price of imports and exports - and could leave legal black holes where EU law stood before. The UK government has been ramping up preparations for no deal since the beginning of summer . MPs believe they will block No Deal through Parliament - in a vote on Wednesday  March - butthey dont its still the default option at pm on March .  ways No Deal Brexit will hit you NOTE,  March : These scenarios are accurate as of early , when this piece was last updated. Some have since been partially resolved - for example, there is an agreement to ensure flights will continue. . Martial law could be imposed with thousands of troops on standby  More than , troops are being held at readiness in case there is a disastrous no-deal Brexit. Army reserves are also legally able to be called upthere is civil unrest, while councils are braced for possible runs on banks, fuel and food. Local Resilience Forums are reporting back to Whitehall and expect several months of disruptionthere is no deal. The government has plans in case it needs to impose martial law - military law - and curfews to restore order. Cabinet minister Matt Hancock admitted the plans existed but insisted the government was not specically looking at martial law and it was not the focus of our attention. . You need to renew your passport early  At the moment, British citizens can enter Schengen area countries with a valid passport eventhey only have a day left before they expire. But in a no deal Brexit, after  March  you may not be able to travel to these countriesyou have less than six months left on your passport. The government is advising travellers to renew any passports older than nine years and six months. . Usually this means renewing six months before your passport expires. Butyour passport had more than  years validity, youll have to renew earlier, because the extra months on top of  years dont count. The following are members of the Schengen Agreement: Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland. . Pet owners must visit the vet FOUR MONTHS before a holiday  There is a huge surge in red tape for pet owners who want to take their beloved animals abroad. Currently dogs , cats and ferrets can travel anywhere in the EU as long as they have a pet passport. The main requirement is that three weeks before the first visit, owners must go to the vet to have their pet vaccinated against rabies and microchipped. But in the worst case no-deal Brexit, pet owners must visit a vet at least four months before taking their pet the EU. And because talks are ongoing, that means youd better book in now. The animal must have a rabies vaccination followed by a blood test at least  days later, to prove the vaccination worked. Pet owners must then wait at least three months before visiting the vet to obtain a health certicate. But this cannot be done more than  days before the date the holiday starts. . KFC and other big names could run out of food  Food is being stockpiled forwe crash out of the EU without a deal, and ministers have promised an adequate supply. But thats not the same as having the range of food we do now. Leaked plans in December warned Brits could have to y their diet. And in January, big names KFC, Pret, Lidl, Co-Op, MS, Waitrose, Sainsburys, Asda and McDonalds signed a damning letter warning food supplies could run short because of disruptions to the supply chain. They wrote in a joint letter to MPs: Our ability to mitigate these risks is limited. As prudent businesses we are stockpiling where possible, but all frozen and chilled storage is already being used and there is very little general warehousing space available in the UK. They added: Retailers typically store no more than two weeks inventory and it becomes dficult to restock storesthe supply chain is disrupted. . You could lose your job  A string of firms have either moved jobs out of the UK or are threatening to do so in a no-deal situation. Airbus, which employs , people in the UK with around , more jobs in supply chains, warned it may move where. Car plants are moving forward standard shutdowns to be around Brexit in case there are supply chain issues. And critics fear new investment will not come the UKs way, hitting jobs in generations. Your motorway commute faces becoming a lorry park  Major motorways in the South of England are set for serious disruption in case of a no-deal Brexit. From early  the Mwill be closed as needed from junctions -, with a contraflow of both directions on the opposite side, so it can be used as a lorry parkthere is gridlock at Dover. A backup lorry park will be in place at Manston Airport. The M in Kent is also expected to be used as a holding area for lorries. And a similar fate could befall a -mile stretch of the M towards Southampton. . Millions of plane tickets could be cancelled  The International Air Transport Associationwarn up to million plane tickets could be cancelledthere is no deal. Currently it is not known exactly which tickets could be hit, or how passengers would find outthey are at risk. The situation arose because in a no deal, there will be no automatic legal basis for flights between the EU and UK after pm on  March . Under a pact struck between the UK and EU in December, basic connectivity will be maintained for a -month periodtheres No Deal. But according to the IATA - which represents  airlines including British Airways - that only means maintaining the number of flights in . It does not allow an increase in services - yet tickets have already been sold based on a predicted increase. Talks are ongoing, but Amyas Morse, head of the National Audit Office, previously warned flights could be groundedgoodwill fails. . Youll find it harder to drive in the EU  Currently a UK driving licence is the only thing visitors need to get behind the wheel on the continent. But under a no-deal Brexit, you should get an International Driving Permit. The pound. documents were due to be sold at , post offices from February. Before they were sold at fewer than . The number of permits issued would have to soar from , a year to million. Meanwhile you will also be forced to apply for a green card to prove you have the right car insurance. The certicates are free of charge and available from insurance companies. But the government warns firms may increase administration fees in order to cope with the extra bureaucracy. Those who forget their green cards would be forced to buy expensive frontier insurance in the country they are visiting. . Up to a million Brits may be forced to take a new driving test  British people driving in Europe could be forced to take a new driving testtheres a no deal Brexit. Up to a million Brits living in Europe were told to replace their driving licence with a local permit immediately. Guidance issued by the Department for Transport said: If you are aUKlicence holder living in theEUorEEAyou should exchange your UK driving licence for a local EU driving licence before  March . From that date, in the event that there is noEUExit deal, you may have to pass a driving test in theEU country you live in to be able to carry on driving there. . If youre an EU citizen, youll have fewer rights to stay in the UK  More than million EU citizens living in the UK will have less concrete rights to stay. Whether theres a Brexit deal or not, EU citizens can stay in Britainthey register for settled status with the government. But the rules are stricter in a No Deal Brexit. In No Deal, only EU citizens arriving before  March can apply, not those arriving by December . The deadline to apply will be  December , instead of  June there is a Brexit deal. And family members will only be able to join settled EU citizens in the UK before  March . As for the other way round - major EU nations have inidually said theyll allow UK ex-pats to stay, but this could y by country. . Pharmacies and hospitals could start rationing medicine  Pharmacists have requested special powers to ration medicinesthere is no Brexit deal Under plans by the Healthcare Distribution Association, they would have special powers to y doctors prescriptions and offer something a drug is unavailable.  million packs of medicines are imported to the UK from the EU every month, and the NHS is preparing for a doomsday scenario to prevent supplies running dry. Government and NHS chiefs have set up a war room called the Operational Response Centre and industry firms are creating six-week stockpiles of medicine. Health Secretary Matt Hancock has chartered a plane to fly in short-shelf-le products, like isotopes for cancer treatment, from Maastricht. Insulin could also be stockpiled. Mr Hancock claimed hes become the biggest buyer of fridges in the world, after fitting out facilities for storage of the crucial drugs. NHS staff are being directed to urge patients not to stockpile medicines personally to avoid shortages throughout the system. . Your mobile phone roaming charges may be hiked  Mobile roaming charges face an immediate hikethere is a No Deal Brexit, the government has confirmed. Tory ministers are revoking the EU law which guarantees UK citizens pay the same for using their phone on the Continent as they do at home. That will leave mobile phone firms free to hike costs whenever they like after the UK leaves. Guaranteed free roaming launched across the EU just  months ago - and meant big savings. But that guarantee will be scrappedthere is no deal, thanks to an obscure law laid before Parliament. . You should get insurance and flexible tickets for Eurostar disruption  Eurostar services could be suspended in a worst-case no deal Brexit. The government has told international train passengers - including the Eurostar - to make sure they have insurance and ticket terms and conditions that are sufficient to cover possible disruption. That implies passengers should buy FLEXIBLE tickets - not the fixed cheap ones that are popular for their low cost. The UK will need bilateral deals with France, Belgium and the Netherlands to ensure international trains keep running. Without such a deal, Britain has proposed recognising EU operator licences until March  to ensure services can continue. But this isnt guaranteed, and UK operators would have to reapply with the EU. The EU has agreed to keep permissions for services like the Channel Tunnel open for three monthsthere is No Deal, while a new agreement is negotiated. But there arent guarantees. Former Transport Secretary Andrew Adonis claimed the vital train link between Britain and Europe could be severed. . You might have to go through airport security twice  Air passengers changing flights in the EU may have to undergo two security screenings under a no-deal exit. Travellers boarding a plane in the UK to fly to a European airport, before changing flights for an onward destination, would be screened in Britain as they are now. But they might have to have a second check in the EU before getting their connecting flight. “Currently passengers flying from the UK and transferring at an EU airport for an onward flight do not have to be re-screened at that EU airport, because the UK applies, and exceeds, the EU baseline aviation security measures,” says a Department for Transport briefing note. “If there is no deal, and the EU decides not to recognise the UK aviation security system, then passengers and their luggage will have to be re-screened when changing flights in EU hub airports.” . You could be barred from using Netflix and Spoty on holiday  Britons could be barred from accessing their accounts for Netflix, Spoty and other online entertainment while travelling to EU statestheres a no-deal Brexit. Under the EU-wide portability regulation, which took force in April, citizens can access accounts set up and based in one country while visiting other member states. But a government technical notice said: The portability regulation will cease to apply to UK nationals when they travel to the EU. This means online content service providers will not be required or able to offer cross-border access to UK consumers under the EU Regulation. UK consumers may see restrictions to their online content services when they temporarily visit the EU. . If you live in Northern Ireland, you face electricity blackouts  Northern Ireland will be forced to take drastic measures to stop the lights going out. A worst-case No Deal Brexit would scupper the all-island electricity market shared by Northern Ireland and the Republic - leaving it without any legal basis. This would make both markets less efficient, with potential effects for producers and consumers on both sides of the border, the government warns. And it may be necessary to seek additional [legal] powers to preserve security of supply. To stop the lights going out, Northern Ireland would have to take more electricity from British power stations through an interconnector running under the Irish Sea. But Northern Irelands Transmission System Operator may need to rely on fall-back arrangements to ensure power keeps flowing, the government warns. That is why, eventheres a no deal, the government will take all possible measures to keep the all-island market running. There has been talk of barges in the Irish Sea. Dustin Benton of Green Alliance warned:Any emergency action to keep the lights on, both in Northern Ireland and across the rest of the UK, would likely be highly polluting and expensive. . You could be stranded on your package holiday  Package holidaymakers could be left with no legal protectionthe firm they booked with goes bust. Currently Brits have insolvency protectionthey book with a package holiday provider thats based anywhere in the EU. But in a No Deal Brexit, that protection would only applythe firms are targeting the UK market. That means those booking with, say, a cheaper Spanish firm online that has no UK presence could be unprotected. Eventhe UK government could act, in practice it will be much harder to take enforcement action against foreign firms because other countries will no longer recognise UK courts. . Youll lose rights to take action over dangerous products  Government documents reveal the same problem - UK courts not being recognised - will strip Brits of their consumer rights for EU goods bought online. Alex Neill of consumer group Which  warned: A no-deal Brexit would massively weaken peoples rights to take action when they purchase faulty or dangerous products from outside the UK. The Governments advice that we all become experts in international consumer law is hopelessly unrealistic. Securing a good deal with the EU is vital to ensure that Brexit doesnt result in a bonfire of consumer rights and protections.” . Your cigarette packets will change  Graphic warnings on cigarette packets will be replaced by Australian versions in a no-deal Brexit. And in some ways they are even more gruesome than the ones we have now. The grim pictures show a foot ridden with peripheral vascular disease, a clogged artery, a bleeding brain and high-resolution teeth stained black. The photos will be changed in a No Deal Brexit because the European Commission owns theon ones we currently use. That means the UK would be unable to use them after  March . . If youre going through a family breakdown, you could be trapped in limbo  Families who are midway through orce or child custody cases involving another EU country could find themselves trapped in limbo. If there’s a no deal Brexit, the UK will cease to be part of co-operation between EU family courts on  March . Instead the UK will fall back on legal conventions drawn up in The Hague. But these are complicated and do not cover every area of the law. The government has advised families with ongoing cases to seek legal advicethey will not finish by Brexit Day. A government technical note says: Broadly speaking, cases ongoing on exit day will continue to proceed under the current rules. However, we cannot guarantee that EU courts will follow the same principle, nor that EU courts will accept or recognise any judgments stemming from these cases.” . Your everyday medicines and perfumes could become more expensive  Currently, popular ingredients in cold medicines can usually be traded within the EU without a licence. In a no deal, a licence will be required to trade these so-called precursors. Sowe leave without a deal, firms who want to trade such chemicals with the EU will have to register with the Home Office, which can cost between pound and pound,. They will also need an import export license, which costs pound. Critics say this could push up prices for consumers in the shops. Similarly, cosmetics firms will be slapped with more red tape to prove their products are safe for human health. Currently they can use one legal “nominated person” to certy a product for the whole EU market. Butthere’s a no deal Brexit, UK checks won’t be recognised in the EU - and EU checks wont be recognised in the UK. That means two sets of checks. Labour MP Owen Smith claimed drug giants will look to pass on the costs. And finally... your regular caviar parties are doomed!

story: NewsBlack mould in your home can cause terrying hallucinations of demons and ghostsA third of Brits believe in ghosts but the solution could be more cleaning basedShareByJane Lavender:,  MAR NewsCould mould be causing terrying hallucinations  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBlack mould in your home could be triggering terrying hallucinations of ghosts and demons, experts have warned. One in three people in Britain believes that a house can be haunted and  per cent think they’ve experienced a ‘supernatural presence’, according to a YouGov survey. But a growing number of scientists now believe toxic mould - which grows on the walls of damp homes in the UK - could be to blame. It comes as Emma Marshall blamed a string of health problems on the black mould in her flat. The -year-old, who noticed the black mould at her flat in Hackney, east London, suffers from exhaustion, memory loss and her hair has been falling out in clumps.   Emma, who works in the music industry, has also suffered from brain fog, chronic nerve pain and skin rashes. She thought nothing of the “thick black mould” in the bathroom of her flat when she moved in in . But, since moving out the following year, her health has steadily declined. She is now hoping revolutionary treatment will help her expert symptoms. But experts claim the terrying hallucinations can be banished by simply scrubbing the mould off.  Ralitsa Prodanova of leading domestic services firm Fantastic Services said: “For eye-witnesses who experience supernatural encounters, the events can be extremely traumatic. “And when the paranormal activity is centred on your own home it can prove even more frightening. “But it’s important to remember that there could well be a rational, domestic explanation for all manner of spirits, poltergeists and demons. “Several studies have suggested the toxic black mould that grows on damp walls could be a factor. “These living, organic moulds can send spores - clumps of microscopic seeds - into the air, spreading like a virus.  “One of the worst-offending types - Stachybotrys chartarum - is present in many homes in the UK, and the mycotoxins it produces can cause respiratory problems, inflammation of the skin, tiredness and nausea. “Meanwhile some types of fungus - particularly the rye ergot fungus - have a psychedelic effect when ingested, causing hallucinations and delusions. “These moulds could well be behind many ghost sightings. And it’s important homeowners are aware of the dangers.” The phenomenon was first examined in  by experts in Maryland, USA, who christened it ‘Sick Building Syndrome’, or ‘SBS’, and documented the effects in the journal ‘Neurotoxicology and Teratology’. Lead author Ritchie Shoemaker analysed the inhabitants of water damaged, and mould-ridden buildings, and found patients had compromised ‘neurological ’, as well as a host of other toxicity-related ailments.  And in , a team of scientists from Clarkson University, New York, studied the links between hauntings and toxic mould. Associate Professor of Civil  Environmental Engineering Shane Rogers sampled the air quality in buildings associated with alleged ghost activity. He said: Hauntings are very widely reported phenomena that are not well-researched. “They are often reported in older-built structures that may also suffer poor air quality. “Similarly, some people have reported depression, anxiety and other effects from exposure to biological pollutants in indoor air. “We are trying to determine whether some reported hauntings may be linked to specic pollutants found in indoor air.”  He also added: “‘Although allergy and asthma symptoms and other physiological effects are well established, there has long been controversy over the effects of indoor mould exposure on cognitive and other ing of the brain.” American physicist and paranormal sceptic Dr Harry Kloor is also convinced mould is to blame for many supernatural events. He said: “A common airborne fungus will actually grow on latex paint and produces these ergot alkaloids which cause people to hallucinate. This could explain the bizarre things that people are seeing.” The NHS warns that, ‘ you have damp and mould in your home, youre more likely to have respiratory problems, respiratory infections, allergies or asthma.Damp and mould can also affect the immune system.’Some are worse affected than others, too, with babies and children, the elderly and those with existing problems, such as eczema or asthma, particularly susceptible. But thankfully there are methods to combat toxic black mould. Fantastic Services professional Ralitsa says: “If you’re attempting to clean black mould yourself, always wear a protective mask, rubber gloves and safety glasses. “And the most effective method of combating mould is to pour bleach into a spraying bottle, before covering mouldy areas and letting the bleach get to work for  minutes. “Open all windows to allow any toxic fumes to escape. “Then wipe and rinse the area and leave it to dry, before disposing of the cloth used.Bear in mind that bleach is a strong chemical product, which makes it dangerous for people with allergies, sensitive skin, as well as kids.”
