story: NewsI go home and tell my kids how much I love them: Doctor reveals terrible toll of le in NHSDr Chris Pickerings work is featured in new hard-hitting Channel  hospital documentary Critical ConditionShareByMatt Roper:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror tv tv-news video graphic-new-channel--drama-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The doctor who is seen fighting to save lives in a new fly-on-the-wall hospital documentary has revealed how deeply he is personally affected by his daily encounters with death. Dr Chris Pickering leads the Major Trauma Centre at the Royal University Hospital in Stoke which is featured in the gripping four-part Channel  series, Critical Condition.The programme goes behind the scenes to show the work of Chris and his team, who are responsible for delivering the immediate le-saving care following a catastrophic event in a person’s le. Cases include a man who has been hacked to within an inch of his le by a machete-wielding attacker and a -year-old motorbike racer who is minutes from death after crashing at mph.The documentary shows Dr Pickering and other consultants calmly directing emergency staff as they resuscitate desperately ill patients, and making le and death decisions knowing that each second counts.  But despite his serene demeanour the father-of-two, who has  years AE experience, admits his work often leaves him feeling emotionally shattered - and has forced him to rethink his own priorities in le. He said: “I certainly go home after a particularly hard sht and make sure my children known how much I care about them. “We see everything, from families who need reconciling on someone’s death bed, to someone who’s arrived too late. It forces you to think about the relationships you have, and make sure that you make the effort with them, before it’s too late. “It makes you think about what’s more important in le.”   And he said that while emergency medics are known as “adrenalin junkies” away from work, living le to the full is a consequence of seeing so many people’s lives cut short before they can achieve their own dreams. He said: “I think a lot of us do find ways of enjoying le away from work. What you see does make you relish the things you have a lot more and make you want to make the most of your time.” Dr Pickering said that having to tell a patient’s family that their loved one didn’t make it is “one of the worst parts of the job” and something that always stays with him. He said: “In my career there are several times that stick in my mind when I’ve had to go in and tell a family the worst news. “And it’s particularly hard when you’re telling parents, it doesn’t matter how old the patient is. But inevitably at some point we have to tell a parent that they’ve lost their child. “As long as I know I can walk away knowing I’ve done the best for my patient, that’s what helps you cope with it, knowing you’ve done the best you can.”  The documentary, which was filmed in autumn last year, shows the moment a patient is told he is going to die and another who is told he has an incurable brain tumour. Cameras also captured the team’s desperate save the le of a -year-old man who was found in a pool of blood after being attacked by a machete, and the moment his desperate mother arrives in the hospital after getting a late night visit from police officers to deliver the news. Dr Pickering said: “Every day I or one of my colleagues in the department will have to have a conversation with a family that will be unpleasant. “We see a lot of people who have found themselves in the end stages of le. “Knowing that I’ve done my best for them, explored all options, done everything that could be done for the patient. That’s what makes it easier to cope with.” The doctor also told how he is worried about the effects of Brexit on his teams le-saving work.He said: I think I worry because I dont know what the effect is going to have. We are a group of clinicians who like to make plans and focus on what we have that is concrete, and its dficult for us to plan or react to what we dont know. But, like you see us doing in the show, its a challenge we will face in the same way when its there in front of us. Well have to react and adapt to whatever model we have when the time comes.Critical Condition is on Channel , tonight, at pm.

story: NewsPeople with rare skin condition challenge perceptions of beauty in incredible photosThe demonstration called How Do You C Me Now will be showcased at the Oxo Tower in LondonShareCommentsByYasmin Harisha:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsGemma Whyatt poses as part of the exhibition "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThese beautul pictures show men and women of dferent ages born with a rare and untreatable skin condition as part of a strikingexhibition. Theexhibition- which is being supported by UK CMN charity Caring Matters Now - has been presented throughout  dferent portrait images. story: NewsPrince Charles laughs as Danny Dyer tells him theyre related at awards bashPrince Charles, Prince of Wales, admitted it was "interesting" to learn of Danny Dyers long-lost royal relationShareCommentsByRussell MyersBradley Jolly:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video prince-charles-didnt-recognise-danny-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the moment Prince Charles chuckled after Eastenders star Danny Dyer told him Im related to you. story: NewsSchool refuses to give girls  days off while mum has le-saving heart surgeryEmma Payne, from Burnley, Lancashire, says she was stunned when the primary school denied her requestShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  MAR NewsEmma Payne, , has suffered with heart problems since birth "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum claims her daughters primary school would not allow them five days off while she undergoes and recovers from a le-saving heart operation.Emma Payne said she was left stunned and feeling let down when she found out her girls - Charlotte, , and Sophie, eight - had to remain in school or  she would be fined for taking them out. The -year-old wants her daughters to be at her bedside with her husband Mark while she is in hospital, as no-one will be home to care for them. The mum, from Burnley, Lancs, had asked St Augustine of Canterbury Primary School to allow both her daughters to have five days leave.   She had hoped they would only need between two and three daysthe upcoming operation at Newcastle Freeman Hospital goes well. If the operation is not a success, Mrs Payne, who runs Emmas Newsagents in Burnley, will need open heart surgery and that will keep her in hospital for five days. The surgery can only take place during term-time as it is the only time a specialist from London can lead the keyhole procedure. In a letter, the school explained it had only authorised two days absence and would not allow five days due to Charlottes standard attainment testsexams in May.   This leaves Mrs Payne facing fines and going to court, she said. She said: Im not requesting the time for a holiday or because Ive got a broken nail, Im having surgery to save my le. My husband, Mark, will take me up to the hospital for the operation on the Tuesday and will be with me, no one  can look after my children and they want to be close to me. I requested they have work brought up with them for them so they arent sitting around doing nothing, but the school have just said no to the five days. Im hoping they will be back in school by the Thursday, butthe operation doesnt work I will have to have open heart surgery, another risky procedure, and be up there for a few more days. The mother-of-two had two major heart operations in  and .  Her upcoming operation, a pulmonary valve replacement, has only been done  times at the hospital, Mrs Payne said. The six-hour procedure involves keyhole surgery through an incision in her leg. She said: Im frustrated with the school because theyre using the tests, which arent for another two months, against me and are more concerned about their Ofsted results. My previous appointments have all managed to be away from term time but this operation has to be when the surgeon can perform it. The children know that Im undergoing a tough operation and they want to be close to me. Sinead Colbeck, headteacher at St. Augustines RC Primary School, said: We cannot comment on inidual cases. Even though we work in line with government guidelines which make it clear that absence can only be authorised in exceptional circumstances, we speak with the families concerned each time to make sure that the reasons are totally understood so that every decision is appropriate. We give careful consideration to each request and review on an ongoing basis. County Cllr Susie Charles, cabinet member for children, young people and schools, said: It would be inappropriate to comment on inidual cases however schools have a very clear policy, based on government guidance, regarding the authorisation of leave. The decision to authorise absence or not rests with the headteacher of the particular school. Schools work closely with parents to understand the reasons for the request. Each request is always taken on its merits. School attendance is given high priority in Lancashire schools and rightly so, as every day counts in each pupils education. However our aim throughout is not to punish parents but to ensure that children and young people attend school and receive a good education.

title: so thats it aint it
story: NewsSo thats it, aint it: Heartbreaking moment dad told he has incurable brain tumourNew Channel  behind-the-scenes hospital documentary, Critical Condition, shows what like is really like on NHS frontlineShareByMatt Roper:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror tv tv-news video graphic-new-channel--drama-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email“There is only a very short list of things that this could be,” explains the consultant as he points to a white blob on a scan of Geoff’s brain. “And the highest likelihood is that it is a tumour.”His calmly-spoken words are met with stunned silence by Geoffs family gather in the quiet room at Royal University Hospital in Stoke.It is eventually broken by Geoff himself, who says quietly: “I’ve had a good le. So that’s it, ain’t it.”The heartbreaking moment was captured by the cameras of a new, no-holds-barred Channel  documentary, Critical Condition, which starts tonight. The four-part series goes behind the scenes to show the work of the hospital ’s Major Trauma Centre as they receive patients on the brink of losing their lives, and care for them during the ‘golden hour’ when every second counts.And some of the scenes are so disturbing the programme is shown after the pm watershed.   They include patients whose lives have suddenly been ripped apart by a road smash, a workplace accident, a massive heart attack or, as in Geoff’s case, sudden excruciating pain as a consequence of a deadly illness. Cameras continue filming as the team work to save their lives, reviving those whose hearts have stopped, pinpointing the cause of bleeding and pain, and performing delicate surgery like carefully removing a blood clot from one man’s brain.Within hours of being told the devastating news he had an aggressive and incurable tumour, surgeons opened up Geoff’s skull to remove the cancer, which had attached itself to his brain - a way to prolong his le and relieve his terrible headaches .Later, cameras film the moment neurosurgeons use an electric saw to cut through Geoff’s skull. “It’s a bit like carpentry, measure twice, cut once,” says the surgeon he removes the bathplug-sized piece of skull he has just cut. After finding the tumour which had caused Geoff’s brain to bulge - and his insupportable headaches - he says: “It’s naked eye dferent, pinkish, greyish, firmer than it should be. It’s definitely a tumour, there’s no doubt about it. “But it’s not good that it’s attached like this, it’s worrying.”   The images capturing such tragic and dramatic moments in people’s lives make for incredible -not dficult - viewing. But they are what NHS trauma teams across the country face every day, according to Dr Chris Pickering, Royal University Hospital’s emergency medicine specialist who features in the programme. The Royal Stoke is one of  specialist trauma centres in the UK, with patients frequently arriving by air ambulance from across the region following major accidents or for le-threatening conditions. Speaking exclusively to , Chris said: “When Geoff came into the resuscitation room we thought he may have suffered a stroke with potentially bleeding to the brain, then at the MRI scan we find this horrible tumour. “It’s a very dficult thing to approach with anyone, to tell them and their family they have something that’s going to get worse and eventually kill them. It feels like a sentence you are giving them. “But I or one of my colleagues will have an unpleasant conversation like that with a family every day.  “We see a lot of people at the end stages of le. In one of the episodes one of my colleagues has to tell a patient they are going to die. “It’s as much about being honest with them, and about the compassion and the way you deliver it. But then making sure you can deliver the care they need, and making sure they are comfortable. “But it’s one of the worst parts of the job. In my career there are several times that stick in my mind when I’ve had to go in and tell a family the worst news. And it’s particularly hard when you’re telling parents, it doesn’t matter how old the patient is. But inevitably at some point we have to tell a parent that they’ve lost their child. “As long as I know I can walk away knowing I’ve done the best for my patient, that’s what helps you cope with it, knowing you’ve done the best you can.”  The series, which starts tonight at pm on Channel , also shows the team’s desperate efforts to save the le of a -year-old man who was found in a pool of blood after being attacked by a machete. The man, called Dave, has a gaping wound in the right side of his head and the left side of his neck. And it also captures the moment a man who arrives complaining of what he believes is indigestion pains has a heart attack. The tense moments during which his heart stops completely, as staff wait for an internal defibrillator in his heart to jolt him back to le are all caught on camera. Filmed during Autumn , the documentary follows Chris and his team, who are responsible for delivering the immediate le-saving care following a catastrophic event in a person’s le. And as well as the serious kinds of injuries and conditions they are required to deal with, the programme highlights the relentless fast pace of the department’s daily workload during which they have to make split-second le and death decisions. Chris says that the on-screen portrayal of his department “is not an unfair reflection of what we do.” And he says he has witnessed the massive increase in workload on NHS staff in the  years since he first started out as a doctor.  He said: “My first ever AE job was a Northwick Park hospital in north London, which at the time was one of the busiest departments in the country, with around  patients a day on a busy day. Today they are close to seeing  a day. “At Royal University Hospital we see between  and  patients a day. “Our resuscitation room has eight beds and we are normally operating with six of those at any one time. We see a lot of very sick patients a day, and we receive an average of two to three traumas a day. “Tonight I will be on sht from pm and on the shop floor until midnight, butI leave before am I’ll be happy. I’ll be on trauma call all night, then back in a meeting room at am. I’ll be in the office all day then working Friday all day on the shop floor again. “I normally only see my we on a Monday evening.” But he says he gets a “buzz” from getting the call that a major trauma patient is on their way. He said: “A colleague once gave me a mug which reads: “Trauma junkie - It’s not that I want you to get hurt, I just want to be there when you do. “That’s very much the attitude we have. We don’t want to see anyone hurt, but you do get a buzz about making people better than they do. “These people we see are going through something horrendous, they have just had a moment of severe pain and distress.We’re really the second phase after the pre-hospital guys have done their work, we’re the ones who try to make sure they recover, or don’t have lasting effects. “It does give you a real buzz to know you are part of that.”Critical Condition is on Channel , tonight, at pm.

title: stonehenge hosted massive rave like
story: NewsStonehenge hosted massive rave-like events  years ago, pig remains suggestA landmark study has unearthed evidence which indicates that feasts in the Stonehenge area attracted people and their beasts from hundreds of miles awayShareCommentsByAdam Aspinall:,  MAR NewsRollo Maughfling, Archdruid of Stonehenge and Britain conducts as ceremony as druids, pagans and revellers gather in the centre of Stonehenge, "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAncient Britons travelled for hundreds of miles for rave-like mass gatherings around Stonehenge in an ancient forerunner of the Glastonbury Festival, a study suggests. State of the art analysis of pig remains reveals that feasts in the Stonehenge area and across the ancient kingdom of Wessex attracted people and their beasts from hundreds of miles away. The landmark study, which unearthed evidence of the earliest large-scale celebrations in Britain, reveals the monumental distances travelled for national mass gatherings. The study is the most comprehensive to date and examined the bones of  pigs, the prime feasting animals, from four Late Neolithic complexes, dating back around , years.   Serving the world-famous monuments of Stonehenge and Ave bury, the four sites - Durrington Walls, Marden, Mount Pleasant and West Kennet Palisade Enclosures - hosted the very first national events. The results show pig bones excavated from the sites were from animals raised as far away as Scotland, North East England and West Wales, as well as numerous other locations across the British Isles.   The researchers believe it may have been important for those attending to contribute animals raised locally at their homes. Lead researcher Dr Richard Madgwick, from the University of Cardf, said: This study demonstrates a scale of movement and level of social complexity not previously appreciated. These gatherings could be seen as the first united cultural events of our island, with people from all corners of Britain descending on the areas around Stonehenge to feast on food that had been specially reared and transported from their homes. Pigs were the prime source of meat for Neolithic feasting, said the scientists.   The team focused on the henge complexes of Durrington Walls, Marden, Mount Pleasant and West Kennet Palisade Enclosures. Dr Madgwick added: Arguably the most startling finding is the efforts that participants invested in contributing pigs that they themselves had raised. Procuring them in the vicinity of the feasting sites would have been relatively easy. Pigs are not nearly as well-suited to movement over distance as cattle and transporting them, either slaughtered or on the hoof, over hundreds or even tens of kilometres, would have required a monumental effort. This suggests that prescribed contributions were required and that rules dictated that offered pigs must be raised by the feasting participants, accompanying them on their journey, rather than being acquired locally. The research is reported in the journal Science Advances.

title: candyman travers beynon brands fans
story: NewsCandyman Travers Beynon BRANDS fans with real tattoos for entry to fantasy partyHis lavish bash has been described as "the hottest party on the planet" and includes performances from half naked womenShareCommentsByJane LavenderLiz Dunphy:,  MAR NewsTravers Beynon is offering people real tattoos to attend the basgh"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHes the playboy who handpicks VIP guests to attend the ultimate fantasy party at his orgy mansion. An agent first invited Taesha to one of Travers Candyman parties but she turned down the offer. When she was later recruited to work at a Candyman party, she refused two roles - as a rollerskater and a cloakroom attendant - but she eventually agreed to be a hostess. title: catherine shaw fundraiser set up
story: NewsCatherine Shaw: Fundraiser set up to bring backpackers body back from GuatemalaIt has already raised nearly £k to help the grieving family of Brit Catherine Shaw, who fell to her death in GuatemalaShareCommentsByTalia Shadwell:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsCatherine Shaw, from Witney, Oxfordshire, had been travelling since September last year "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA fundraiser has been set up to help the grieving family of British backpacker Catherine Shaw to bring her body back from Guatemala. The Bring Catherine Home page has been set up after the Oxfordshire -year-old plunged more than ft to her death in a mountainous region of the country. So far poundk has been raised towards a poundk goal to assist her parents in covering the costs of the search for Catherine, repatriating her body back to England, her funeral, and recovering her possessions. The fundraiser has been organised by the Lucie Blackman Trust, a charity which supports families of British people missing abroad, and has been helping her loved ones.  Catherine, from Witney, and described as a nature lover, was backpacking in the region and staying at an eco hotel. She had been reported missing from her hotel in the village of San Juan La Laguna. Tragically, after days of looking, a search party located her body after a stray puppy she had been carrying with her was found close by.  She was found in a cavern around ft from the peak of a hiking trail and two miles from her hostel on Monday. Investigators say she died from a traumatic brain injury and may have laid undiscovered for between four to six days. Guatemalan authorities are still working to determine how she came to fall to her death. Her family have criticised local media reports speculating foul play was suspected in Catherines death. They made a statement via the Lucie Blackman Trust, saying it was unlikely foul play was involved.  Earlier reports from Guatemalan media had suggested the backpacker had been raped and killed, because her body was found naked. Catherine had been travelling since September last year, heading to the central American country, and had been staying in the San Pedro, Lake Atitlan area with a friend. The Trust said Catherine appeared to have been fasting and had stripped off to take a walk and watch the sunset.  The statement issued by the Trust in response to the speculation said: “She was very much a nature lover and adored sunrises, so it seems quite conceivable that she went up the mountain to greet the sunrise, shedding clothing as she went, and due to her lack of intake of food and fluid may have passed out or fallen, causing the wounds to her body. The Trust says  per cent of the funds raised for Catherines family, including any funds in excess of what is needed for their cause, will go toward supporting other families in similar situations. Guatemalas Interior Ministry earlier said in a statement immediately after Catherines body was found: After several days of intense searching by police authorities, other institutions and volunteers for the missing British national, participating teams are being coordinated at the scene where her body has been found. After  hours of an exhaustive search, the result is very regrettable and the Interior Ministry and police chiefs have immediately designated a team which will carry out the criminal investigation. This is to determine what has happened and who could be involved in this deplorable incident.

title: woman hugs boyfriend begs him
story: NewsWoman hugs boyfriend and begs him not to die after stabbing him in stomachWARNING - DISTRESSING CONTENT: Erick Omar told witnesses in Mexico girlfriend Sonia Amayrani Nunez Aguilar wanted to kill him as she declared her loveShareCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video moment-woman-begs-boyfriend-not-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman was filmed begging her boyfriend not to die, as he lay bleeding in the street - after she reportedly stabbed him. A row broke out between the couple outside the Hotel La Cascada in Mexico, but it turned violent and Erick Omar ended up with a deep kne wound. In the video filmed by an eyewitness, Erick is seen kneeling on the ground while holding his stomach as his girlfriend Sonia Amayrani Nunez Aguila, hugs and kisses him. Sonia, , could be heard saying on the video: He hit me. He tried to kill me, before turning to Erick and demanding: Tell them the truth. At one point the desperate woman screams: Forgive me my love, please don’t die.Hiding in plain sight: The evil rapist and murderer who became a local celebrity  Asthe -year-old struggles to hold on, he counters her accusation and asks for help while telling the bystanders she wants to kill me. The distraught woman replies: I am not going to kill you because I love you. I’d never do that to you, but you have no idea what you did to me, OK. The man replied: God is really a witness. According to local media, a police patrol car arrived, but the officers refused to take the victim to the hospital because they did not have enough petrol.  An ambulance was called, arriving more than an hour later, before transferring the injured man to hospital. Reports said that Erick is out of danger following emergency surgery. His girlfriend has been arrested and placed at the disposal of the public prosecutor’s office. The motive for the attack is not yet known as police in the city of Iguala investigate the alleged stabbing.

title: dundee gaffer mcintyre wants dark blues to show a more ruthless side against celtic
story: Jim McIntyre wants to see more ruthlessness from his Dundee side but took solace from the fact they “defended far, far better” in the defeat to Hearts ahead of a daunting test against Celtic this Sunday.The - reverse against the Jambos at Dens Park on Saturday condemned the Dark Blues to their third loss on the spin after - and - defeats to Hibs and Rangers.Despite the nature of a very scrappy goal scored by Sean Clare after  minutes that ultimately gave Hearts the points, the Dens gaffer was encouraged by the way his side coped with a dficult frontline.Big striker Uche Ikpeazu was a real handful but chances were kept to a minimum by the Dundee defence.Jim said: “Hearts are a hard team to play against but I felt we defended far, far better than we have in the last couple of games.“We didn’t gt chances and our subs did well.“Those are the positives, we defended better and our subs gave us a good impact.”Where he’s desperate to see an improvement is in the final third as good opportunities came and went.Jim said: “We have to look at where we can be better and I feel in the first-half we were in great areas and we could have been a bit more ruthless.“Their keeper, when he’s been needed, he’s made a couple of big saves, especially from Kenny’s header – that was a great save, the save of the game.”He added: “I can’t be disappointed with the effort the guys have given me.“I can bemoan a wee bit of quality and ruthlessness here and there but in terms of what I’m seeing and working with every day they are giving me everything they’ve got.“A win is only round the cornerwe keep playing like that.”

title: dundee need to pick up points at home says jim mcintyre
story: Home matches against Hearts are where Dundee need to be picking up points, according to manager Jim McIntyre.The Dens boss felt his side were worth at least a point from Saturday’s - defeat to the Jambos but he concedes “it’s about making sure you are good in both boxes and we weren’t”.There were positives in the performance for the Dark Blues boss as his side created decent opportunities but conceded a poor th-minute winner from Sean Clare.Jim said: “It’s hard to be critical because it’s so scrappy.“It’s not asthey’ve cut us open.“Where I’m disappointed is that we don’t stop the cross but we have men in place and it is an old-fashioned stramash where the ball is stuck between bodies.“They got a toe-poke to it and it was a really frustrating goal, a scrappy, poor goal to give away.”Asked about the chances in the opening minutes of the game, Jim replied: “They are the opportunities you have to take.“Goals give you a real surge in belief but we are showing plenty of spirit because we are conceding the first goal a lot but we are coming back and still at it in the th minute.“At the same time, we are at home and we need to be picking up points against Hearts at Dens.“We had a brilliant result against them at Tynecastle but we want to be picking them up here and I felt there was enough in the performance to deserve at least a point.“It’s about making sure you are good in both boxes and we weren’t.”

title: dundee united striker pavol safranko in slovakia call up

title: dundonians reaction to brexit fiasco
story: The UK has been left in even more disarray after Theresa May’s Brexit deal was again rejected in parliament – and we took to the streets to find out what readers made of the latest development.MPs voted  to  against the deal in another humiliating night for the prime minister.It’s now back to the drawing board as MPs bid to work out the next solution to what has been a shambolic two and a half years since the vote on leaving the European Union.This morning the Tele spoke to people in Dundee as they made their way to work and asked what they expected from the next stage in the process.Angela Gillespie, , was a leave voter and admits she has been left completely dumbstruck by the way negotiations have been carried out by the UK Government so far.Angela, from Whitfield, said: “It’s so confusing at this point. I voted to leave, but the more information we’re being fed from dferent sources I now have no idea.”Graham Galvin, , from Monieth, was a remain voter and admits he has also been left confused by the current state of affairs at Westminster.He added: “Brexit is horrendous. I think both sides need to take some time to consider what a no-deal Brexit would really mean for the UK and the EU.“We definitely need to re-assess what we’re doing.”The developments leave Brexit on a kne edge, with MPs set to vote on whether the option to leave the EU without a deal should be on the table or not. The vote will take place tonight in line with a promise from Mrs May last month, with MPs deciding whether the UK can leave the EU without a deal on the agreed date of March .If, as expected, a no deal scenario is rejected, MPs will again vote tomorrow on whether to authorise Mrs May to seek an extension to Article .

title: if united can refocus their targets it can set them up for play offs
story: Results at the weekend and this week confirmed to me Dundee United are heading for another year in the play-offs.Andthat’s a disappointment for Arabs, what I’d say to them is things could be a lot worse.If, as I think, the route to promotion is going to be via that post-regular season lottery, it’s better to know now than later.I say that because very often in these cases a team that narrowly misses out on automatic promotion right at the end of the league campaign, or in the final week or so, goes into the play-offs on a massive downer.That makes it hard to lt players and fans and is very often why it’s one of the lower-ranked teams, one that’s been on a good run to get to that stage, that comes through and wins them.Where United are now, it would take a big collapse by leaders Ross County for them to be caught.I don’t see that happening and, evenit did, I’m not sure the Tangerines can go on the kind of winning run needed to capitalise.They have definitely been progressing under Robbie Neilson but they’re not yet where he wants them to be.That means they will drop points at times, like last Saturday at Partick Thistle, and that will make it even harder for them to put any real pressure on County.That’s why I think knowing top spot is gone with a few weeks to spare could prove a blessing in disguise for Robbie Neilson and his players.They have to keep their eye on the ball and make sure they don’t slip out of second spot – something that cost them dearly under Csaba Laszlo last season.If they do that, though, they can use the next couple of months to make sure the squad is ready for the final promotion push.That might mean resting some players here and there, while others could be worked a bit harder in training to get their fitness levels up a bit.A few of the players brought in during the January window hadn’t been playing a lot, so giving them extra training would be useful.One worry I have for United is, in the past couple of games, they’ve looked a side teams know how to play against. Particularly against Inverness last week, they seemed to be able to keep United at arms’all too easily.I think that had a lot to do with the tempo of their play, which was not high enough. Particularlythey were to come up against the Premiership team in a play-off final, that would have to be addressed.Lee Wilkie was writing in his weekly column in the Evening , published every Wednesday.

title: sponsored national lotterys va support helps dundee woman realise dream
story: A young Dundonian has told of the impact VA Dundee has had in creating opportunities for creative talent to stay and thrive in the city.Supported by The National Lottery, VA Dundee opened in September , attracting more than , visitors in the first three weeks alone. As the only other VA museum anywhere in the world outside London, VA Dundee presents the brilliance of Scottish creativity and the best of design from around the world, providing a place of inspiration, discovery and learning through its mission to enrich lives through design.As well as attracting international visitors, the museum has made a strong local impact as well, including the opportunities it has provided for young people in the city like Ailsa Purdie. vw, px"  Ailsa, , was brought up in Dundee and became involved with VA Dundee as a member of its Young People’s Collective, which gave young people a voice by offering ideas and getting them involved in designing the opening D Festival and creating events for the museum. Ailsa embraced it and when the job of Membership Coordinator arose, she applied and was successful – key, she says, to her being able to stay in Dundee.Ailsa said: “VA Dundee being here has created a lot of opportunities for young people like me. Even the impact beyond the museum, it has all helped keep a lot of the creative talent and young people who would possibly have been going away otherwise.“A lot of my friends I was at school or college or university with have actually stayed in Dundee now, whereas before they would maybe have left for another city. Having the museum here has created this place where people want to be and want to start their business and want to work which is fantastic to see.“One of the big changes I see in Dundee is there is a lot of civic pride, people are really proud of their city. There were so many amazing things going on before VA Dundee was here, but the museum has really just shone that spotlight on everything that was always going on here, brought it to the forefront and brought a lot more people into the city to see these things. “Among the many positive experiences Ailsa has enjoyed through volunteering and then employment, her favourite and most memorable moments have been her involvement both in the opening of VA Dundee last September and then the official opening of the museum by the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge in January.Ailsa explained: “The opening was such an exciting time for everybody, it was mind-blowing to see it all on such a large scale. Once it was all happening it was so emotional to see my city having the eyes of the world on it – just to witness that was a once-in-a-letime experience that I will cherish forever.“I was then involved in the Royal visit representing the Young People’s Collective. The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge came to visit the museum during which they were really keen to meet the young people involved in the opening.“So a few of us got to meet them both which was such an amazing experience, they were so interested in everything we’d been doing and asked lots of questions. It was a surreal experience but a wonderful one.” vw, px"  Over £ million of National Lottery funding was awarded to help VA Dundee become a reality – and Ailsa says it has changed her le and the lives of many others.She added: “VA Dundee has changed my le in so many ways. It’s given me a chance to stay here and to do something amazing in my town. One of my neighbours I’ve grown up with and who is supportive of me, when I got the job she told me it is so amazing that Dundee is able to give me this opportunity and I think that sums it up.”From today, any organisation that has received National Lottery funding has the chance to gain nationwide acclaim by entering the th Birthday National Lottery Awards – a search for the UK’s favourite ever National Lottery-funded projects.National Lottery Awards winners will receive a £, cash prize and national recognition at a glittering ceremony broadcast on BBC One later in the year. To enter your favourite project in this year’s National Lottery Awards, tweet @LottoGoodCauses with suggestions or complete an entry form through the Good Causes website by midnight on  April .To find out more about National Lottery Good Causes visit the website or follow #ThanksTayYou on social media.

title: aberdeen pta groups plans to revamp football pitch rejected by council
story: Plans to replace a grass playing field with an all-weather G surface have been knocked back by Aberdeen City Council.Broomhill School PTA applied for planning permission to revamp the pitch, in the hope it could be used by pupils from the primary school all year round.The pitch falls in the Woodies area of Broomhill Road, across the street from the school.A decision signed by Aberdeen City Council development management manager Daniel Lewis, stated the plans were largely compliant with planning policy, but the pitch would encroach into “a signicant portion of the root protection areas of three adjacent mature trees”.Mr Lewis describes the trees as “contributing toward the landscape character and local amenity of the Woodies”.The decision said: “The groundworks would result in soil compaction, lack of water availability and restricted soil and air gaseous exchange for the roots, which would in turn result in the severe decline and or death of the trees.”Kevin Rinchey, the head of the PTA steering group responsible for the project, said: “We’re disappointed.“When we drew the plans, we did realise there were trees in the field, and all the plans we drew tried our best to avoid them.“So it was disappointing when it came back.“We wanted to protect the trees as well.”Kevin, who has two children at the school, said the group will not be coming back with a change of plans, or appealing the decision.He said: “We’ve re-jigged them a few times, so I don’t think we’ll come back with anything .#We did a tree survey and re-adapted the plans two or three times, so I don’t think we’ll come back with anything.”Mr Rinchey described having a year-round facility for use by the youngsters is “vital”.He said: “I’ve lived in Broomhill all my le, and I’ve just watched it deteriorate.“The kids can’t use the facilities so they have to go where, like Kaimhill or Harlaw for their activities.”

title: former strictly star ian raises cash for comic relief with aberdeen airport show
story: A former star of Strictly Come Dancing showed off his footwork as he visited Aberdeen airport to raise funds for charity.Ian Waite, who appears on the BBC show’s spin-off It Takes Two, was at Aberdeen International Airport yesterday to support Comic Relief.The event was organised in conjunction with British Airways’charity Flying Start, which supports the Comic Relief Appeal. Ian, , who got dressed up in a red tutu for the occasion, began his day by entertaining passengers on a flight from Heathrow. vw, px"  He then helped host a bake sale and bucket collection in the terminal – and even found time to dish out a few dance lessons to some lucky travellers.He said: “Everyone has been very, very generous. People are always a bit shy at first but when I invited them to come and have a dance they were very keen. We did a bit of salsa with them and everyone has had a lot of fun.”Flying Start has raised more than £ million since its partnership with Comic Relief began in  – two years ahead of its intended deadline of . The money raised has helped support more than , children and young people in the UK and in some of the poorest communities around the world.BA has also announced £m of funding will be invested in projects focusing on early childhood development in key locations. vw, px"  Flying Start’s regional executive Laura Phillips said: “Over the last two weeks we have been going all over the country getting celebrities on flights and in airports to raise awareness of the work we are doing.”Aberdeen International Airport managing director Steve Szalay said: “Ian most definitely brought some Strictly cheer to our passengers. It was great to see so many people get involved.” vw, px"  In May, Ian willto the city with ex-Strictly star Vincent Simone for their Ballroom Boys show at the Tivoli.Elsewhere, Strictly hosts Tess Daley and Claudia Winkleman raised more than £, for Comic Relief during a -hour danceathon which ended last night at the BBC Radio  studios.

title: play it cool call to blue toon in bid for title joy
story: Peterhead’s Jack Leitch says the Blue Toon still need to “wait and see” after one of their main rivals dropped out of the League Two title race.Clyde, who were seven points behind the Blue Toon with a game in hand, were hammered with a four-point deduction by the SPFL for fielding an ineligible player in matches aginst Albion Rovers and Queen’s Park.They proceeded to lose - away at Elgin City to drop  points back.That leaves just Edinburgh City – five points behind the Blue Toon – between the Balmoor outfit and the title, plus automatic promotion to League One.However, Leitch, pictured, isn’t letting himself get too excited just yet. He said: “I know, obviously with what happened to Clyde. But Edinburgh have been up there the whole way, so we just need to concentrate on them.“We play them in two weeks and they play Annan next week, which will be dficult for them as they’re a really good side.“We’ll just need to wait and see, keep doing our jobs and see what happens come the end of the season.”Leitch was effusive in his praise of fourth-placed Annan, who led after  minutes at Balmoor on Saturday before goals from the midfielder and veteran striker Derek Lyle sealed the points.He said: “They started really well actually and came out really bright the first  minutes.“It took until their goal to kickstart us a wee bit, but after that I think we played really well. With the wind, it was obviously dficult, but we settled down and played a lot better.“It was definitely . We said that at half-time.“We were really happy to come in at one each the way we started the game, but the way we went about it in the second half – we played a wee bit more in their half, with a lot more corners and opportunities. We were delighted.”While Edinburgh are taking on Annan, Jim McInally’s side will be in distant Berwick, playing the league’s second-bottom side.A consequence of Clyde’s punishment was rock-bottom Albion Rovers getting three points and, buoyed by the news, they beat Stirling Albion - at Forthbank.This means they are now just two points behind Berwick, something Leitch thinks will make the meeting with the Borderers at Shielfield Park dangerous.Leitch said: “It’s been proven so many times, anybody can beat anybody in this league. The games are so competitive and so tight.“We’ll prepare right this week and look forward to Berwick.”

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby

The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowShinty in Mid Argyll has lost one of its great stalwarts with the passing of John Crawford of Ardrishaig after a short illness.John, aged , died in Mid Argyll Hospital on the evening of Thursday February .John was born and brought up in Minard in Argyll. He was a former member of shinty#s South of Scotland area executive council and did a lot of work for the Referees’ Association.He was probably best known for his work with young players in Mid Argyll, organising qualying tournaments of the Aviemore Indoor Sixes tournament for many years. His work for that competition was recognised by the organisers when he was given a special award at Aviemore along with his friend Donnie MacKenzie of Lochaber.John helped reform Kilmory shinty club in the mid s along with Ian MacPhee, the late Kenny MacRae, Roddy Munro and Alex Campbell. He also served on their committee for many years.John had served as a policeman for a short time before working in the quarry at Furnace, then going on to be a very well-known driver with Gleaner Oils, which supported many of his shinty activities with young players in Argyll.John was a great organiser and acted as goal judge in a number of senior shinty finals including the Glasgow Celtic Society Cup and notably the Camanachd Cup Final in Inverness when Gordon MacIntyre of Oban Camanachd scored his famous winner at the Bught Park.John apparently retrieved the ball from the net and lobbed another onto the park for the re-start before presenting the goal-scoring ball to Gordon after the match.John is survived by his brother Jim who played for Glasgow Police and he was pre-deceased by his we Donella. Just about visible across Loch Gilp is the Scottish Canals-led Egg Shed project to create a new heritage and interpretation centre in Ardrishaig, due to open this summer.And the council is bidding for funding worth more than £ million through Historic Environment Scotland#s CARS scheme to refurbish some of Lochgilphead#s town centre buildings.Add to that planned improvements to public halls and the KGV pitch in Ardrishaig planned upgrades at Mid Argyll Community Pool a major project by Mid Argyll Youth Development Services and more, it is clear things are happening in Mid Argyll.If you want to give your thoughts on what should feature in the front green project, there will be a drop-in event between am and pm at the corner of Colchester Square and Poltalloch Street where you can meet council staff and members of the design team and ask questions, hear about the plans and give your views.An Argyll and Bute Council spokesman said: #We want to work with the community on the plans for delivering improvements to the front green and Colchester Square, so please come along for a chat and a cuppa.#A second event will be held on Saturday April , when people will be able to see how the plans have developed based on comments gathered this weekend.Design team member Nick Wright said: #This is a great opportunity for folk to come and share ideas about how to make the front green into a space that the community is really proud of.#We’ll have some ideas to start people thinking, but we want to hear what people’s ambitions are for the space.#That could be anything: stopping flooding, more events, a nice place to sit, more exciting play areas or something to make tourists stop and spend time in the town. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: crumbs cocktails bar boss hails
story: Owner Ashley Nicholson, pictured front right pictured with staff member Kirk Burns, front left, with customers."Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA bar boss has hailed heroic punters who chased an alleged gunman from her pub. Ashley Nicholson said customers had “risked their lives” to protect her business and staff during a terrying hold-up. A man was later arrested and charged following the drama at Ayr’s Crumbs and Cocktails. Ashley, , said: “It was horrendous but our customers’ reaction says a lot about not just our bar, but Ayr in general. “It’s easy to get down about the town at the moment with Hourstons closing and one thing or another. “Maybe it takes something like this to show how people can pull together when you need them.” Ashley’s popular haunt was the subject of an attempted raid last Monday night. It followed the bar’s busy quiz night when an alleged gunman struck about .pm. Around  punters had been in the bar shortly before. Ashley, who has run Crumbs for six years, said: “People risked their lives to stop this person and of course I would never advocate doing that. “But it’s brought all of us closer together...I’ve always said this pub is like a dysal family. “We all look out for each other and everyone who comes in shows respect for one another. “The reaction since it happened has been amazing. “People have been coming in full of hugs to check we’re okay and the town has been so supportive.“In a way I’m happy it happened here rather than somewhere with vulnerable staff andcustomers.“Like many pubs, we have a sense of community and I’m glad we could show it.” A man appeared in court last Wednesday in connection with the armed robbery on Crumbs and Cocktails. The -year-old was accused of being in possession of a firearm with intent to cause fear or violence. He was also charged with using a firearm to resist arrest when he appeared at Ayr Sherf Court. He made no plea or declaration when he appeared and was remanded in custody pending further police investigations. He was expected to make a second appearance in court tomorrow .Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnFirearmsAyrCourts

title: end era popular ayr music
story: NewsEnd of era as popular Ayr music shop shuts downBig Sparra Vinyl in Ayr has announced its closure following a recent flood at the New Bridge Street store.ShareByAbi Smillie:,  MAR NewsIan Wallace of Big Sparra Vinyl "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt’s the end of an era for a much-loved record store which has touched the hearts- and ears- of many across the country. Big Sparra Vinyl in Ayr has announced its closure following a recent flood at the New Bridge Street store. The record shop has been selling golden oldies and modern mixes for half a decade. And Big Sparra has had its fair share of the limelight as it featured as one of the main filming locations in a TV advert as part of the National Trust for Scotland’s campaign, For the Love of Scotland. The store have been big supporters of annual Record Store Day in the past and even opened at am to allow vinyl collectors to get their hands on limited-edition discs. But it seems it’s not the end for co-owners Robert McKain and Ian Wallace as the pair move on to new ventures, with the latter half of the duo hoping to reopen in the same unit. Robert took to Facebook to tell of the closure and thank their supporters.   He said: “We want to thank all of our customers and friends for their support over the last five years in Ayr. “All hasn’t been plain sailing lately and the recent flood was the catalyst in our decision to close the Ayr store as we know it. “Before we tell you about exciting future plans we just wanted to show our genuine gratitude for making us part of the local community. “To be accepted so warmly really has made our time in Ayr all the more enjoyable. “Rarely in our ten years working together have Ian and I had so many entertaining encounters. “Very sad to end this chapter, even though we are both going on to work on interesting new projects. “Let it be known that it won’t be the last you hear of Ian who plans to reopen in the same unit with a new emporium for gts, some music and coffee.”

title: holiday beach made rubble
story: NewsThe holiday beach made of rubbleSilver strand is lined with brickShareByStuart Wilson:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsNo sand castles - but they can be made from brick. Derek Hart examines. "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA town’s beach is set for an overhaul after a winter battering. Residents in Prestwick say their much-loved shore has been left in a pathetic state following rough weather. And they insist only long-term surgery will cure the ongoing problem of rubble piling up on the prom. Bosses at South Ayrshire Council have pledged tolater this month with a dredging machine to tackle the sand. But Derek Hart, chair of the town’s North Community Council, reckons the bigger picture must now be embraced. He said: “We have been in talks with the council and had assurances they willto work on the sand. “This is a source of huge relief to all concerned as the beach has got into a pretty pathetic state of late. “With Easter just around the corner we simply have to take action. “But longer-term we know this is a problem which won’t go away. “The rubble is piling up, as we knew it would following the winter, and the issue is going to keep repeating itself.” Campaigners fought to have the council roll on to the sand last year at a cost of pound,. Tons of rubbish, much of which originates from broken sea defences at Newton Shore, was removed. But just a few months on the prom is back to square one. Derek added: “A lot of people don’t even know Prestwick has a beach and that’s something we want to change. “We want to boost the number of attractions at the prom but that has to start with a high standard of beach.” A council spokesman said: “Our beaches are important for the local environment so the Prestwick beach cleaning project is scheduled to take place each year to ensure rubble is removed before the main beach season. “This year work will start towards the end of March, subject to weather conditions. “We will continue to work closely with the local community councils, the Friends of Prestwick Seafront and other community partners so that the amenity beach looks its best for the busy season.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnPrestwickAyrAyr NewsSouth Ayrshire CouncilReligion

title: old favourite haunt mcarthurs ayr
story: NewsOld favourite haunt McArthurs in Ayr to open later this monthArthur Street joint gets .am licenceShareBySarah Hilley:,  MAR NewsAs it was - shutters came down six years ago "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA shut pub in the heart of Ayr’s night strip is on the verge of opening again under new management. The former McArthurs, which closed six years ago, will become home to The Buf later this month. The Buf already operates a premises on Main Street, Prestwick. The newly launched boozer has been given permission to open late until .am on the weekend of March  for opening celebrations. Solicitor Brian Dunlop said the premises had been purchased by new owners and the business venture would create  new jobs. Speaking at last week’s South Ayrshire Licensing Board, he said: “These premises were formerly known as McArthurs and have been closed for many years.” The council received no objections to the plans. Building work has been taking place over the course of recent weeks. Councillor Siobhian Brown said: “I am really pleased The Buf are opening up in Ayr.” She said nightle had suffered in the town, with people flocking to Prestwick instead. The board approved a set of late opening .am nights but turned down another couple of requests. Global Wine Distributors Ltd is behind the pub venture. In a report to the board licensing standards officer Catrina Andrew said: “The premises have been closed for the past few years and have recently been taken over by a new operator who is also responsible for a premises in Prestwick.” Currently the premises is due to close at .am on Monday to Saturday and midnight on Sunday. A social media statement from The Buf said: “Yes the rumours are true-we’re coming to Ayr.” Arthur Street has been the site of a number of new nightspots including Vinyl and Arthur Street Kitchen. title: rail passengers ayr glasgow faced
story: NewsRail passengers from Ayr to Glasgow faced chaos as train cancelled because of Storm GarethCustomers urged to check ScotRail on social media for latest informationShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR NewsRailway station at Glasgow Prestwick International Airport."Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRail passengers faced chaos this morning as damage from Storm Gareth caused widespread disruption to services in and out of Ayr, writes Paul Behan Last night’s storm caused overhead line damage in the Barassie area, resulting in cancellations to services to and from Ayr Central. As a result trains from Glasgow to Ayr are currently terminating at Irvine- with trains from Ayr to Glasgow starting at Irvine. Replacement bus services have been put in place to keep customers moving, though, and ticket acceptance is also arranged with Stagecoach West. Additionally, a tree fell onto the overhead wires between Irvine and Kilwinning, causing damage. This meant that, from the start of service today, Largs and Ardrossan trains terminate and start from Kilwinning. Trains from Kilmarnock Ayr to Girvan Stranraer have also been cancelled. Replacement buses were also put in place for Largs, Kilwinning and Ardrossan. A ScotRail spokesperson said: “We are sorry to customers who have experienced disruption as a result of Storm Gareth, and share their frustration. “We are working flat out to get services back to normal as quickly as possible. “We are doing everything we can to keep people moving, including ticket acceptance with local bus providers and replacement bus services. “Customers should check ScotRail on Twitter or download the ScotRail app for the most up to date information. “Anyone delayed by  minutes or more can claim money back through our Delay Repay Guarantee on our website or mobile app.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnScotrailTwitterAyrSocial mediaGirvanLargsArdrossan

title: britains-longest-serving-ice-cream-man-set-to-have-galashiels-street-named-after-him
story: BRITAINS longest-serving ice cream man is set to have a street named after him in Langlee.Adam Kelly along with former Scotland footballer John Collins and one of Galashiels greatest servants Bill Lamb, have all been put forward by the community council.Last month, members were asked to draw up a list for three unnamed roads at the Melrose Gait.And after much discussion, they came up with Adam Kelly Place, John Collins Crescent and Bill Lamb Crescent.Mr Kelly made national headlines when he finally hung up his ice-cream scoop three years ago after five decades of serving up cones and tubs from his van.He died last year at the age of .Sports star Mr Collins, who was born in Langlee, played for a number clubs at home and abroad, including Celtic, Hibernian, Fulham, Monaco and the Scottish national team.And former councillor Mr Lamb held several portfolio posts when the Liberal Democrats were in power at Newtown St Boswells.He died last year.Chairwoman of the community council Judith Cleghorn said: "Adam Kelly seemed to be a very popular suggestion from people."I would also like to put forward Bill Lamb. He was served the town well and was a very good friend of mine."Tom Ingoldsby said he supported John Collins.He told the meeting: "John Collins came from Langlee and made a big name for himself, I think it would be good to recognise him."Also among the suggestions were naming a street after Charles Lapworth ndash a geologist who moved to Galashiels in  George Hope-Tait ndash a poet and councillor who is also recognised for his contribution to art, architecture, journalism and authorship in the town and former Town Clerk George Knox.Members were askedthere was a reason why most of the suggestions put forward were to recognise people who have died.Community councillor Rick Kenney said: "A lot of towns normally name streets after people who have passed away."The reason why many dont pick living people is because of the risk of them letting the town down."

title: watch-foreign-secretary-jeremy-hunt-visits-galashiels
story: JEREMY Hunt says we must keep our Borders open to welcome international students after Brexit.The Foreign Secretary was speaking during a visit to Heriot Watts Galashiels campus this afternoon.One third of the universitys , students are from countries outside the UK.And Mr Hunt said studying here must remain an "attractive" option after Britain leaves the European Union.He told us: "We have to demonstrate to all our universities that the Brexit we end up with is a Brexit that is going to be positive for higher education in the UK."The reason for that is it is one of our most important and most successful industries."One of the reasons I am here is because when I go around the world and I talk about the great prospects Britain has,I talk about our universities."Last week we had rankings that showed we have four of the worlds top ten universities. A number of Scottish universities are very high up the list in the global rankings."I understand there is uncertainty, but what has powered our universities has been the fact they are so attractive for students all over the world. And that is what we want to continue."During the visit, Mr Hunt spoke with textiles students about theircourses and even had a go at printing a t-shirt.And he was quick to praise them for their creativity.He added: "I have seen fantastic creativity here at Heriot Watt."There are changes happening in all industries. Were on the cusp of the fourth industrial revolution."Textiles, as with other industries, is in the process of a huge digitisation which means that lots of things are done online andthrough D printing."All of these things have a big impact, but the one thing that computers and technology cant substitute for is creativity."And what we have in this country is extraordinary creativity."We have always had it. It has always been one of our great gts."

title: innerleithen-in-pole-position-ahead-of-biking-centre-report
