title: community-choir-set-for-day-long-comic-relief-tour-of-the-borders
story: COMIC Relief will be hitting the high notes and the road this weekend with a little help from a Peebles community choir.InChorus will travel around the Borders on Sunday to perform at ious unlikely venues.And they hope their selection of contemporary upbeat and light-hearted songs will bring a smile to audiences as well as boost funds for Comic Relief.InChorus events manager Paul Sewell told us: ldquoWe intend to stop wherever there are groups of people and sing to them. Comic Relief assists so many worthy charities and we want to raise as much for them as possible."For our part the trick will be to sing well while wearing our red noses!InChorus will open their day-long tour with a set in the Peebles branch of Sainsburys at .pm.Their next scheduled stop is Borders General Hospitals WRVS lounge.And then it will be on to Milestone Garden Centre near Newtown St Boswells and Woodside Garden Centre near Ancrum before an encore at Saunsburys in Kelso.As well as singing the choir will be collecting for the charity.Choir manager Lynne Johannessen added: ldquoIt is very much the ethos of InChorus to assist other charities when possible."Over the past ten years we have raised tens of thousands of pounds to this end."During this time we have received enormous support from the public and hope they will give generouslythey see us on Sunday."Please look out for us and come and say lsquohello."

title: borders-woman-chased-dog-walker-on-her-mobility-scooter
story: A BIZARRE bust-up between two dog walkers resulted in a furious woman chasing her rival on her mobility scooter, Jedburgh Sherf Court has been told.Christina Rowley, who was suffering from sciatica at the time, pursued Kerry Gwzodz on the electric vehicle as the dispute escalated.She even circled round Ms Gwzodz and drove the scooter at her forcing the woman to dodge out of the way.Eventually Ms Gwzodz fled down a flight of stairs with -year-old Rowley unable to follow her and the police were called.Rowley was initially charged with assaulting the woman with the mobility scooter by trapping her foot under it and spitting on her.But at Jedburgh Sherf Court she pleaded guilty to an amended charge of behaving in a threatening or abusive manner, shouting and swearing and driving the mobility scooter at Ms Gwzodz.The offence happened in Glebe Mill Street, Hawick, on July .Tessa Bradley, prosecuting, explained both women were walking their dogs on a public footpath along the banks of the River Teviot at .am when the incident happened.Rowleys dog was not on a lead and after it ran towardsMs Gwzodz and her two dogswords were exchanged.Defence lawyer Mat Patrick said his client insisted Ms Gwzodz reaction to the dog bounding towards was "excessive".And he added Rowley lost her temper during the exchange of words.Rowley of Earl Street, Hawick, was fined pound and ordered to pay Ms Gwzodz pound in compensation.

title: moy-set-to-unveil-collection-at-borders-art-fair
story: SCOTTISH landscape artist Moy Mackay is putting the final touches to her latest collection ahead of this yearrsquos Borders Art Fair.Over  exhibitors will join the award-winning artist this month at the non-profit fair in Kelso.Moy graduated from Glasgow School of Art in .She has achieved international acclaim in the likes of Australia, the USA and Europe for her unique work as a fibre artist.In , Moy was a contestant in the Sky Arts Landscape Artist of the Year with her felt creations.Moy has been a regular exhibitor and loyal supporter of the Borders Art Fair since it was launched.And she is excited about this years forthcoming event.Moy told us: ldquoWe canrsquot thank festival director Frances Fergusson, patrons Hugo Burge, Will Ramsay, Jane Countess of Haddington and their team of helpers enough.ldquoI know from first-hand experience that the positive impact and wide-ranging benefits of this event are felt right across the Borders and are impossible to quanty in figures only.ldquoPeople are proud that the Borders is staging this event and proud to be part of it too.ldquoSince the inaugural Fair in  and last yearrsquos revamp, the Borders Art Fair has been a welcome breath of fresh air for many artists and gallery owners working across the Scottish Borders and beyond.ldquoIt is also becoming increasingly important as a unique and reliable showcase for those of us who continue to find inspiration through living and working in this especially beautul yet too frequently unsung part of Scotland, and for whom it is essential to promote our work to the wider UK and potentially international market.The Fair was re-branded and re-launched last year due to an increase in funding opportunities.Now they can showcase work from dozens of artists from across the Borders and further afield.The Moy Mackay Gallery line-up this year includes work from Amanda Philips, Elizabeth Waugh, Sally Anne Fitter, Alison Cowan, Jen Collee and Lesley Anne Clarke.

title: scottish-borders-council-to-close-two-bin-lorry-depots
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council is to close two of its waste recycling bin lorry depots as part of its new budget.The plans will see council bin lorries being moved from Peebles and Duns and consolidated in Hawick and Galashiels, leading to longer journey times for bin crews and some other staff travelling to work.The extra travelling times for bin crews operating in the north and east of the Borders could also lead to an increase in the waste disposal servicersquos carbon footprint.A council spokesperson said: ldquoA review of the waste collection service was considered by the council as part of its budget, and the decision was made to progress with operating the waste and recycling collection service out of two depots, Galashiels and Hawick, instead of the current four ndash Galashiels, Hawick, Duns and Eshiels, near Peebles.ldquoThese depots will not be closing as there are also community recycling centres at these sites.ldquoMoving to an operation out of two depots allows the delivery of a more efficient service, allowing the improved management, support and use of staff and fleet resources, and to address workload equality and inequality issues, deliver economy-of-scale efficiency savings, reduce need for and reliance on agency staff, enable more standardised operations and improve communications.ldquoAll changes are made and staff are supported in line with existing human resources policies and procedures.The council spokesperson also said that extra fuel costs associated with the move would not negate any potential savings.The change forms part of the councilrsquos - budget, agreed on Thursday, February .Speaking at that meeting, council leader Shona Haslam urged her colleagues to vote for the administrationrsquos budget proposals saying: ldquoThis administration has, from the outset, been determined that our core front-line services would be protected, that our most vulnerable iniduals, families, and communities would be protected, and Irsquom extremely pleased that we have achieved this in the budget.ldquoBut thatrsquos not enough. Wersquore ambitious for the future, we want to invest in our communities and our young people. This budget also does that. This budget promises a digital, technological revolution in our schools.ldquoIt brings forward plans to replace four high schools in our region with a sensible, costed solution for how to do that.ldquoIt provides vital services such as bin collections and public toilets and brings forward solutions on how we can ensure that these services are fit for the future.

title: scottish-borders-council-may-force-joiner-to-close-shop
story: A JOINER who converted a garage into a workshop without planning permission could be forced to cease trading from the site.Daniel Howard, a director of Kilnknowe Caravan Park in Wood Street, Galashiels, bought the disused Redburn Garage, on the A Galashiels-to-Peebles road, and began operating a furniture repair and sale workshop from the site.The garage, once known as Bruce Motors, has been closed for several years, and Mr Howard believes his business will create up to  jobs for the area.After beginning to operate his business from the site, Mr Howard then applied for retrospective planning permission from Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning department.However, planners scuppered his proposals, saying the business is having a detrimental effect on the character and visual amenity of the area, and that Mr Howard has not demonstrated that there are no alternative sites available closer to the town centre.Now, Mr Howard has appealed to the councilrsquos local review body, and councillors will deliberate on the application when they meet on Monday  March.In his appeal statement to the review body, Mr Howard writes: ldquoI believe I have transformed a failing site with no future use prospects into inidual units creating jobs and increasing revenue in rates and taxes.ldquoI have requested a site visit so that the local review body can see that this joinery workshop is no more detrimental to the character and amenity of the area than a garage workshop.ldquoAdded to this point is that as a joinery workshop, it is less of a noise or spillage pollutant than the former garage was.ldquoIt is hard to see how it can be conceived as so dferent to a garage  Anyone looking in would see a joiner or a mechanic ndash is that enough of a dference to refuse the application ldquoChange of use has been permitted in many previous cases, and rightly so. If we did not encourage change, we would still be living in caves.Mr Howardrsquos arguments have not swayed principal planning officer Carlos Clarke as he recommends that councillors reject the application and force him to cease trading from the premises.He writes: ldquoAspects of the development are acceptable, subject to conditions, particularly to rationalise the number and appearance of the ious small structures proposed.ldquoHowever, the joinerrsquos workshop and retail sales would be contrary to the local development plan, and this conflict is not overridden by other considerations.ldquoAs these elements form a signicant part of the development proposal, it would not be appropriate to delete them from a prospective consent by condition.ldquoUltimately, therefore, the application should be refused because of the proposed retail and joinerrsquos workshoprsquos conflicts with council planning policy.The proposed joinerrsquos workshop would be contrary to the local development plan in that there is inadequate justication for the proposed use on this site, which is not located within an allocated employment, mixed-use or redevelopment area, and would be potentially detrimental to the character and amenity of the surrounding area.ldquoThe proposed retail use would also be contrary to the local development plan in that the site is not within the town centre and it is not been demonstrated that there are no sequentially preferable sites closer to or within the town centre or that the proposed development would not detract from the vitality and viability of the town centre, and because the visual impact of the retail use proposed would be detrimental to the character of the surrounding area.ldquoOther material considerations do not outweigh this conflict.

title: pet-of-the-week
story: This weeks Pet Of The Week, from Borders Pet Rescue, is Fluffy.The charity told us: "She is around six months old and is a very shy girl. She is looking for a home where her owners will have the time and patience to help build her confidence around people."Fluffy is shy of any new people although once she has built up a trusting bond she is happy to be stroked. However, she does not enjoy being handled so whoever takes her on must be able to read when she is wanting her own space and respect her limits."Fluffy is looking to be the only pet in a quiet home with no children."If you would like to offer Fluffy her loving forever home, please email Borders Pet Rescue at info@borderspetrescue.org for an application."

title: journey-from-poland-to-carlops-via-inverness
story: A UNIVERSALLY acclaimed play is coming to Carlops next month.Written and performed by Matthew Zajac of Dogstar Theatre, The Tailor of Inverness is stopping in Tweeddale on its Scotland-wide tour.Inspired by the le of Matthewrsquos father Mateusz, it is the story of a boy who grew up on a farm in Eastern Poland, now Western Ukraine, and became a tailor in Inverness.The tailorrsquos le spanned most of the th century, and the journey he took was made by thousands of Poles during the Second World War.His was a forced migration across many borders, subject to the brutal unpredictability of war.A promoter for the play told us: ldquoThe Tailor of Inverness is one of the most widely travelled and highly praised Scottish theatre productions of the last decade.ldquoWherever it has been seen, the universally acclaimed international hit play has evoked extraordinarily enthusiastic reactions.Matthew Zajac worked as an actor for over  years, appearing in theatres throughout the UK, and in numerous film, TV and radio productions. In , he was named Best Actor at the CATS Awards for his performance in this play.Zajac said: ldquoI come from the Soviets and the Nazis. I come from a farm, from the forests and fields of green Ukraine, from the resettlement camps of Germany, from the beaches of the Adriatic, from the grimy streets of Glasgow and the cool air of Inverness.The play premiered at Edinburghrsquos Assembly Rooms in  and was regarded as an instant success.The play has toured Scotland five times already and has been seen across Europe, Australia and the USA. In , the play sold out for three weeks at Manhattanrsquos Brits of Broadway Festival.Carlops Village Hall is hosting the play on Tuesday, April .For information on tickets you can call

title: finishing-touches-made-to-neidpath-viaduct
story: A PEEBLES resident has stepped in to help install an information plaque on a historic Tweeddale railway bridge.As previously reported, the Gutterbluids Society, along with the townrsquos Callantsrsquo Club have worked tirelessly to restore the Neidpath viaduct.And now, thanks to a donation from local Gerry Rossi, the finishing touches have been made to the project.John Falla, who is a member of the Callantsrsquo Club told us: ldquoIt was reported when the Gutterbluids Society, Peebles Callantsrsquo Club and friends repainted the Neidpath Viaduct, that all that was missing was a plaque to honour the designer ndash Peebles resident Mr Robert Murray.ldquoAnd Gerry Rossi very kindly responded.ldquoWith partial funding from both societies and Wemyss Estates the plaque is now in place.ldquoWe would like to thank Gerry for the very substantial donation towards the project.The bridge, built over the Tweed in , is listed as one of the best examples of a skew arch construction in Scotland.It saw its last steam train in , but is a popular crossing for locals and visitors exploring the woodland that surrounds the river. And in August last year, dedicated volunteer groups helped restore the viaduct to its former glory.Locals rolled up their sleeves, grabbed their paint brushes and restored the   of railings ndasha job which had not been undertaken in almost a century.Mr Falla, added: ldquoWe trust Mr Murray would be happy that local volunteers admire and care for his work some  years later.ldquoI am so grateful to everyone who had faith in this fantastic project, without their hard work it would not have been possible.

title: borders-author-wins-2019-bookbug-picture-book-prize
story: A BORDERS author and childrens book publisher has won the  Bookbug Picture Book Prize.Alan Windrams book, One Button Benny, which was illustrated by Chloe Holwill-Hunter, is the story of a little robot who has a special button that he is only allowed to press in an emergency, and of what happens when he finally has to press his button to help his friends.The winning book was announced in an exclusive video to schools and registered groups in January and presented at a ceremony in Glasgow last week.It was chosen by children across Scotland, aged between three and seven years old, who voted for their favourite via the Scottish Book Trust website. More than , children voted.The award is run by Scottish Book Trust, the national charity, with support from Browns Books for Students.The Bookbug Picture Book Prize celebrates the most popular new picture books by Scottish authors or illustrators. The runners-up were Eric Makes a Splash by Emily MacKenzieand I am Bat by Morag Hood .Alan Windram is an author and, along with his we Susan, is co-founder of Little Door Books, which has published work by Vivian French MBE, Emily Dodd and Fort William author Barry Hutchison. Earlier this year, Little Door Books was highly commended at the Saltire Literary Awards in their Emerging Publisher of the Year category.A free copy of each of the three books on the shortlist was gted to every primary one pupil during Book Week Scotland last November in the Bookbug P Family Bag.Alan Windram said: "I am so thrilled, excited and humbled that so many children voted for my book with Chloe to win this fabulous prize."Like Benny, I am absolutely over the moon. Congratulations go to Morag and Emily on their fantastic picture books, and thank you so much to everyone who took Benny to their hearts and voted for One Button Benny to win."We are all dferent, we are all special and we all have something to give."Marc Lambert, chief executive of the Scottish Book Trust, said: "Many congratulations to Alan Windram and Chloe Holwill-Hunter for winning this yearrsquos Bookbug Picture Book Prize. Itrsquos wonderful to see so many children taking part in the voting process, and we hope they enjoyed reading the shortlist, which was gted recently in the Bookbug Primary  Family Bag."Mairi Kidd, interim head of literature, languages and publishing, said: "Reading for pleasure is a precious gt and itrsquos great to see Bookbug encourage children to think about their reading choices, discuss books with those around them and make their voices heard."Huge congratulations to illustrator Chloe Holwill-Hunter and especially to author Alan Windram, whose young company Little Door Books also published One Button Benny. This is a brilliant endorsement for all Alanrsquos hard work and belief in the power of stories."Claire Smith, sales manager for Browns Books for Students, said: "Very well done to all of the shortlisted authors and illustrators for this yearrsquos Bookbug Picture Book Prize, and a huge congratulations to Chloe Holwill-Hunter and Alan Windram for winning this yearrsquos award."Browns Books for Students are proud of our ongoing partnership with Scottish Book Trust. It is a privilege to have such a strong association with Scottish Book Trust and supporting them with their outstanding work, in the development of reading and literacy in Scotland."For more information about One Button Benny, oryou would like to organise a visit from Alan Windram to your school, visit www.littledoorbooks

title: selkirk-woman-admits-embezzling-16k-from-mother-in-law
story: A SELKIRK woman has admitted a pound, embezzlement offence.Kirsten Darling embezzled the sum of pound, while acting under a welfare and financial Power of Attorney granted on behalf of her mother-in-law who was then suffering from dementia.The -year-old pleaded guilty at Selkirk Sherf Court to the offence which happened at her home in Leslie Place, between April and July last year.Darling, who is a former RAF chef and was the Selkirk Ex-Soldiers Association Standard Bearer at the towns  Common Riding, had sentence deferred until April  for the production of background reports.

title: border-league-enjoys-chess-master-class-during-grand-day-out-in-galashiels
story: ITS claimed chess could help reduce social isolation in the Borders.But, with the increase in popularity and speed of games online, its feared local clubs are in danger of disappearing.Selkirks Martin Keen says the regular meets are ideal for getting people out the house - young and old - and hes encouraging them to swap their computers for a traditional board once a week.Mr Keen said: "Wed love to see more players coming along and just turning up for a casual game of chess, whether that be at Gala, Selkirk, Kelso, or Berwick - they even have a club at NHS Borders."Especially with competing interests online, come out and challenge yourself and come and play face to face with people. There is a place for online, but come out and speak to people, socialise."A total of  players, from local school children to members of the Border League and beyond, took on the regions strongest player, David Kilgour , in a simultaneous challenge at the Focus Centre in Galashiels on Sunday.David, who helped set-up the annual primary school competition in , holds the Grandmaster title at Correspondence Chess.While games can be played via the internet in as little as  seconds these days, he recalled a time when he played by post - with each player mailing their next move to each other and one game lasting five years.Of the  boards played, David won , lost two and drew two.Galas Ally McGilvray was the only local victor, alongside Alex MacDonald, who had made a -mile round-trip from Irvine especially for the challenge.The highest graded challenger, Galas Martin Wallace and Selkirks John Moore each enjoyed a share of the spoils.A minutes silence was held at the start of the event in memory of Gala player Francis Lauder, who passed away last month following a battle with cancer, aged just .Ally, who took his place in Galas recent Border League games, dedicated his victory to him.For more information on your nearest club, contact Martin Keen on  .

title: teal-makes-miracle-recovery-after-road-accident
story: A FAMILY pet from Galashiels has defied the odds after being knocked down by a car and rupturing her spleenLabrador Teal suffered devastating internal injuries after being knocked down.And it took a team of eight vets and nurses to save her le.The black lab was out for a walk with devoted owner Jackie Paton when disaster struck.Vets believe the much-loved family pet would have bled to death had it not been for the quick-thinking of Jackie and husband, who rushed the dog to the surgery in Gala Terrace.An ultrasound scan showed heavy internal bleeding and there were fears a major organ could have ruptured.Teal underwent a delicate two-hour operation, where it was discovered the eight-year-old had a ruptured spleen and lost a pint-and-a-half of blood.Clinical director at Border Vets, Jim Ross and his team managed to stem the blood loss and removed part of Tealrsquos spleen, before giving her a transfusion of her own blood.Jim, who had joined the practice as new Clinical Director only a month earlier, paid tribute to the teamwork that helped to save Tealrsquos le.He said: ldquoI was initially concerned because Teal had heavy internal bleeding and we had to find the cause as we didnrsquot knowit was a major vessel."When we opened up her abdomen, it was full of blood, so we performed an autotransfusion, where blood she was losing was filtered and put back into her veins to avoid having to find a donor.ldquoWe discovered that the spleen had ruptured where she had been hit by the car and it was bruised and badly damaged. We then had to assessother organs were damaged, but there was no further visible trauma or blood loss."She was very lucky it was the spleen rather than another organ.ldquoBecause she lost so much blood, she wasnrsquot out of the danger zone after surgery. Fortunately, blood tests showed she was regenerating her own blood cells.After a tense  hours following surgery, to make sure she recovered, Teal was allowed home.Jim added: ldquoNot only did the owner react very quickly, but the whole team at Border Vets pulled together and stayed behind long after their working day had finished to ensure the best possible outcome for Teal.ldquoIrsquom over the moon with her recovery as she looks great and I canrsquot praise the fantastic teamwork by everyone at the practice enough.Teal lives with Jackie, her husband and their three sons, at their home in Galashiels.Jackie said: ldquoShe is an obedient dog but I think she misheard the command while we were waiting to cross the road."Irsquove never been in such a panic in all my le. Although there wasnrsquot a mark on her, she appeared fine for a short while however very quickly she deteriorated and became very poorly and couldnrsquot move very well.ldquoI couldnrsquot see a positive coming out of this situation and was worried about having to tell the children she had been put to sleep because she is part of the family."But I knew she was in the right place at Border Vets. Itrsquos such a relief that she is doing fine and is back to her old self.

title: storm-gareth-gale-force-winds-set-to-batter-the-borders
story: GALE force winds are set to batter the Borders from tonight, as Storm Gareth hits the region.The Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning for this evening and tomorrow.Chief meteorologist Paul Gundersen, said: ldquoThe strong north-westerly winds will affect southwest Scotland late on Tuesday, spreading across much of England and Wales through Wednesday."Gusts of - mph are likely inland."Winds will gradually ease during the afternoon."A warning has also been issued from Transport Scotland.Stein Connelly said: "The high winds forecast for the west Scotland could lead to some travel disruption, with potential for bridge restrictions in the affected areas and spray on coastal routes."Travellers should check the latest information before they set off, drive to the conditions and follow police travel advice."The Traffic Scotland mobile website allows you to get information on the move and the Traffic Scotland twitter page is updated regularly."The windy conditions are also likely to lead to disruption on other modes of transport, so we urge those planning to travel on trains, ferries and flights to check with their operators to seetheir services are affected."

title: galafoot-bridge-reopens-to-traffic
story: GALAFOOT Bridge has now reopened.The bridge was closed just after .pm in both directions due to fallen power lines.A ersion was put in place andScottish Power engineers were called to the scene.As previously reported the region will be hit by strong winds this evening and tomorrow.

title: parking-ticket-blitz-in-selkirk-isnt-the-answer
story: A BLITZ by Community Action Team officers in Selkirk last week led to  parking tickets being issued.But local councillor Gordon Edgar believes the work of the seven-strong force is just lsquoputting a sticky plaster over a bigger problemrsquo.And he is pushing for a more permanent solution to parking.Since traffic wardens were withdrawn from Borders towns in , incidents of problem parking have escalated.And police officers only react to offences on an ad-hoc basis.Councillor Edgar said: ldquoThe Community Action Team doesnrsquot just deal with parking ndash they have a lot of other anti-social issues to be getting on with as well.ldquoWhile they are working on other issues the traffic management issue is being ignored.Selkirk has been badly hit by drivers leaving cars on yellow lines in and around the High Street.Community policeman Conal McEwan has advised locals to report the parking pests.He said: ldquoIssues like parking need to be reported so that we know where and when to be.ldquoUnless itrsquos reported it wonrsquot be seen as a problem.

title: demolition-begins-on-historic-galashiels-church
story: DEMOLITION work has begun on a -year-old church in Galashiels.The historic St Aidanrsquos Church in Gala Park, which was founded in , required around pound, of repairs.Due to the extent of damage Book Development Limited was given consent to demolish the historic building.Council officers said it had now been "satisfactorily demonstrated" that the retention of the church would not be economically viable.A number of objections had been lodged to the demolition plan, arguing that the loss of the building should not be accepted for heritage reasons.The B Listed church was originally named the South United Presbyterian Church and in  merged with the former Trinity Church on the High Street, when it became known as St Cuthbertrsquos.Then in , St Cuthbertrsquos was united with Ladhope Parish Church, being renamed St Aidanrsquos in .St Aidanrsquos finally closed in  due to low congregational membership and high maintenance costs,

title: scottish-government-prepared-to-invest-up-to-85m-in-borderlands-deal
story: THE Scottish Government has announced it is prepared to invest up to pound million into the Borderlands Growth Deal.Ministers claim the cash, which would be injected over a -year period, will help fund digital connectivity, tourism, regeneration and skills.And Infrastructure Secretary Michael Matheson has called for the UK Government to match his commitment.He said: "I am delighted to confirm that the Scottish Government is investing up to pound million in the Borderlands Deal to support and develop the South of Scotland economy.ldquoAlongside the establishment of a new enterprise agency for the south of Scotland, and the activity being taken forward by the South of Scotland economic partnership, this investment will help to drive inclusive growth that delivers signicant and lasting economic benefits for iniduals, businesses and communities right across the region.ldquoI call on the UK Government to match our financial commitment, over the same timescale of ten years, to deliver a package of transformational investment that will harness the regionrsquos full economic potential.

title: brexit-live-debate-continues-as-mps-prepare-to-vote-on-blocking-no-deal
story: The debate surrounding Brexit continued on Wednesday, after Prime Minister Theresa May suffered another defeat in the Commons.MPs voted by  to  against the PMrsquos Withdrawal Agreement.Members will later vote on whether they are willing for the UK to leave the EU without a deal on March .The Speaker has provisionally selected the following amendments that may be voted on in this evenings #NoDealBrexitdebate:ndash @spelmancndash @DamianGreenRead all the selected amendments here: https:t.co iKXsuYTJpic jQHoYynYEmdash UK House of CommonsMarch , They will also vote on two amendments:ndash Amendment A, tabled by Conservative former minister Dame Caroline Spelman and which rejects a no-deal Brexit at any time and under any circumstances. While she later said she was withdrawing it, Speaker John Bercow said ldquoher amendment is frankly in the hands of the House of Commons.ndash Amendment F, in the name of Conservative former minister Damian Green and which calls for a delay to Brexit day from March  to May  to give time for preparations to leave without a deal. It says the Government should then offer a ldquostandstill agreement with the EU and its member states, lasting up to the end of  at the latest, during which the UK would pay into EU budgets and observe legal obligations while a permanent relationship is negotiated.Herersquos the latest:lsquoPeople against the ParliamentrsquoTory Brexiteer Sir John Redwood threatened a public revolt against ParliamentMPs voted to block a no-deal Brexit.Demanding the Government ditch Mrs Mayrsquos deal in favour of a no-deal exit before seeking a free trade deal with the EU, he said:ldquoThis Parliament must allow us to leave on March  otherwise it will be the people against the Parliament.Tory Remainer Dominic Grieve, former attorney general, said he found it ldquovery troubling to see Conservative colleagues support no deal just because they were dissatisfied with Mrs Mayrsquos deal.ldquoIt is an extraordinary form of frenzy, theBeaconsfield MP said. ldquoYou smash up the china first and then when yoursquore not satisfied with the china yoursquove smashed you decide to smash some more.ldquoThat is what wersquore facing and itrsquos my duty to do everything I possibly can to prevent it.lsquoWe can pass motions ruling out no deal until wersquore blue in the facersquoTory former cabinet minister Damian Green spoke to move amendment F, stating one of the purposes was to avoid a ldquoclf-edge no-deal Brexit for which itrsquos clear the country as a whole and in particular many of our major industries are not prepared.He said: ldquoI think that no deal on March th would be a disaster for the economy of the country.He added: ldquoVoting against no-deal does not mean that a deal will magically emerge. This House has to agree a deal and that deal needs to be acceptable to the EU. We can pass motions ruling out no deal until wersquore blue in the face but it will make no dference unless there are options that this House will support.The principle aim of the amendment he said was to make sure that Brexit is ldquoas smooth as possible for citizens and businesses.Brexit advocates lsquostill chasing unicornsrsquoIrish premier Leo Varadkar has said that people who advocated for Brexit has been chasing unicorns for a ldquovery long time.Taoiseach Leo Varadkar speaking at the US Chamber of Commerce in Washington DC Speaking to the press at the US Chamber of Commerce in Washington he said: ldquoAs we head into the next few weeks it should be blatantly obvious that unicorns only exist in fairy tales.ldquoI would say to people who advocated Brexit ndash is this really what they wanted, protectionism, borders, tarfs, restrictions on trade.ldquoIs this really what Brexit was all about. And for those who voted against the Withdrawal Agreement on the basis that they feared that Northern Ireland would be treated dferently as a result of the backstop, it must be evident to them now that itrsquos the UK Governmentrsquos intention to treat Northern Ireland dferently.Spelman pulls her amendment ndash but Bercow says itrsquos still on tableTory former minister Dame Caroline Spelman told MPs she will be withdrawing her amendment.But Speaker John Bercow replied: ldquoShe canrsquot withdraw her amendment, her amendment hasnrsquot yet been moved ndash her amendment is frankly in the hands of the House of Commons.ldquoIfputs forward an amendment and chooses not to move it thatrsquos for her judgment and people will make their own assessment of that, but itrsquos perfectly possible for other signatories to it who do stick with the wish to persist with it to do so.Dame Caroline said there is a majority against a no-deal Brexit in the Commons, adding: ldquoIrsquom really pleased the Prime Minister has brought forward a motion to rule out leaving without a deal on March .She said Mrs Mayrsquos motion offered a greater opportunity than her amendment to obtain a ldquoreally large majority against a no-deal Brexit, adding: ldquoI really appreciate the offers of support from other parties but I will be withdrawing my amendment.Sterling higher ahead of voteSterling moved higher on Wednesday as currency traders looked towards tonightrsquos vote.The pound was up over % versus the US dollar at . at the London market close, and up a similar amount against the euro at ..Markets also appear to be pricing in a potential extension to the Article  process, which is also driving the British currency higher.Connor Campbell, financial analyst at SpreadEx, said: ldquoIt appears that sterling is now working on at least two assumptions.ldquoOne, that there is no appetite for a lsquono-dealrsquo Brexit among the majority of MPs ndash including the Prime Minister herself ndash something that will be reflected in Wednesdayrsquos vote.ldquoAnd, two, that this will lead to a pound-positive outcome from Thursdayrsquos ballot on whether or not to request an extension to Article .Labour will support amendment ASir Keir said Labour would act tonight and oppose no deal with support of amendment A, adding: ldquoWe believe that is the cleanest and clearest way for the House to express its opposition to no-deal.He said Labour supported a close economic relationship with the EU and also supported a public vote.He said: ldquoIt is extraordinary that the Government have acceded to a free vote on the matter of such importance today, not to have a position on whether this country should exit the EU without a deal. That we know what they want.He added: ldquoPlease make up your minds in London, because this uncertainty cannot continue. Not for us, not for Britain and certainly not for our citizens.Watch: Countdown to BrexitlsquoNo hard borderrsquoIrelandrsquos Europe Minister Helen McEntee reiterated that Ireland was not planning for a hard border on the island.She said people in Northern Ireland did not want the Withdrawal Agreement to be cast aside and ministers in the Republic were still not planning to allow the introduction of a physical border on the island.ldquoIt is not something that we as a Government have been planning for, it is not something that we are thinking about and it is not something that we would allow.She said the UK and Ireland collectively had obligations as co-guarantors of the  Good Friday peace agreement to protect the peace process.Flying the flagFormer Ukip leader Nigel Farage attended this morningrsquos plenary session at the European Parliament in Strasbourg.lsquoAppallingrsquo timing for tarfs updateNational Farmersrsquo Union president Minette Batters said it was treat many agricultural sectors ldquosensitively but raised concerns over sectors which would not have such protection, such as eggs, cereals, fruit and vegetables.ldquoEven those sectors that are treated sensitively will, in most instances, see worrying and large reductions in the tarf rates currently charged on non-EU imports, she said.ldquoWe recognise the importance of ensuring food prices for consumers do not rise in a no-deal Brexit but we are deeply concerned that the approach to tarfs published today will mean a greater reliance on food produced overseas.And she urged MPs and Government to take ldquono-deal off the table and find a workable solution as a matter of urgency.Deal remains lsquoonly available treatyrsquoThe EUrsquos chief Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier, told the European Parliament that the Withdrawal Agreement reached last November ldquois and will remain the only available treaty.In agreeing to draw up documents clarying the terms of the Agreement in Strasbourg on Monday, ldquowe went as far as we possibly could in order to help the UK Government get the support of the House of Commons, said Mr Barnier.The EU has done everything it can to help get the Withdrawal Agreement over the line. The impasse can only be solved in the #UK. Our ldquono-deal preparations are now more important than ever before.mdash Michel BarnierMarch , Mr Barnier said it was now ldquothe responsibility of the UK to suggest a way forward.ldquoThey have to tell us what it is they want for their future relationship, he told the European Parliament.ldquoWhat will their choice be, what will be the line they will take  That is the question we need a clear answer to now. That is the question that has to be answered before a decision on a possible further extension.ldquoWhy would we extend these discussions  The discussion on Article  is done and dusted. We have the Withdrawal Agreement. It is there.ldquoThat is the question asked and we are waiting for an answer to that.Former foreign secretary Boris Johnson claimed the EU would come up with a new deal by March .He told LBC Radio: ldquoI covered a lot of EU summits, I have been to a lot of them in my time, I have seen how the EU works.ldquoThe horses always change places in the final furlong, itrsquos always at five minutes to midnight that the real deal is done.ldquoIn Brussels the real fix is always in at the end.Cameron: No deal a disasterDavid Cameron has warned MPs that failing to rule out a no-deal Brexit would be a ldquodisaster for Britain.The former Conservative prime minister said he backed Theresa Mayrsquos attempts to secure a deal despite her second overwhelming defeat in Parliament on Tuesday night.He told Sky News: ldquoIrsquove always supported the Prime Minister in her attempts to have a close partnership deal with Europe and she continues to have my support.ldquoThatrsquos the right thing to do. Obviously what needs to happen next is to rule out no deal, that would be a disaster for our country, and to seek an extension and Irsquom sure thatrsquos whatrsquos going to happen next.Warning over no-deal tarf regimeA new tarf regime on EU products in the case of a no-deal Brexit will act as a ldquosledgehammer to the UK economy, business has warned.The new levies, to be imposed from the day after a March  BrexitMPs vote for a no-deal withdrawal, would force up prices on EU imports including cars and many food products.The unilateral and temporary regime includes levies of .% on European cars and trucks which had previously been free of tarfs, potentially increasing the cost of a typical family hatchback by around pound,. Car parts would face no extra tarfs to avoid disruption to supply chains.But tarfs will be slashed on imports from outside the EU, potentially lowering prices on goods from countries like the USA and China.CBI director-general Carolyn Fairbairn told BBC Radio rsquos Today: ldquoThis tells us everything that is wrong with a no-deal scenario..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Brexit live: Debate continues as MPs prepare to vote on blocking no deal

title: kintyre campbeltown mini rugby news
story: At last Sunday#s tournament, between Mid Argyll, Lochaber, Oban Lorne, Etive Vikings and Kintyre-Campbeltown, the club fielded a full team of P  and, with some players not able to travel, seconded a couple of players for P  from Oban to make up a   teamDespite Saturday’s down pours, the Lochgilphead pitches stood up to the constant pressure and every club played five games each refereed by ious coaches.The club#s P , having not played a proper game since last year#s Dalriada, had a shaky start but grew in stature with each game played.Club spokesperson, John Forster, said: #Confidence was key and believing in themselves.#All the games were close and the net result was that P  drew three, lost one and won one.##The first P  game was closely contested ending in a draw.#The second game against a well drilled team saw a loss, however undeterred the players came back in their third to draw.#In the final P  game a quick score at the end pipped the opposition to give a well deserved win.#For both teams the coaches can now concentrate on improving the skill base and above all brushing-up the tackling.The next mini-rugby Dalriada is in Oban this Sunday and there will be a Campbeltown Dalriada at the Meadows on Saturday March .

title: kirstie renton is kintyres answer to laura muir
story: The same day as Scots runner Laura Muir achieved the #double-double# at the European Indoor Athletics Championship several Kintyre athletes raced to their own sports hall victories.Bill McCallum, organiser of the Argyll Sports Hall Athletics, urged competitors in Sunday#s Kintyre heat to go home and watch Laura compete in the biennial track and field competition.Those who followed his instruction would have seen Laura, , winning gold in the ,m and ,m events in Glasgow, two years after claiming both titles in Belgrade.After three hours of competition, the star of Kintyre#s Victoria Hall contest, in which  young athletes competed, was arguably Castlehill Primary School#s Kirstie Renton.Kirstie won four of the six events in the under  girls# section and impressed spectators in both running events, recording . seconds for the two-lap race and an amazing . seconds in the four-lap race.These times were not bettered by any of the boys or older girls.Kirstie also title: letter islands should not be side lined
story: I was happy to join Councillor Sir Jamie McGrigor at the latest Argyll and the Islands strategic group meeting.With Scottish Government representatives in attendance, many pressing local and national issues were discussed, from the road equivalent tarf, air flights to and from the islands, infrastructure challenges fuelled by our huge industrial growth, fuel poverty in rural Scotland and much more. per cent of Argyll and Bute#s population live on islands and Argyll and Bute has more inhabited islands than any other constituency in the United Kingdom.This means we should not be sidelined by central governments that can, at times, seem indferent to the challenges we in island communities face.Since the last local elections, island communities have councillors like Sir Jamie McGrigor and myself fighting hard for our constituents and their concerns all year round and I can give my proud assurance of that continuing.Councillor Alastair Redman,

title: dazzling dixieland jazz distraction
story: Kintyre Music Club welcomes Quattro MacJazz, comprising Alastair McDonald, banjo and vocals, Lennie Herd, trumpet, Hamish McGregor, clarinet and vocals, and Roy Percy, bass, to Lorne and Lowland Old Church Hall on Friday March  at .pm.Alastair first appeared in the late s with the George Penman band and carved out a highly successful career with his breezy folk and gospel oriented shows.Never forsaking his first love, jazz, he has become one of Scotland’s most loved, most talented and versatile showbiz personalities.A full-time bassist since , he has performed not only in his native Scotland but also in the USA, Canada, Germany, Denmark, Israel, Thailand, East Africa and the United Arab Emirates.He plays a mean banjo # as Billy Connolly said once in a radio interview: #Alastair McDonald…he’s a REAL banjo player!#For more than  years, Lennie Herd has been the first choice Dixieland trumpeter in the country.At the start of the Scottish trad boom in , he was one of the founders, along with Alastair, of the much-admired George Penman Band.He has since featured with countless bands across the UK including the Scottish Jazz All Stars, the New Orleans Joymakers and Alastair’s Clan MacJazz.Lennie has played with a number of Britain#s best musicians including George Chisholm, Alan Barnes, Terry Lightfoot and Humphrey Lyttleton.Hamish McGregor # playing his famous white clarinet # is undoubtedly among Scotland’s most charismatic jazz performers and his playing career now in its sixth decade.Self taught, he quickly found a liking for Dixieland music and started his first band aged .In , he formed the iconic Fat Sams Band, known for its high octane, toe-tapping #s, #s and #s era jazz covers.Fat Sams spanned three decades before being ‘put to bed’ in  and Hamish has now ed to his roots in Quattro MacJazz.Roy Percy is probably the hardest-working bass player on the British jazz scene.For  years he has been an integral part of Swing , the fine Django-inspired Edinburgh quartet. He has played with Fat Sam’s Band and Ken Mathieson’s Classic Jazz Orchestra.He is the exception to any moan about the absence of a desire to play among upcoming generations, being a quarter of a century younger than the rest of Quattro MacJazz.Roy can also be found playing in Scottish country dance bands, Rock-a-Billy bands and as part of a group specialising in th and early th century Italian love songs.His speciality is the rarely heard ‘slap’ technique but says that his main criteria in any performance is to #keep things swinging and drive the rhythm along#.Quattro MacJazz. title: free solo a review of an oscar winning documentary
story: This year#s Oscar winning best documentary feature Free Solo screened for one night only at Campbeltown Picture House.The film is about rock climber Alex Honnold#s obsession with solo climbing, without ropes, El Capitan#s ,ft route named Freerider in America#s Yosemite national park.Humans have always pushed their boundaries in many fields of endeavour and constantly look for innovative ways to do things dferently.In conventional sport, such as athletics and cycling or in team games like football, hockey and netball, advances nibble away at the impossible.Before Roger Bannister broke the four-minute-mile, it was considered a step too far.Endeavour which risks human le though falls into a dferent sphere and can polarise opinion.Into such categories must fall the space race. After his first two space launch attempts ended in failure, it is no surprise that Elon Musk#s SpaceX recently took a dummy to the International Space Station.Solo ocean crossings in a sailing boat are another example of a sport that seems too risky to many.Free Solo tells of Honnold#s perfectionism but ultimately he relies on  practice, friction, magnesium carbonate chalk for his sweaty palms and his wits.Throughout the ascent, and the preamble which leads to it, including romance and his girlfriend#s struggle #to understand#, Honnold is filmed by his friends, some of whom cannot bear to watch the final solo.Extreme solo feats have existed as long as humans. The marathon developed in Ancient Greece as a solo running challenge and people still die in the st century emulating those barefoot warriors.Climbing and mountaineering has a long history of solo risk taking and many of its protagonists live relatively short lives.Some though, such as legendary Italian Walter Bonatti, were hard wired for solitary ascents. He shot to fame in the s with a solo ascent of a climb on the Dru, renamed the Bonatti Pillar, in the French alps.Bonatti finished his hard climbing career in  with a solo in winter of the north face of the Matterhorn for the centenary of that mountain#s first attempt. He passed away, aged , in bed.Up till Free Solo, many films about climbing have only been of real interest to climbers and have not made it into mainstream cinema.Using the latest techniques including drones, remote cameras, huge telephoto lenses on digital cameras from the valley floor and cameras wielded by dangling climbers has created a National Geographic movie which has transfixed audiences.Even climbers emerge after an-hour-and-a-half with sweaty palms after the glimpse into Honnold#s seemingly nihilistic world.A still of Alex Honnold during his climb. title: letter spin doctors letter has no place in courier
story: I have always subscribed to the maxim that letters to local newspapers should reflect points of view, concerns, local topics of interest and similar items and should not be a  for political dialogue.I refer specically to the letter published in the March  edition of the Courier attributed to Alex Orr of Edinburgh, who happens to be the managing director of Orbit, an Edinburgh Communications Consultancy.Any ‘spin doctors’ interpretation of a political point of view tends to be marginally disingenuous, generally by omission by not containing the full facts.The letter in this case promoting the SNP, the content about which I do not wish to comment.The point I wish to promote is, that letters of this nature, particularly ones from professional bodies, should be addressed to the national newspapers either daily or Sunday editions and not, as I have intimated, to local newspaper editions.John R Newall,MoDhachaidh,Drumore,Campbeltown.

title: letter being a great listener can make all the difference
story: As a proud Scout ambassador I am always looking for ways to help young people develop the skills they need to succeed. One of the most essential of these is active listening.Today, according to new YouGov research,  per cent of UK adults who had a view said we do not listen to each other enough in UK society. That needs to change.In my profession, on the set of a Hollywood movie,actors don’t listen to each other, the scene doesn’t work.The same applies in real le – it’s about taking the time to understand dferent points of view and showing respect.Good listening is vital at both home and at work. Some  per cent of those with a view believe active listening is important in creating a productive work environment.The good news is that the Scouts in Argyll and Bute are leading the way in this area. More than  per cent of UK adults say that the Scouts are helping young people to develop this important skill by working together with dferent kinds of people in small teams.When young people learn listening skills, it encourages them to develop empathy and understand more about the needs of others.So whether you are an adult looking for a great volunteering opportunity in Argyll and Bute this year, or a young person looking to develop your skills, then visit www.scouts.scot to find out how to get involved.Thanks to all our great Scout volunteers and thanks for listening.Warwick Davis,

title: dale see signs of recovery in tough conditions
story: Glasgow University B Greater Glasgow Football League Div After a series of heavy defeats, partly due to injuries, Carradale performed very well against a side, second in the league and looking for promotion.Carradale chose to play with the strong wind in the first half and pressed forward with the advantage it gave.Early on DJ slipped a ball through to Nanek who beat the keeper only to see the ball slam into the post and the danger was cleared.#Dale played a high line attacking position, but with all credit to Glasgow University they passed the ball round and were always a danger on the break.#Dale had three free kicks from corners of the box but none disturbed the opposition keeper.Midway through the first half a lull in the weather gave Glasgow a chance and slick passing manoeuvres, with eight players involved in each finished with Deans scoring from  yards out in the th minute.The Kintyre side was very unfortunate not to equalise a minute later, when Elliot Gemmill, on the right wing, cut inside the full back and his first time effort, from the corner of the box, came crashing off the crossbar.The McFadyens Transport sponsored #Dale finally equalised in the  minute, again the Glasgow side were playing from the back but DJ took full advantage.He scored with a thumping shot into the back of the net having dispossessed the keeper.On the stroke of half-time Matthew Lang playing with Nanek had a chance to put #Dale ahead but the keeper saved the shot.Carradale knew they would be under pressure from the well drilled University side, when playing against the wind and tried to play a high level going into the second half.But the away side caught them offside. Craig Galbraith worked well playing with, eventual man of the match, Calum Johnson for the first time.In the th minute there was a skirmish in the box after a corner, Johnson cleared the ball but it ricocheted off the incoming player into the net.The Glasgow students had more possession with the wind advantage. With  minutes left, a tremendous fingertip save, by Neil McMillan, pushed the ball over the bar.With four minutes left the away side put the game beyond #Dale#s reach when Matthew Lamont tried to clear a corner shot but unforunately scored an own goal.In high winds and driving rain the game fizzled out.Both sides had played well in the conditions and kept the ball on the deck in addition, referee, Archie Mitchell said it was an easy game to ref with no bad tackles.The match ball was sponsored by Wee Toon Sports and a Carradale spokesperson thanked Food for Thought for the post match hospitality.Tomorrow Carradale travels to Helensburgh for an early kick off at noon.
