title: meeting-arranged-in-bid-to-save-cockenzie-and-port-seton-gala
story: Organisers previously announced following their emergency general meetingyesterday eveningthat the gala, which celebrated its th anniversary last year,had been cancelled due to a lack of support.A statement issued on Facebook by Cockenzie and Port Seton Gala committee said:"Following on from the poor attendance at our EGM, it is with deep regret that we must inform you that the  gala is cancelled and future galas are also in jeopardy."We appreciate this will be deeply upsetting for you all to hear."We will look to organise a disco event for the gala children as a small compensation."We tried our best but we can no longer carry on with the number of committee we have."However,after an outpouring of support on Facebook, the committee has decided to review the decision to cancel the gala, although its future is still uncertain.A meeting will be held on Thursdayand all volunteers and potential committee members are encouraged to attend.The meeting takesplace at pm at Port Seton Community Centre cafe, with any queries to be emailedto cpsgala@hotmail

title: developer-looks-to-have-plans-rubber-stamped-for-another-150-houses-in-gullane
story: CALA Homes already has planning permission in principle for the site at Saltcoats Field, on the villagersquos south-eastern edge.Now they will look for the local authority to approve the design, which includes eight three-bedroom apartments and  three-bedroom detached and semi-detached homes.A further  properties are split into  four-bedroom detached villas and  five-bedroom detached villas.Registered Social Landlord People for Places will also provide  affordable properties.That will be made up of eight one-bedroom apartments and a dozen two-bedroom apartments.Ten two-bedroom semi-detached properties will also be created, alongside eight three-bedroom semi-detached homes.Tom Drysdale, chairman of the villagersquos community council, which also covers Dirleton, Aberlady, West Fenton and Drem, said: ldquoPlanning permission in principle was given some time ago.ldquoWhat they have applied for is detailed planning permission.ldquoWe have been looking at that, the community council has been looking at that, and I think we accept there is not much point nit-picking about the development ndash it is going to happen.However, Mr Drysdale felt there were details of the plans that could be improved.The main point was the lack of connectivity between the existing properties in the village and the proposed development site.Mr Drysdale said: ldquoThey are big houses, with two cars, and people are simply going to use their cars.ldquoThat was the area we have written in, making those comments, and hope the council will take on board.According to the developer, the proposals will help to meet the growing need for new family homes in the local area, with the properties appealing to a erse range of buyers.The development will also see CALA invest a further pound.m into local infrastructure, including schools, transport, sports pitches, play equipment and rail contributions.Other proposals by CALA include a footway from Gullane to West Fenton, forming part of the Drem-Gullane Core Path link.Derek Lawson, land director with CALA Homes , said: ldquoSaltcoats Field will be a logical follow-on from our current developments in Gullane.ldquoSubject to the planning process, we hope to be in position to commence development in , with homes for sale being available in .

title: labour-and-liberal-democrats-announce-haddington-by-election-candidates
story: The vice-chairman of Ormiston Community Council has been announced as Labourrsquos candidate for the seat vacated by the resignation of Conservative councillor Brian Small last month.Neal Black will represent Labour as they attempt to secure a third seat in the Haddington and Lammermuir ward.Provost John McMillan and Councillor Shamin Akhtar were elected as Labour councillors in  and will be hoping Mr Black, who works as a learner engagement officer at Edinburgh College, joins them in the ward.Tom Trotteris the other sitting councillor in the ward.Mr Black also represents Ormiston on Farsquoside Area Partnership andhas a long association with Ross High RFC, where he is currently the clubrsquos secretary.He said: ldquoIrsquom delighted that local members have put their faith in me to contest this important election.ldquoI can think of no greater honour than being able to serve the community where I was born and have lived my whole le.ldquoIrsquom looking forward to giving my all to the campaign and talking to as many people as possible over the coming weeks.ldquoMy priority will always be standing up for local interests and defending local services.The current Labour-led administration has made signicant investment in the communities that make up the Haddington and Lammermuir ward.Meanwhile, Stuart Crawford will represent the Scottish Liberal Democrats at theby-election, which takes place on May .The count takes placethe following day at Meadowmill, near Tranent, with Haddingtonrsquos Corn Exchange undergoing a major refurbishment.Mr Crawford is a writer and journalist,as well as a trustee of Haddington Garden Trust.He said: ldquoI am really looking forward to being given the chance to represent residents of the Haddington and Lammermuir ward where I live.ldquoIt is important that the concerns of local people in vital local issues such as the pressures increased housing bring on the area are put above party interests.ldquoToo often local peoplesviews are ignored in the interests of party politics.I seek to reverse this.The Scottish Conservatives announced last week that Craig Hoy would be representing them at the by-election.The SNP have not yetannounced a candidate for the by-election.

title: council-paying-20-per-cent-over-valuation-for-new-sheltered-housing-in-tranent
story: The new development in Tranent will see four one-bedroom and eight two-bedroom flats bought by the local authority for pound.million.Planning chiefs said that the decision to pay above the district valuerrsquos recommended value of pound.million was taken because they believed it was good value for money.And they argued it was hard to value the new properties correctly as there were no other homes like them in the town.The flats, being built on the site of a former dairy on Elder Street in the town centre, will be bought by the council once complete.A report on the purchase, which has been agreed by the council with the local developer, said that although they were designated as sheltered housing, no warden accommodationor common room was included on the site.It said: ldquoWhilst these properties will be restricted to specialist housing, discussions are currently being held as the preferred client group. This may result in the designation being changed from sheltered housing in the future.The report revealed that the final purchase price for the flats, which will include a lt and sprinkler system, was above the district valuerrsquos valuation of the propertyrsquos worth by some pound,.However, planning chiefs said there was evidence that the development represented value for money. The report adds: ldquoThe valuation of these flats in Tranent is dficult as there are no other similar flats for sale in the area to make a comparison with and consequently may be under-valued.The flats will be added to the councilrsquos rental stock once available.

title: hollywood-star-films-advert-in-east-lothian

title: brexit-live-debate-continues-as-mps-prepare-to-vote-on-blocking-no-deal
story: MPs voted by  to  against the PMrsquos Withdrawal Agreement.Members will later vote on whether they are willing for the UK to leave the EU without a deal on March .The Speaker has provisionally selected the following amendments that may be voted on in this evenings #NoDealBrexit debate: ndash @spelmanc ndash @DamianGreenRead all the selected amendments here: https:t.co iKXsuYTJ pic jQHoYynYEmdash UK House of CommonsMarch , They will also vote on two amendments:ndash Amendment A, tabled by Conservative former minister Dame Caroline Spelman and which rejects a no-deal Brexit at any time and under any circumstances. While she later said she was withdrawing it, Speaker John Bercow said ldquoher amendment is frankly in the hands of the House of Commons.ndash Amendment F, in the name of Conservative former minister Damian Green and which calls for a delay to Brexit day from March  to May  to give time for preparations to leave without a deal. It says the Government should then offer a ldquostandstill agreement with the EU and its member states, lasting up to the end of  at the latest, during which the UK would pay into EU budgets and observe legal obligations while a permanent relationship is negotiated.Herersquos the latest:lsquoPeople against the ParliamentrsquoTory Brexiteer Sir John Redwood threatened a public revolt against ParliamentMPs voted to block a no-deal Brexit.Demanding the Government ditch Mrs Mayrsquos deal in favour of a no-deal exit before seeking a free trade deal with the EU, he said:ldquoThis Parliament must allow us to leave on March  otherwise it will be the people against the Parliament.Tory Remainer Dominic Grieve, former attorney general, said he found it ldquovery troubling to see Conservative colleagues support no deal just because they were dissatisfied with Mrs Mayrsquos deal.ldquoIt is an extraordinary form of frenzy, theBeaconsfield MP said. ldquoYou smash up the china first and then when yoursquore not satisfied with the china yoursquove smashed you decide to smash some more.ldquoThat is what wersquore facing and itrsquos my duty to do everything I possibly can to prevent it.lsquoWe can pass motions ruling out no deal until wersquore blue in the facersquoTory former cabinet minister Damian Green spoke to move amendment F, stating one of the purposes was to avoid a ldquoclf-edge no-deal Brexit for which itrsquos clear the country as a whole and in particular many of our major industries are not prepared.He said: ldquoI think that no deal on March th would be a disaster for the economy of the country.He added: ldquoVoting against no-deal does not mean that a deal will magically emerge. This House has to agree a deal and that deal needs to be acceptable to the EU. We can pass motions ruling out no deal until wersquore blue in the face but it will make no dference unless there are options that this House will support.The principle aim of the amendment he said was to make sure that Brexit is ldquoas smooth as possible for citizens and businesses.Brexit advocates lsquostill chasing unicornsrsquoIrish premier Leo Varadkar has said that people who advocated for Brexit has been chasing unicorns for a ldquovery long time.Speaking to the press at the US Chamber of Commerce in Washington he said: ldquoAs we head into the next few weeks it should be blatantly obvious that unicorns only exist in fairy tales.ldquoI would say to people who advocated Brexit ndash is this really what they wanted, protectionism, borders, tarfs, restrictions on trade.ldquoIs this really what Brexit was all about. And for those who voted against the Withdrawal Agreement on the basis that they feared that Northern Ireland would be treated dferently as a result of the backstop, it must be evident to them now that itrsquos the UK Governmentrsquos intention to treat Northern Ireland dferently.Spelman pulls her amendment ndash but Bercow says itrsquos still on tableTory former minister Dame Caroline Spelman told MPs she will be withdrawing her amendment.But Speaker John Bercow replied: ldquoShe canrsquot withdraw her amendment, her amendment hasnrsquot yet been moved ndash her amendment is frankly in the hands of the House of Commons.ldquoIfputs forward an amendment and chooses not to move it thatrsquos for her judgment and people will make their own assessment of that, but itrsquos perfectly possible for other signatories to it who do stick with the wish to persist with it to do so.Dame Caroline said there is a majority against a no-deal Brexit in the Commons, adding: ldquoIrsquom really pleased the Prime Minister has brought forward a motion to rule out leaving without a deal on March .She said Mrs Mayrsquos motion offered a greater opportunity than her amendment to obtain a ldquoreally large majority against a no-deal Brexit, adding: ldquoI really appreciate the offers of support from other parties but I will be withdrawing my amendment.Sterling higher ahead of voteSterling moved higher on Wednesday as currency traders looked towards tonightrsquos vote.The pound was up over % versus the US dollar at . at the London market close, and up a similar amount against the euro at ..Markets also appear to be pricing in a potential extension to the Article  process, which is also driving the British currency higher.Connor Campbell, financial analyst at SpreadEx, said: ldquoIt appears that sterling is now working on at least two assumptions.ldquoOne, that there is no appetite for a lsquono-dealrsquo Brexit among the majority of MPs ndash including the Prime Minister herself ndash something that will be reflected in Wednesdayrsquos vote.ldquoAnd, two, that this will lead to a pound-positive outcome from Thursdayrsquos ballot on whether or not to request an extension to Article .Labour will support amendment ASir Keir said Labour would act tonight and oppose no deal with support of amendment A, adding: ldquoWe believe that is the cleanest and clearest way for the House to express its opposition to no-deal.He said Labour supported a close economic relationship with the EU and also supported a public vote.He said: ldquoIt is extraordinary that the Government have acceded to a free vote on the matter of such importance today, not to have a position on whether this country should exit the EU without a deal. It is the latest evidence the Government is not governing and cannot act in the national interest.Tory Father of the House Ken Clarke said: ldquoEffectively wersquore back to square one, there is absolutely no consensus within the Government, within the Opposition party, within this Parliament and amongst the public exactly what leave means.The Governmentrsquos Withdrawal Agreement he said was ldquodead in the water, adding any extension was dependent on  other Governments ldquoall of whom are fed up to the back teeth with the state of British politics.Defeat for Government in LordsPeers have inflicted a heavy defeat on the Governmentrsquos plans for post-Brexit trade deals in backing moves to prevent a hard Irish border in the future.The House of Lords supported by  votes to , majority , a cross-party proposal aimed at ensuring the continuation of frictionless trade between Northern Ireland and the Republic and blocking the imposition of customs arrangements or other checks and controls after Brexit day.North-South trade  progress of trade deals post-#Brexit in spotlight as #HouseofLords continues to examine and make changes to #TradeBill. Find out more https:t.co BHzwvPVof pic UbqhQvlmdash House of LordsMarch , Labour lsquostill supporting public votersquoLabourrsquos Sir Keir was challenged on whether his party was still pursuing a second referendum, as he told MPs the Governmentrsquos Brexit deal has reached a ldquohopeless end.He said: ldquoIn those circumstances, both of the things we were ruling out in our manesto ndash the red lines of the Prime Minister and no-deal ndash are the only things on the table, and that is why we support a public vote to protect against those outcomes.ldquoI am proud that wersquore doing that at this stage of the exercise and itrsquos obvious why we need to do so.Independent MP Anna Soubry, a former Tory minister, asked Sir KeirLabour would support a motion or amendment for a ldquopeoplersquos vote.Sir Keir replied: ldquoThe Leader of the Opposition two weeks ago Monday made it clear that we would support an amendment to that end or put one forward for ourselves.ldquoTiming depends on discussions across the House and with others, but thatrsquos the clear position that we put down.Francois suggests a third meaningful vote is on the cardsERG member Mark Francois said the House of Commons has now said emphatically twice that it does not want Mrs Mayrsquos Withdrawal Agreement.ldquoWhen you read it, it means we donrsquot actually leave the EU. Thatrsquos always been the fundamental problem with it. Itrsquos billed as a way out ndash itrsquos not.The Conservative MP added: ldquoMPs, no matter what people think of them, can read. Theyrsquove read it, understand it and they ainrsquot voting for it.ldquoI suspect May will try to go back to Brussels to get more successions and wersquoll have a third meaningful vote on the week commencing March th.ldquoMy gut-guess is that in a very British way wersquoll muddle through, wersquoll drink a lot of tea, and leave the EU and be a free country again because thatrsquos what . million people voted for.ldquoMy message to Theresa May is to listen to her Party ndash all of it. Just about everyone voted for the Brady Amendment and the Malthouse one has been signed by Brexiteers and Remainers alike.lsquoBetween very bad or even worse is not a meaningful choicersquoShadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer said he wanted to see the ldquomantra of my deal or no dealhellip dead and buried in the vote tonight.He said: ldquoOn this side of the House we have never accepted there should be a binary choice between the Prime Ministerrsquos deal or no deal.ldquoBetween very bad or even worse is not a meaningful choice and it would be a very sorry end to the negotiations.ldquoYesterday the House overwhelmingly voted to reject the first of those options, the Prime Ministerrsquos deal. Today we have the chance to reject the second and we should do so with as big a majority as possible.ldquoThe mantra of lsquomy deal or no dealrsquo needs to be dead and buried tonight.Direct ruleMr Gove later claimed direct rule in Northern Ireland could be a consequence of a no-deal Brexit on March .Independent unionist Lady Sylvia Hermonsaid MPs, including the DUP, must give ldquodue weight to the serious warning issued by the head of the Northern Ireland civil service David Sterling about the ldquograve consequencesthere is a no-deal Brexit.Mr Gove said she was ldquoabsolutely % totally right, adding legislation issued by the Westminster Government to empower Northern Irelandrsquos civil servants to take decisions is ldquosustainable at the moment and it is hoped the executive can be restored.Mr Gove went on: ldquoBut it is also clear that the current situation with no executive would be very, very dficult to sustain in the uniquely challenging context of a no-deal exit.ldquoNow we, in the circumstances that the House has voted for no-deal, would have to start formal engagement with the Irish government about further arrangements for providing strengthened decision-making in the event of that outcome, and that would include the very real possibility of imposing a form of direct rule.ldquoNow that is a grave step and experience shows us itrsquos very hard tofrom that step, and itrsquod be especially dficult in the context of no-deal.Protesters raise banners on both sides of debateAs the debate continues inside the Commons, pro-Brexit protesters have taken to the streets outside to push their case.But they were met with pro-EU supporters.Ken Clarke seeks assuranceTory Father of the House Ken Clarke called on Mr Gove to confirm it was the Governmentrsquos position ldquothat we are ruling out leaving on March th with absolutely no arrangements at all, we are ruling out the complete collapse of all our legal and trading arrangements with the Continent.Mr Gove replied: ldquoHis point is correct, the motion commits the Government not to leave on March th without a Withdrawal Agreement, I hope that is clear and unambiguous, but the motion also makes clear that the default position in law is that we do leave the EU unless we can secure assent to a withdrawal agreement.Mr Gove said it was ldquoso disappointing the Government did not secure a mandate last night.Soubry queries whipping plansA cross-party amendment to take no deal off the table may not be put to the vote, Independent MP Anna Soubry has suggested.Ms Soubrysaid Dame Caroline Spelman, a former Conservative Party chairwoman, was unlikely to put her motion ldquo the Government whips against.Pointing out how the Prime Ministerrsquos motion left no deal on the table as the default, Ms Soubry said: ldquoIs it the case the Government is giving a free vote on theamendment and yet it is whipping against  ldquoItrsquos a shameful carry on when a former chairman of the Conservative Party is whipped against to the extent she will not push that amendment to the vote.ldquoThis House will be denied the chance to take no-deal off the table ndash thatrsquos the truth of it isnrsquot it Dodging the question, Mr Gove replied: ldquoShe is a distinguished criminal barrister and now I know what itrsquos like to be cross-examined by her but I also know why barristers are paid by the hour.Lost voice lsquobut not lost her focus on national interestrsquoMichael Gove stood in for the Prime Minister at the opening of the no deal Brexit debate, and began by praising her saying: ldquoShe may temporarily have lost her voice, but what she has not lost, and will never lose, is her focus in the national interest, and a full-hearted desire to do what is right for our country.The Environment Secretary said since Mrs May lost the first meaningful vote on her Withdrawal Agreement in January she has spent ldquomore than  hours at the despatch box, and: ldquoHas shown fortitude, tenacity, thoughtfulness, diligence ndash and above all an unselfish and unstinting patriotism.Mr Gove said it was only appropriate that ldquoon all sides of the House MPs recognise the way in which illustrate the political, economic and reputational risk that the Governmentrsquos make-it-up-as-we-go-along approach poses to the United Kingdom.ldquoToday the Commons must reject any prospect of a the formation of the plan.ldquoShe has her very clear red lines.She set them out ages ago.Theyrsquore much too constraining.ldquoWe rushed into them without thinking about them.And she never actually That is the question that has to be answered before a decision on a possible further extension.ldquoWhy would we extend these discussions  The discussion on Article  is done and dusted. We have the Withdrawal Agreement. It is there.ldquoThat is the question asked and we are waiting for an answer to that.Former foreign secretary Boris Johnson claimed the EU would come up with a new deal by March .He told LBC Radio: ldquoI covered a lot of EU summits, I have been to a lot of them in my time, I have seen how the EU works.ldquoThe horses always change places in the final furlong, itrsquos always at five minutes to midnight that the real deal is done.ldquoIn Brussels the real fix is always in at the end.Cameron: No deal a disasterDavid Cameron has warned MPs that failing to rule out a no-deal Brexit would be a ldquodisaster for Britain.The former Conservative prime minister said he backed Theresa Mayrsquos attempts to secure a deal despite her second overwhelming defeat in Parliament on Tuesday night.He told Sky News: ldquoIrsquove always supported the Prime Minister in her attempts to have a close partnership deal with Europe and she continues to have my support.ldquoThatrsquos the right thing to do. Obviously what needs to happen next is to rule out no deal, that would be a disaster for our country, and to seek an extension and Irsquom sure thatrsquos whatrsquos going to happen next.Warning over no-deal tarf regimeA new tarf regime on EU products in the case of a no-deal Brexit will act as a ldquosledgehammer to the UK economy, business has warned.The new levies, to be imposed from the day after a March  BrexitMPs vote for a no-deal withdrawal, would force up prices on EU imports including cars and many food products.The unilateral and temporary regime includes levies of .% on European cars and trucks which had previously been free of tarfs, potentially increasing the cost of a typical family hatchback by around pound,. Car parts would face no extra tarfs to avoid disruption to supply chains.But tarfs will be slashed on imports from outside the EU, potentially lowering prices on goods from countries like the USA and China.CBI director-general Carolyn Fairbairn told BBC Radio rsquos Today: ldquoThis tells us everything that is wrong with a no-deal scenario.

title: key-questions-surrounding-the-brexit-stalemate
story: How did we get to this point The country voted to leave the EU in the referendum.But that was in , so why the continuing uncertainty The House of Commons keeps rejecting the Prime Ministerrsquos deal.What does the deal involve The agreement runs to hundreds of pages but basically it covers financial arrangements, citizensrsquo rights, aims for a future trading relationship and a mechanism or backstop to prevent a future hard border on the island of Ireland.Whatrsquos not to like A large number of Theresa Mayrsquos own Tory MPs and all the DUP MPs she needs for a majority do not like the backstop.And many hardline Brexiteers think no deal would be better than what one critic described on Tuesday as a ldquopolished turd.What would no deal mean Depends who you ask. Some say economic doom and gloom while others argue it would give the UK the freedom to strike its own favourable trade deals with trading partners around the globe.What happensMPs canrsquot agree on a deal One option is to request an extension to the transition period beyond the current agreed deadline of March .Would the UK get an extension It would have to be agreed by the EUrsquos remaining  members states.How long could the extension last It would probably last no longer than May  because otherwise the UK would theoretically have to elect a new set of MEPs to the European Parliament.Would a Brexit extension solve anything It would give the UK more time to end the current stalemate. But given all the isions, it might not be enough.Would a general election help It is what Labour wants but current polling does not suggest any party would win a decisive majority.

title: brexit-advocates-chasing-unicorns-says-irish-premier
story: The Taoiseach made the comments to media in the US on Wednesday while MPs at Westminster prepared to vote on whether they are prepared for the UK to leave the European Union without a deal.As part of his annual St Patrickrsquos Day visit, Mr Varadkar attended a lunch atthe US Chamber of Commerce in Washington DC.ldquoAs we head into the next few weeks it should be blatantly obvious that unicorns only exist in fairytales, he told media at the event.ldquoI would say to people who advocated Brexit ndash is this really what they wanted  Protectionism, borders, tarfs, restrictions on trade.ldquoIs this really what Brexit was all about  And for those who voted against the Withdrawal Agreement on the basis that they feared that Northern Ireland would be treated dferently as a result of the backstop, it must be evident to them now that itrsquos the UK Governmentrsquos intention to treat Northern Ireland dferently.Addressing the UKrsquos tarf proposals in the event of a no-deal Brexit, Mr Varadkar said Northern Ireland will become a back door to the European single market.ldquoI donrsquot think the UKrsquos proposals will be workable for very long. They propose to treat Northern Ireland dferently from the rest of the UK, he said.ldquoNorthern Ireland will become a back door to the European single market and I think that in a matter of months that will lead to the need for checks at Northern Irelandrsquos ports.ldquoSo those that opposed the agreement may find that something very akin to the backstop is applied by the UK Government in a few weeksrsquo time.Mr Varadkar also said that in the event of a no-deal Brexit the European customs code will apply to goods exported from the UK to the EU.ldquoThat will obviously have a severe impact on the UK economy and the Northern Ireland economy in particular.ldquoWestminster can take the no deal off the table this evening, andthey do so then there is the potential to look at alternatives, for example the UK staying in the customs union.Mr Varadkar added that Ireland has been preparing for a no-deal Brexit scenario for a long time.Here in Washington DC and starting a busy week by meeting some friends from home: the Dublin and Belfast Chambers of Commerce pic gvaOFElmdash Leo VaradkarMarch , ldquoWe are well placed to deal with any shock that may arise from a no-deal , he added.ldquoThe fact that we have a budget surplus means that we can borrowwe have to to support our economy.The Taoiseach started his programme of engagements on Wednesday at the US Chamber of Commerce with Enterprise Ireland and Science Foundation Ireland.Irish businesses employ  people in the US and Ireland is the ninth largest source of foreign direct investment here. Irsquom meeting some of these Irish companies who are bringing jobs and investment here in Washington today with @Entirl pic TxYhZFhiYmdash Leo VaradkarMarch , He also attendeda round table meeting with Enterprise Ireland chief executive Julie Sinnamon and senior Irish executives, some of whom will be announcing new investments in the US.There are more than  Irish companies operating at  locations across all  US states, employing more than , American workers.The US Bureau of Economic Analysis calculated the value of Irish direct investment in the US at . billion dollarsin , ranking Ireland as the ninth largest source of foreign direct investment.

title: ancient-britons-travelled-hundreds-of-miles-to-stonehenge-raves
story: They brought home-reared pigs to the feasts, whose discarded bones have been analysed by scientists.The results show that people travelled from as far away as Scotland to attend the ritual ldquoparties in Wiltshire more than , years ago.Researchers examined the bones of  pigs from four Late Neolithic sites serving the famous stone circle monuments at Stonehenge and Avebury.Chemical signals in the bones from the food and water the animals consumed identied the geographical areas where they were raised.The scientists were surprised to find that the pigs had come from as far away as Scotland, north-east England, and west Wales.Lead researcher Dr Richard Madgwick, from the University of Cardf, said: ldquoThis study demonstrates a scale of movement and level of social complexity not previously appreciated.ldquoThese gatherings could be seen as the first united cultural events of our island, with people from all corners of Britain descending on the areas around Stonehenge to feast on food that had been specially reared and transported from their homes.Pigs were the prime source of meat for Neolithic feasting, said the scientists.The team focused on the henge complexes of Durrington Walls, Marden, Mount Pleasant and West Kennet Palisade Enclosures.Dr Madgwick added: ldquoArguably the most startling finding is the efforts that participants invested in contributing pigs that they themselves had raised. Procuring them in the vicinity of the feasting sites would have been relatively easy.ldquoPigs are not nearly as well-suited to movement over distance as cattle and transporting them, either slaughtered or on the hoof, over hundreds or even tens of kilometres, would have required a monumental effort.ldquoThis suggests that prescribed contributions were required and that rules dictated that offered pigs must be raised by the feasting participants, accompanying them on their journey, rather than being acquired locally.The research is reported in the journal Science Advances.

title: lorry-goes-up-in-flames-and-causes-delays-on-the-m1
story: West Yorkshire Fire and Rescue service received a call shortly after pm on Wednesday reporting a vehicle was alight heading southbound on the motorway at Lofthouse.The flames had spread to the nearby banking but no casualties were reported.Footage posted to social media showed a column of fire and smoke streaming hundreds of metres into the air and enveloping nearby homes.One witness said Robin Hood and Lofthouse, about six and a half miles south of Leeds and three and a half miles north of Wakefield, had been ldquoplunged into darkness as smoke billowed over buildings.Lofthouse and Robin Hood plunged into darkness due to a lorry fire on M @WakeExpress @LeedsNews pic gmmMnUvimdash Helen FeeleyMarch , Another described ldquohuge explosions coming from the vehicle.It is not clear what started the blaze or the cargo the lorry was carrying.Huge lorry fire on M! Delays to Leeds ndash Hopefully everyone is okay! #M #MFire pic cqAqHEIODmdash Thomas BrewerMarch , A spokeswoman for Highways England said the southbound carriageway of the M between junctions  and  will remain closed until any potential damage to the road had been assessed and the debris had been cleared.

title: herald-diary-was-theresa-may-angling-for-a-sick-day
story: SOME weather. As reader Alasdair MacKenzie gets in touch to tell us: "It has been quite wet recently, so imagine my surprise this morning to see a council worker watering the plants in Glasgows George Square!"And as a colleague told us: "Its so windy today Ive decided to venture out dressed as a mime artist so I dont look daft when I walk to the shops."ShoppedWE can just imagine the conversation as young Amna was telling her pals on social media about ing to Glasgow. Said Amna: "I was helping out at my dads shop when a customer asked, Oh, arye wan ay the weans  I replied, Aye, just helping out for a wee bit the day. Said the customer, Which wan are ye again  The teacher  Or the wan who never visits "Voice of the peopleSORRY, cant really ignore the Brexit bourach. As Richard Littler comments: "Were not having a second referendum. The will of the people is clear. You cant just keep having referendums until youre happy with the result, says Theresa May as she submits her deal for the third time."And the fact that the Prime Minister was struggling not to lose her voice during her Commonds delivery yesterday did not elicit sympathy from everyone. Said radio presenter Iain Lee: "Theresa May doing her sick voice so she doesnt have to turn up at her work tomorrow. Genius. Weve all done it."AlarmingOUR growing old observation today comes from veteran DJ Tony Blackburn who commented: "You know youre getting older when people call you at pm and askthey woke you up."Took offCHELTENHAM Festival has begun ndash weve already tipped Bellshill in Fridays Gold Cup ndash and we shouldnt forget Scotlands other big connection with the festival which was the late Cumnock-born bookie Freddie Williams who took mammoth bets at the festival without blinking an eye. He was once robbed by armed gunmen as he left the course in his Range Rover, and the next year he arrived by helicopter stating: "If they shoot that down, then good luck to them."Not all of Freddies bookmaking was at the races. In his early days he was at a Cumnock Juniors game where committee members from Cumnocks opponents bet Freddy that they would lose -, which they did. Freddie, though, had shrewdly taken a bundle from locals backing Cumnock to win by at least six.THOSE WERE THE DAYS - : ldquoIf I see a real tragedy in someonersquos hand I keep it from themFood for thoughtTHE things weans say, continued. Says Bob Jamieson: "We took our grandaughters, six and nine, out for the day. As we sat on a bench having a picnic, my we asked, Would Grandad like something to drink  The six-year-old took one look and said, Donrsquot think so Granny, hersquos too busy stuffing his face."JokingTODAYS piece of whimsy comes from a reader who emails: "Tell the punchline first."How do you ruin a joke "Fighting talkBIG birthday yesterday was the th anniversary of the world wide web. Its contribution to our lives was perhaps best summed up by TV station Dave which declared: *The internet is a place where you get to pick fights with strangers and not get thrown out of the pub.*There are millions of dferent websites on the internet but its best to stick to the two or three you know.*You can do anything on the internet, watch opera, find new music, share ideas but its best just to watch gs of dogs.*Always remember that there is a le outside of the internet, but there are people and bees and rain out there so stay safe on the internet.Any other good uses of the internet Camleys Cartoon: Calmac begin business networking cruises to the islands

title: nicola-sturgeon-the-case-for-scottish-independence-has-never-been-stronger
story: The First Minister said the predictable result could have been avoidedMrs May had stood up to ldquoBrexit extremists in the Tory party instead of trying to appease them.She urged MPs to vote tonight against the ldquocatastrophe of no deal and said Brexit should be delayed enough to allow a Peoplersquos Vote to be held with Remain on the ballot paper.The SNPrsquos Westminster leaderIan Blackford suggested a Peoplersquos Vote could be held in the autumn.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoThe Prime Minister and the UK Government should be hanging their heads in shame. We now have a Government that has effectively ceased toand a country that remains poised on a clf edge.ldquoWhat is abundantly clear is the UK Government and Parliament have been unable to turn the result of the  referendum into a workable or deliverable plan to leave the EU.She said the Prime Minister should rule out a no-deal Brexit, rather than offer MPs a free vote on it today.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoRuling out no-deal and extending Article  would stop the clock on Brexit and enable another referendum on EU membership to be held. We will support any such referendum, provided it has the option to remain in the EU on the ballot paper.ldquoScotlandrsquos needs and voice have been ignored by the UK Government throughout the Brexit process. A handful of DUP MPs held more sway over Scotlandrsquos future than our own national Parliament ndash that demonstrates more clearly than ever the case for Scotland becoming an independent country has never been stronger. We will continue to stand up for Scotland and to reflect our nationrsquos overwhelming vote to remain in the EU.Scottish Secretary David Mundell said he was ldquodisappointed but not surprised by the -vote defeat for Mrs Mayrsquos deal, which he said was only ldquomarginally better than the -vote defeat in January.He said it had been a ldquogood deal offering an orderly exit and a positive new relationship with Europe.He said: ldquoI will be backing the Prime Ministerrsquos motion to decline a no-deal outcome. I think that would be wholly negative for Scotland, and I donrsquot want to see, and have never wanted to see, that outcome. Indeed, thatrsquos why Irsquove supported this deal.He said he still hoped the coming days would see the emergence of ldquoan agreed basis for leaving the EU that can command majority support across Parliament.Mr Blackford said Mrs May was ldquoin office, but not in power.Calling for an extension of Article , he said: ldquoScotland voted to remain in the EU and we must not be dragged out against our will. The case for independence is stronger than ever. If Westminster continues to prove incapable of respecting Scotlandrsquos wishes Scotland will move to protect our own interests.For Labour, shadow Scottish secretary Lesley Laird said: ldquoAfter weeks of running down the clock, Theresa Mayrsquos dreadful deal has been defeated again in the Commons.ldquoThis is a Prime Minister, in office but not in power, who drew needless red lines to appease hardline Brexiteers instead of reaching out in common sense to find common ground. Parliament must now vote to take no deal off the table.Dr Liz Cameron, head of Scottish Chambers of Commerce, said the defeat would add to the ldquogrowing frustration and disappointment felt by businesses around the country.She said: ldquoFirms have shouldered the burden of uncertainty too long, and this result will further impact on our capacity to trade, invest and hire.ldquoBusiness communities have warned time and time again that the UK is not ready to face the consequences of a disorderly exit from the European Union.ldquoYet, we are alarmingly close to departing without a clearly thought-out plan - this must not be allowed to happen on th March, whether by default or design.ldquoWith only  days to go, politicians on all sides must deliver for business and the economy, and seek to avoid the debilitating consequences of a no deal outcome would have on the Scottish and UK economy.Scottish LibDemsrsquo MP Jamie Stone said: ldquoThe Prime Ministerrsquos government has lost its authority and cannot take this forward. Parliament now has to get no deal off the table. MPs should extend Article  to allow time to exit from this mess through a Peoplersquos Vote, with the option of remaining in the EU.Kerry Buist, director of Scotland For A Peoplersquos Vote, said: ldquoYet again, the UK Government has been defeated by a huge majority on one of the most important votes ever brought to the House of Commons ndash with per cent of Scottish MPs rejecting Theresa Mayrsquos bad deal.ldquoA further spin of the wheel at Westminster for this dead deal would be utterly pointless. Instead, there is only one way forward ndash to hand the final decision back to the publicthrough a Peoplersquos Vote.ldquoPolls show that people in the rest of the UK have joined with voters in Scotland in not wanting Brexit at all anymore ndash a Peoplersquos Vote is a democratic opportunity for Scotlandrsquos wish to stay in the EU to be respected Edinburgh."South Labour MP Ian Murray, an advocate of a Peoplersquos Vote, said: ldquoThis latest humiliating defeat for the Prime Minister shows that she cannot command the support of MPs for her disastrous deal. Itrsquos is disgraceful that she has run down the clock, and with time running out she must now stop playing this reckless game with peoplersquos livelihoods.ldquoIt is vital we seek to extend Article , rule out a calamitous no deal Brexit, and go back to the people with the option to keep the best deal we currently have as a member of the EU.

title: soap-barons-bid-to-change-islands-way-of-life-is-marked-100-years-on
story: Generations of families have toiled to survive, digging for peat to warm their home, growing what meagre crops could survive the westerly gales and venturing into the roaring seas to fish for herring.Today, islands such as Harris and Lewis are attracting a new generation keen to keep alive traditions, skills and heritage.Yet,  years ago, one incomerrsquos vision of a more modern way of le was fuelling croftersrsquo wrath, and would inadvertently go on to help spark one of the most dramatic upheavals in land ownership of the age.Soap baron Lord Leverhulme arrived on his newly-acquired island of Lewis in  with a vision to propel crofters into a modern world ndash a move that could have seen a precious and fragile way of island le lost forever.Instead, he encountered a strong-willed group of locals who not only wanted to retain their way of le, but to firmly reject his.Later this year Lord Leverhulmersquos botched attempt to sht reluctant islanders into factory jobs ndash sparking a series of bitter land grabs ndash will be remembered during a three-day event on the island.The gathering, in September, will be a chance for islanders to reflect on how close they came to losing their much-loved way of le.The  clash between Lancashire-born soap baron William Hesketh Lever, known for his ldquoforced labour style of management, and the spirited crofters and cotters , pitched th century progression against age-old clan heritage, and it would end in humiliation for the powerful businessman.one of the business worldrsquos most powerful men.ldquoLeverhulme didnrsquot understand what the people wanted and was baffled by the fact they didnrsquot welcome his proposals, says historian Dr Iain Robertson, who explores the episode in his book Landscapes Of Protest In The Scottish Highlands After .In the end, the author adds, rather than unpick what he saw as an outdated way of le by removing crofts in favour of large farms and a modern fish-processing industry, Lord Leverhulme strengthened crofting heritage and even laid the foundations for the pivotal  Land Act and the bedrock for todayrsquos flourishing community right-to-buy land schemes.Lord Leverhulme bought Lewis for pound, in . The semi-retired earl, whose Lever Bros business would go on to form part of giant Unilever, believed the croftersrsquo outmoded way of le needed a visionary like him to revolutionise their communities.He believed a mechanised fishing industry with ice factory, canning and processing plants to feed his UK-wide network of businesses could end the back-breaking task of toiling the land and allow crofts to merge to create single, sprawling farms, boosting his fortunes in the process.ldquoThere was a strong aspect of late Victorian paternalism, of people in poverty and seeing the crofting way of le as a very backward one, adds Mr Robertson.ldquoHe thought these were impoverished people in need of being improved. He didnrsquot see any benefit in crofting and thought what Lewis and Harris needed were more large farms ndash dairy farms in particular ndash and that the people should go to work on the farms or in his fish processing and canning factory.Resistance came, in particular, from young men home from the First World War. Angry at having been initially promised crofts on their , they drew inspiration from the rebellious actions of the Red Clydesiders and organised themselves in military-style groups.Together they marched on crofts that Leverhulmersquos farms had swamped, and carried out a series of land grabs to take them back. Sixteen of Lord Leverhulmersquos  Lewis farms were affected, while his threat to evict the crofters drew little public or political sympathy.ldquoLeverhulme didnrsquot understand the crofts and cotters. They didnrsquot want what he was offering, it was incompatible with their lives, says Mr Robertson, a lecturer at the University of Highlands and Islands.ldquoTherersquos a Gaelic word lsquoduthcashrsquo an amalgam of a sense of heritage and a fundamental belief in common rights. They believed they had a right to inherit land ndash even land they didnrsquot own.A showdown between Lord Leverhulme and croftersrsquo representatives symbolised the yawning gap between the two.The episode is marked today by the Gress Raiders Memorial. Eventually, Lord Leverhulme gave in and switched focus to Harris, where a small fortune was ploughed into creating his modern vision in the fishing port of Obbe ndash hastily renamed Leverburgh. He died in .But the episode prompted Parliament to pass rethink croftersrsquo rights and passed the Land Settlement Scotland Act , which gave government the right to remove land from private ownership and deliver it to the people.Today, it is accompanied by more recent ldquoright to buy legislation that gives communities, such as recently happened in Ulva, the chance to push for landowners to sell land to them.Mr Robertson said: ldquoLeverhulme wanted to completely reorganise how the land was worked on Lewis and Harris. The irony is in many ways, he helped keep it alive.

title: Rosemary Goring  Owners must be compelled to maintain A-listed buildings
story: Its current owner says that the A-listed building is in the process of being repaired after serious water damage in , and that he intends to be living in it by Christmas. Experts, however, take a less optimistic view. One, Susan Hallsworth, believes thatit is not immediately repaired, within a decade it will be beyond saving. Meanwhile, Scottish Borders Council is liaising with the proprietor over the ongoing renovation, and progress thereof.Since the studio has been designated ldquoAt Risk by Historic Environment Scotland , the agency that protects the countryrsquos most historically valuable buildings and properties, we should remain hopeful that, with so many concerned eyes upon it, the studio will be resuscitated in the nick of time. But it is not a certainty, and as many at HES must doubtless feel, it should not have been allowed to fall into such a state in the first place.Lately I have learned a great deal about some of our most priceless properties, be they country houses or castles, sheep pens or coal mines. Ask me the dimensions of the Titan Crane on Clydebank, and I could reel them off. Want to discuss the visionary genius of Charlotte Square in Edinburgh  Irsquoll give it a go. I could even hold forth,required, on the origins and s of corrugated iron, a subject I never realised was so gripping.Read more: MSP call for public inquiry into GSA fireAll this has been for a book called The A-List, about  of the most fascinating properties on this register. One of them, of course, is the Bernat Klein Studio. This elegant, light-filled construction is a delightful example of the modernist work of Wormersley, among whose other structures are the ndash in my opinion ugly ndash football stand for Fairydean FC in Galashiels, to which architects flock from all over the world.Yet while the Klein Studio is of the architectural first-rank, it is also a landmark in the story of the Borders textile industry. A vital part of our industrial legacy, itrsquos a reminder of the boost that Klein, whose tweeds and textiles were picked up by the likes of Chanel and Dior, gave to a region whose mills were almost as dilapidated when he arrived in the s as his studio looks today.The role of HES in preserving our built environment goes on largely unseen and, as the studio shows, being placed on the A-list does not guarantee a buildingrsquos safety. If only. How painful to think that, with the exception of Edinburgh Castle, probably our most famous single building was the Glasgow School of Art. It was A-listed, yet still appears not to have been taken care of properly. That magnicent, inspiring edice ought to have been one of the cornerstones of the A-list, yet now it is a blackened shell.The Governmentrsquos culture committee, tasked with examining the fires that destroyed Charles Rennie Mackintoshrsquos masterpiece, came to the conclusion that there should be a public inquiry. More interestingly, it also advocated that HES be given powers to compel owners or custodians to safeguard celebrated buildings.An inquiry, sadly, wonrsquot bring back the school, but enhancing the authority with which HES can act would be a step in the right direction. At the moment, as with any listed building, custodians of the A-list cannot make structural changes without permission. Itrsquos a protracted and restricting procedure, which probably makes some deeply regret their purchase. Yet while these are necessary and important safeguards, there are none, it seems, that allow HES to step in and prevent ruination. As the examples of the Glasgow School of Art and the Bernat Klein Studio make abundantly plain, this has to change, and fast.If the A-listare deemed a crucial part of the nationrsquos heritage, upkeep ought to be a legal obligation on all caretakers. If this proves unreasonably expensive, then financial assistance should be available. Otherwise who would ever buy somewhere with a roof bigger than a coal shed, or with acres of harling that might not last another winter To be honest, I can think of few things more thrilling than living in a slice of history ndash ideally a Border keep. It would be a heavy responsibility, but also a privilege. Who caresitrsquos impossible to install a power shower or stairlt  Our time on this earth is fleeting. As with the land under our feet, we are not lords and masters of our venerable houses or castles, merely ndash as goes the advert for a pricey range of watches ndash taking care of them for future generations.

title: letters-it-really-is-time-now-for-a-peoples-vote
story: However, one wonders what good an extension will actually do given the negotiating position of both the EU and the UK. The UK is deadlocked, in terms of its people, Parliament and Cabinet and the likelihood of any semblance of a deal that commands the majority of the House of Commons is unlikely. This is especially true given the deep isions within the Tories, both Remainers and Leavers, as well as opposition from the DUP.Given this situation those like myself have long argued that a UK-wide referendum on the deal, now that we know its contents, with the option to remain in the EU, is the only credible way to break this deadlock.As David Davis, the former Brexit Secretary and an ardent Leaver, pointed out before the EU referendum: ldquoIf a democracy cannot change its mind, it ceases to be a democracy.There are few I know who voted for Brexit in the belief it would make them poorer, and it is up to the public to give its view on whether the deal, and more importantly its implications, are what it wants.For once I agree with Jacob Rees-Mogg who previously supported a vote on the renegotiated settlement. A statement he now curiously seems to have forgotten.The Scottish Parliament has led the way in backing a Peoplersquos Vote and now that we know the precise nature of the deal, it is up to the public to have its say.Alex Orr,Flat ,  Marchmont Road, Edinburgh.THE intransigence of the EU is breathtaking. The way forward must therefore be either no deal now, or a second referendum that respects the result of the first and poses only two questions, Theresa Mays deal or no deal.This might just be a wake up call to the SNP, which needs to be far more aware of the straightjacket EU membership would lead toScotland were independent. Maybe even at this late stage, the SNP will realise we are better together and call off indyref and its awful consequences for Scotland.EU membership is no magic cure, it is simply another headache.Dr Gerald Edwards,Broom Road, Glasgow.Read more: UK Government behaving towards Holyrood asit is a dictatorship, claims RussellAS the Brexit fiasco gets more ridiculous every day, the present focus seems to be entirely on ldquothe backstop. However we seem to be forgetting why the UKvoted to leave Europe. You will recall that big red bus, much was made of the ldquovast sums of money we were handing over to the EU every week, with no mention of what was ed in the way of subsidies to farming and fishing. also capital contributions to a plethora of infrastructure and other projects throughout the UK.I have just received my tax code notication for the next financial year on the back page of this document there is a pie chart showing how my tax contributes to public spending. Under ldquoUK contribution to the EU budget" I am paying pound, or . per cent of the total.This segment of the chart is so small that it appears as virtually a single line.So, for the price of a pizza and a wee glass of wine I am being dragged out of the EU against my will, and my European citizenship gone.At least Irsquove still got my UK citizenship and a passport, unlike our European friends who have lived, worked and paid taxes here for many years and and are now facing distressing uncertainty over their future.The politicians who are allowing this to happen are a disgrace, and will not be forgiven for destroying our economy and the rights we have enjoyed for more than  years.Angus Ferguson, Hutton, Glasgow.THE Prime Ministers own political survival has surely now been dealt irreversible damage and a no- deal Brexit which critically endangers our economy, democracy and international standing, will, almost certainly, be rejected by our parliamentarians.Following a likely extension to Article  this week, the country will remain in a political and constitutional paralysis, with a moribund Prime Minister, and a ided Government and Opposition. The call for a second referendum may now result in even more instability and uncertainty in the country and even invoke civil unrest.David Cameron left Mrs May with the ultimate poisoned chalice. She has failed to negotiate the Brexit maze and deliver a deal that even superficially unites the British people.Her only recourse now is to call a General Election to let the people decide what path to follow democratically. Her resignation will, irrespective of the result, inevitably follow.Owen Kelly, Dunvegan Drive, Stirling.AS the Brexit clock ticks away, hardliners who will not accept any deal other than simply walking away, will likely find the SNP joining them in the voting lobby. Nicola Sturgeon and her colleagues are determined to see nothing good in any plan the UK proposes. Instead of course they seek to link Brexit and independence. Amongst other things, this includes the knowingly misleading assumption that those in the majority who voted to stay in the UK in , and who went on to vote Remain in , would somehow support the SNPrsquos demand to break-up the UK on the promise of a possible future in the EU .As leading figures in the independence movement are falling out amongst themselves over just how much austerity they are willing to accept to join the EU, we must hope that as Ms Sturgeon demands the power to call an independence referendum rerun, she has the good grace to be honest about the very real prospect of separating from the UK only to find we are also left stranded outside of the EU.Keith Howell,White Moss, West Linton, Peeblesshire.

title: disruption-as-storm-gareth-batters-scotland-with-gales-of-up-to-75mph

title: brexit-five-things-you-need-to-know-about-the-next-48-hours
story: Events over the next two days will have a major impact on how, when - and- the UK leaves the European Union. Here are five things you need to know about the next  hours in Brexit.:Nicola Sturgeon: Tories should hang their heads in shame over Brexit chaos- What is happening in Westminster MPs will vote on today on whether they want to leave the European Union without a Withdrawal Agreement and Political Declaration - a no-deal Brexit.The Prime Minister warned that a no-deal scenario would be "bleak", with a "signicant economic shock", the loss of security co-operation with Europe and the prospect of the break-up of the UK as support for Scottish independence and a united Ireland could increase.:MPs to vote on blocking no-deal Brexit after Theresa May suffers defeatShould MPs reject that, there will be another vote on whether Parliament wants to seek an extension to Article  - delaying the UKs departure beyond the current March  deadline.But Mrs May stressed that would not resolve the isions in the Commons and could instead hand Brussels the power to set conditions on the kind of Brexit on offer "or even moving to a second referendum".- How could Brexit be delayed and for how long To secure an extension to Article , Mrs May would need the support of the  other EU states. They are likely to agree to an extension as long as there was a prospect of a deal being reached - or a referendum or general election which could change the political landscape at Westminster.European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker said that Brexit should be completed before the European elections which take place between May  and ."If the UK has not left the EU by then, it will be legally required to hold these elections," he said.If a longer extension was sought, that would mean taking part in the elections, something likely to fuel Eurosceptic anger - and potentially see Nigel Farage standing for the new Brexit Party.- Who is supporting an extension Tory former Brexit minister Steve Baker has tabled a "Malthouse Compromise" amendment to Wednesdays motion with Tory colleagues which would seek extension of Article  until May .It was signed by Damian Green, Iain Duncan Smith, Nicky Morgan, Steve Baker, Jacob Rees-Mogg, Simon Hart and the DUPs Nigel Dodds.The amendment calls for the Government to "seek an extension of the Article  process to .pm on May nd , at which point the UK would leave the EU".Thereafter, it says, "in a spirit of co-operation and in order to begin discussions on the Future Relationship, the Government should offer a further set of mutual standstill agreements with the EU and Member States for an agreed period ending no later than th December ".- Will the Prime Minister seek further changes in Brussels Mr Juncker was clear during his meeting with the Prime Minister in Strasbourg that there was no more room for movement."In politics, sometimes you get a second chance. It is what we do with this second chance that counts. Because there will be no third chance," he said.:What amendments have been tabled to no-deal Brexit motion "There will be no further interpretations of the interpretations and no further assurances of the re-assurances."But a European Council summit on March  could give Mrs May one last chance to persuade her fellow leaders face-to-face that she needs extra help to get a deal over the line.- So what happens on March  Impossible to say at this stage. If a deal is somehow reached and legislated for then although the UK will formally leave the EU at pm, very little will change as a transition period will smooth progress to the UKs new future.If there is a delay, the UK will still be in the European Union until the extension period expires.Butthere is a no-deal Brexit, things are a lot more uncertain - the Government has been ramping up preparations to try to prevent shortages of food and medicine amid fears that increased bureaucracy will clog up key ports where goods arrive from the Continent.:Kirsty Blackman: Scotlands best future would be as an independent nation in the EU

title: tariffs-to-be-slashed-on-many-imports-from-outside-the-eu-in-no-deal-brexit
story: But some products coming from the remaining  EU member states which are currently imported free of tarfs will now face levies for the first time.Ministers said that, overall, the changes would represent a ldquomodest liberalisation of the UKrsquos tarf regime.Among the % of imports by value which will be subject to tarfs will be:ndash Beef, lamb, pork and poultry and some dairy products, in order to protect UK farmers and producers from cheap importsndash A number of tarfs on finished vehicles to support the automotive sector, which will not apply to car parts imported from the EU to prevent disruption to supply chainsndash Products including certain ceramics, fertiliser and fuel, where tarfs protect UK producers against unfair practices like dumping and state subsidiesndash Goods including bananas, raw cane sugar and certain kinds of fish, where tarfs are used to permit preferential access to the UK market for developing countries.Proposed tarf rates on a range of food products were announced as a proportion of the so-called ldquomost favoured nationcurrently imposed by the EU on imports from countries which do not have a free trade agreement.Rates include beef , poultry meat , sheep meat , pig meat , butter , Cheddar-like cheese , protected fish and seafood productsand milled and semi-milled products .Tarfs on finished cars and trucks will be set at .%, down from the EU MFN rate of .%, while for finished buses the rate will remain unchanged at .%.Other rates include .% on mineral products, .% on chemical products, . on fertilisers, .% on plastics and rubber, .% on leather and hides, .% on textiles and textile products, .% on stone and cement, .% on ceramics, .% on glass and .% on transport equipment.Trade Policy Minister George Hollingbery said: ldquoOur priority is securing a deal with the EU as this will avoid disruption to our global trading relationships. However we must prepare for all eventualities.ldquoIf we leave without a deal, we will set the majority of our import tarfs to zero, whilst maintaining tarfs for the most sensitive industries.ldquoThis balanced approach will help to support British jobs and avoid potential price spikes that would hit the poorest households the hardest.ldquoIt represents a modest liberalisation of tarfs and we will be monitoring the economy closely as well as consulting with businesses to decide what our tarfs should be after this transitional period.

title: edinburgh-fringe-urges-capital-residents-to-provide-a-room-for-artists-during-2019-festival
story: The Fringe, the worlds biggest cultural festival, will today announce a new partnership with an online booking , TheatreDigsBooker, which the festival hopes will increase the amount of affordable accommodation for artists in the city.The festival, which has noted accommodation as a key issue for artists at the annual event, is now encouraging Edinburgh residents "with a passion for the arts to share their homes with a Fringe participant."The Fringe would like residents to host a performerthey have a spare room and are prepared not to charge the performers the highest rates.A statement said that the Fringe Society are "looking for people who are primarily interested in the experience both they and the artists can share, as opposed to the financialthey can gain.:ARTS NEWS: New director for Scottish Dance Theatre, Kickstarter and the Fringe make deal, Auld Alliance inspires exhibitionTheatreDigsBooker is a website designed specically for artists seeking accommodation across the UK, and was established in .No money is changing hands in the deal, a Fringe spokeswoman said, but the two would be working together to increase the amount of "affordable" accommodation in the city during August.The Fringes Blueprint, a series of ideas about its future launched last year, includes the plan to increase the availability of accommodation through partnerships with accommodation and transport providers.The Fringe has also arranged an agreement with Queen Margaret University and Napier University.Both will be providing "affordable rooms specically for artists", the Fringe said.Shona McCarthy, chief executive of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe Society said: "The Fringe Society is committed to making accommodation more affordable for artists at the Fringe, and I am delighted to announce this important step in tackling one of the biggest issues participants face."In partnership with TheatreDigsBookerrsquos online , we are reaching out to the residents of Edinburgh to register their property and host an artist in their spare room."Over a third of Edinburgh residents visit the Fringe during August and this is another way they can engage and support the artists that make this festival erse, inclusive and amazing."Ensuring that those participating at the fringe, including performers, producers and technical staff can continue to bring incredible work to our city each year, irrespective of background or financial status. Itrsquos also a fantastic opportunity to see the Fringe in a whole new light."The founder of TheatreDigsBooker, said: "The team and I are really excited to be working with the Fringe."We love the festival and everything that it brings to the theatre industry."We hope that pooling our combined resources will make finding and booking accommodation for the Fringe easier than ever and make a genuine dference to participants experience."Around  private hosts are already listed on TheatreDigsBooker in the Edinburgh area.

title: cyclist-struck-by-lorry-at-kings-road-junction-in-portobello
story: Police were called to Sir Harry Lauder Road at the Kings Road junction with Portobello Road at .amfollowing a report that a cyclist had been struck by a lorry.The -year-old man was later confirmed to have died at the scene.Portobello High Streetremained closed between Portobello Road and Bath Street until .pm while collision investigations continued and the lorry was recovered.Sergeant John Easton said: "Weve now contacted the cyclists family and our thoughts are with them at this very dficult time."Extensive road closures and ersions were put in place in the Portobello area to allow emergency services safe access to the scene, and I want to thank motorists and the local community for their co-operation."Id urge anyone who may have witnessed this or who has information that could be relevant, especially those travelling in the area at the time with dashcam footage, to contact us as soon as possiblethey have not already spoken to officers."

title: spring-statement-at-a-glace-the-main-points-from-chancellor-philip-hammonds-budget
story: - Mr Hammond said Tuesdays vote to reject the EU Withdrawal Agreement "leaves a cloud of uncertainty hanging over the economy" and his most urgent task is to lt it.- Funding totalling an additional pound million is to be made available immediately to police forces in England to pay for additional overtime targeted on kne crime and new Violent Crime Reduction Units.- The Office for Budget Responsibility forecasts GDP growth of .% this year, then .% in  and .% for each of the following three years. The OBR expects to see , new jobs by , with wage growth at % or higher in each year of the forecast period.- Borrowing this year will be .% of GDP - pound billion lower than forecast at the Autumn Budget. Borrowing will be pound. billion in  , then pound. billion, pound. billion and pound. billion in the following years to reach pound. billion in   - its lowest level in  years.- The Government remains "on track" to meet both of its fiscal targets early, with the cyclically adjusted deficit at .% next year and falling to .% by  . Headroom against the fiscal mandate increases from pound. billion at the time of the Autumn Budget to pound. billion today.- Debt is forecast to be lower in every year than predicted at the Budget, falling to .% of GDP next year, then %, .% and % in the following years and % in  .- Mr Hammond said he will decide in the Spending Review later this year how to share the proceeds from any "Deal Dividend",the UK leaves the EU with a deal, between increased spending on public services, capital investment and keeping taxes low.- The Chancellor warned that the countrys economic progress will be at risk in a no-deal Brexit, and said he was "confident" that the Commons will agree a smooth and orderly EU withdrawal "over the coming weeks".:Malthouse Compromise: What is it, will it work and what next - Mr Hammond announced up to pound million for the Borderlands Growth deal covering the border regions of England and Scotland, and said negotiations are progressing on future deals for mid-Wales and Derry Londonderry.- A pound million package of reforms to help small businesses take on more apprentices, announced in the Autumn Budget, is to be brought forward to the start of the new financial year in April.- From June, the UK will begin to abolish the requirement for paper landing cards at points of entry to the country and will allow citizens of the USA, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, Japan, Singapore and South Korea to use e-gates at airports and Eurostar terminals.- Mr Hammond announced a new pound billion Affordable Homes Guarantee scheme to support delivery of around , affordable homes and pound million from the Housing Infrastructure Fund to unlock up to , new homes on sites in west London, Cheshire, Didcot and Cambridge.- Some , square kilometres of ocean around Ascension Island is to be declared a Marine Protected Area.:Brexit: Fallout continues as MPs get set to vote on blocking no-deal- The Government will fund free sanitary products in secondary schools and colleges in England from the next school year.Labours shadow chancellor John McDonnell responded to the Spring Statement, saying: "We have just witnessed a display by the Chancellor of this Governments toxic mix of callous complacency over austerity and its grotesque incompetence over the handling of Brexit."Whilst teachers are having to pay for the materials their pupils need, working parents are struggling to manage as school close early, their children are sent home, , of our fellow citizens will be sleeping in the cold and wet on the streets tonight."Young people are being stabbed to death in rising numbers. And the Chancellor turns up today with no real end or reversal of austerity and to threaten us because this is what he means that austerity can only endwe accept this Governments bad deal over Brexit."Mr McDonnell said downgrading forecasts were a "pattern" under Mr Hammond before he criticised Government borrowing.He added: "On the deficit, hes boasting about the deficit - hes not eliminated the deficit as we were promised by ."Hes simply shted it on to the shoulders of headteachers, NHS managers, local councillors and police commissioners and, worst of all, onto the backs of many of the poorest in our society."The consequences are stark - infant mortality has increased, le-expectancy has reduced, and our communities are less safe."Police budgets have faced a cut of pound. billion since  and nothing the Chancellor has said today will make up for the human and economic consequences of those cuts."Mr McDonnell added there is "nothing balanced" about a Government giving more than pound billion of tax cuts to the rich and corporations while " people a day die before they receive the care they need".

title: french-castle-with-17-bedrooms-goes-on-sale-for-5m
story: Currently owned by two artists, the th century Chacircteau de Lamothe has its own art studio, outdoor kitchen, wine cellar, private cinema and parking for  cars.Once the summer residence of the Roman Catholic Bishops of Oloran, the estate has views of the Pyrenees mountains and gardens lined with -year-old magnolia trees.The enormous fully-restored castle features original chandeliers, murals,ling and stone fireplaces, and is a short drive from both the ski slopes and the coast.Read more: of Scotlands favourite castlesValued at euro,,, it has been used as a luxury bed and breakfast formore than a decade and is going up for auction with Concierge Auctionswithout a reserve.Paulina Kimbel, vice president of business development at Concierge Auctions, said: ldquoThis is our second sale in the region of Pau and we are delighted to be ing to this picturesque corner of Southwest France."Chacircteau de Lamothe represents an ideal holiday home for those wholove to entertain or a savvy investment opportunity, with the estate already perfectly set-up as a rental property or events space."Dating back to the th century it was previously the summer residence of the Bishops of Oloran - a former Roman Catholic Diocese dating back to the th century.The main chacircteau features , square feet of living space including awood-led library, wine cellar, multiple reception rooms, nine bedrooms and a home cinema.A separate annex includes eight en-suite bathrooms, a bar and more reception rooms.There is a secluded swimming pool with terrace, an outdoor kitchen, parking for  cars and mature gardens.The entire estate has recently been restored, including a complete overhaul of the roofing, wiring, plumbing, and landscaping.Read more:The Cool List: Scottish castles you must visitThe chacircteau is three minute walk from the riverside town of Oloron Sainte Marie, which has a private airfield.The ski slopes of the Pyrenees are reachable in just under an hour by roadand the coastal resort of Biarritz is nearby too.The property will sell without reserve to the highest bidder on  March,and bidding opens on March .

title: philip-hammond-scotland-gets-its-fair-share-and-precious-little-thanks-we-get-for-it
story: It came following an exchange with Kirsty Blackman who criticised the government for their austerity measures and said that Scotland was missing out.:Theresa May confirms she will vote to block no-deal BrexitAccording to the AberdeenNorth MP, Scotlands resource block grant for  was almost bn lower in real terms than it was in , a result of the Conservative "obsession" with austerity.The Scottish MP also called criticised the introduction of Universal Credit saying that "Scotland has been badly served by consecutive Westminster governments" and that people in the UK had suffered from "a decade worth of austerity."The SNP economy spokesperson also called for the Westminster government to easevisa constraints andtackle the benefits freeze. title: chancellor-hints-at-soft-brexit-to-end-impasse
story: Despite Numbers  insisting Theresa Mayrsquos twice-defeated deal is the best option, the Chancellor suggested a revised deal for a better ldquofuture relationship was the answer.He also held out the prospect of a poundbn ldquodeal idendno-deal was avoided and the damaging uncertainty over Brexit was put to bed.Labour said it showed the Tories were moving towards their proposal for a far softer Brexit.Addressing MPs at the end of his lsquomini-budgetrsquo, Mr Hammond said Tuesday nightrsquos -vote defeat for Mrs Mayrsquos withdrawal deal mean he was not where he had hoped to be.He said: ldquoThe uncertainty that I hoped we would lt last night, still hangs over us. Tomorrow [the day of a vote to delay Brexit], we will have the opportunity to start to map out a way forward towards building a consensus across this house for a deal we can, collectively support, to exit the EU in an orderly way to a future relationship that will allow Britain to flourish, protecting jobs and businesses.
